answer: Ton cher mari` + Ton chère femme`

question: What is the closing for a semi-formal letter?
answer: Chaleureusement ('warmly' for more casual correspondence) + Amicalement + Cdlt + SVP + STP; Alternative: Cordialement always works.

question: What is the closing for a formal letter?
answer: Bien à vous (with respect) + (Bien) Cordialement + Mes meilleures salutations + Sincères salutations (only for business correspondence; super polite; similar to 'best regards') + Veuillez recevoir` Madame` Monsieur` mes salutations distinguées.

question: a family name + a first name
answer: un nom + un prénom

question: My name is x.
answer: Je m'appelle x. OR...informally: Moi c'est x.

question: But my friends call me x.
answer: Mais mes amis m'appellent x.

question: a nickname
answer: un surnom; Take care because this is a 'faux ami'. It does not mean surname (British English for last name).

question: What is your name? (informal)
answer: Comment tu t'appelles? / Quel est ton nom?; nom is masculine so QUEL and ton must agree with it

question: What is your name? (formal)
answer: Comment vous vous appelez? / Quel est votre/ton nom?; nom is masculine so QUEL and VOTRE must agree with it

question: I am x years old (this year).
answer: J'ai x ans (cette‿année).; The number + ans is spoken very quickly; it's also fully linked together (e.g. 44‿ans = 'catr-von-ca-TRON' where the end of the number has a liaison with ans); ans is a very quick nasal sound 'on' on the end; 'This year' is a duration so use année. Ans is used for counting (e.g. years old).

question: How do you pronounce when saying you or someone's age?
answer: there is always a linking between number and 'ans'; 'ans' is pronounced 'oh' super nasal

question: How old are you (informal)?
answer: Quel âge a tu?; Use QUEL because âge is masculine and singular here.; Do not ask: Combien d'ans as-tu? This does not make sense in french. Use âge instead.

question: How old are they?
answer: Quels sont leurs âges?; Use QUELS because âge is masculine and we are using the plural here.

question: I am X meters tall.
answer: Je mesure ('meh-zoor') 1`8 mètres.; MESURER triggers avec.

question: I am a software engineer.
answer: Many options: 1) Je suis ingénieure logicieles/software. 2) Je suis développeure/développeuse (informatique). 3) ingénieure informatique = engineer of computer science ('IT'); programeur/programmeuse is an outdated term.

question: What is the formal name for a software engineer - if you write it?
answer: Ingénieur en développement logiciel or Ingénieur en génie logiciel

question: I have a health issue. + I have a serious medical condition.
answer: J'ai des problèmes de santé. + J'ai une condition médicale très sérieuse/grave.; médical(e) (= medical) is an irregular adjective. It becomes médiCAUX when it modifies a plural noun. e.g. les cabinets médicaux = the medical offices

question: I am healthy + I am sick.
answer: Je suis en bonne santé. + Je suis malade.; Use 'en bonne santé' to describe the health of a person.; Generally: sain is used for objects. santé is used for people.

question: not healthy / not good for your health (like for food)
answer: pas sain; Do not use this to say that a person is not in good health.

question: I eat healthily.
answer: Two idiomatic options: 1) Je mange équilibré (most idiomatic). OR Je suis un régime sain. (= I follow a healty diet.); Less idiomatic but possible: Je mange sainement. Sainement is an adverb that describes an activity (verb) that is good for a person's health (santé).; Generally: sain is used for objects. santé is used for people.

question: healthy food + junk food
answer: la nourriture saine + la malbouffe; BOUFFER is an informal verb meaning 'to eat'.

question: less calories (e.g. for a diet)
answer: un faible nombre de calories; faible means weaker but it can also mean a small(er) amount.

question: organic
answer: organique OR bio; Bio is more commonly used (than organique) to describe healthy/natural food.; When speaking in terms of science and chemistry... organique and biologique have the same meanings as in english.

question: What do you say when someone sneezes?
answer: á tes souhaits (a-te-sway) ...familiar / á vos souhaits ...formal

question: I must be careful. (e.g. to avoid catching virus) + I pay attention to the stairs.
answer: Je dois faire attention. + Je fais attention aux escaliers.; faire attention + À + noun

question: No problem.
answer: pas DE problème OR (Il n'y a) pas de soucis (no worries; 'soo-see'); Use generic preposition DE because PAS is a quantity.

question: Don't worry. / No worries.
answer: T'inquiète (pas). OR Ne vous inquiétez (pas).; inquiéter = to worry; This is a common saying so often the 'ne' and 'pas' are dropped/implied.

question: I have a problem/worry.
answer: J'ai un souci.; This is much more idiomatic than: J'ai un problème. It uses the same word base as we do for no worries / no problem (pas de soucis)

question: to stay + to take away (when ordering at a café)
answer: sur place + emporter; EMPORTER means 'to take out' and can apply to many things.

question: to pick up (from a store)
answer: pour récupérer (literally: to recover)

question: to recover
answer: récupérer; This can be used in many ways. e.g. to recover during a vacation = récupérer des forces / des énergies pendant les vacances

question: I feel 20 years old again.
answer: J'ai rajeuni de 20 ans.; rajeunir = to rejuvinate (the word for young 'jeun' is in the word)

question: Hold on (when putting someone on hold)
answer: Ne quittez pa ('nuh-key-tay-pa'); literally you (formal) do not leave; the verb is quitter

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Je suis désolé(e).; Add the extra E if you are a woman because it is an adjective that modifies JE.; Alternative: Je regrette.

question: I was wrong.
answer: Je me suis trompé(e)/tort(e).

question: I had the wrong idea (about something).
answer: J'ai l'idée faussée (idée is feminine). OR Je n'ai pas une bonne idée de la question.; faussée is a form of faux = false

question: Well done! / Good job! (when someone succeeds at something)
answer: Bien joué! ('zhoo-ay'); loosely translated: they played it well; Alternative: Bon travaille!

question: It's magnificent. + It's marvelous.
answer: C'est manifique. (There is no G!) + C'est merveilleux. ('mare-vay-yo')

question: idiomatic way to say: I enjoy... e.g. I enjoy swimming.
answer: Je prends du plaisir à + INFINITIVE; e.g. Je prends du plaisir à nager.

question: Was I right/correct?
answer: Est-ce que j'avais bon?; Generally the word good (bon/bonne) is used to mean correct.; Alternatively you can use the adjective exact(e). C'est exact. = That is correct.; Do NOT use 'correct' which technically exists in french but is extremely anglo.

question: You are right/correct.
answer: Tu as raison ('ray-zon').; Avoir raison is the way to express someone being correct.; Technically you could ask: Ai-je raison? = Am I right? This is correct french but a bit formal.

question: reasonable
answer: This depends on what you are describing. 1) a person: If you are describing a person then use raisonnable. e.g. Il est raisonnable.; 2) a thing: Use réalisable (because you can only use raisonnable to describe a person). e.g. Le projet est réalisable.

question: You are reasonable. + The price is reasonable.
answer: Tu es raisonnable. + Le prix est réalisable.; Raisonnable can only describe a person. Réalisable can describe things such as prices and projects.; NB: It is possible to use raisonnable to describe a price but it connotes low cost.

question: There are too many stops. It's not reasonable.
answer: Il y a trop d'arrets. Ce n'est pas réalisable.; Do not use raisonnable because it can only be used to describe a person. Réalisable can describe things.

question: The drivers honk the horn for no reason.
answer: Les automobilistes se mettent à kloxonner sans raison valable.; valable is a good word to use in this case. It is related to the idea of what is reasonable.

question: the correct choice / the correct response
answer: le bon choix / la bonne réponse

question: Can you hear me? (when on a call)
answer: Vous m'entendez? OR Tu m'entends?; Do not use pouvoir. Keep it simple.

question: Are you available? + Is there a job opening available?
answer: As-tu disponible? + Est-ce qu'il y a un poste disponible?; You could also use libre in casual conversation: Je suis libre vendredi.

question: at the same time
answer: en même temps OR à la fois; NB: temps is almost always plural - it always ends with S.

question: in the same place
answer: au même endroit

question: your free time + our time together
answer: ton temps libre + nos temps ensemble

question: I know how to prepare coffee.
answer: Je sais ('shhhhhsay') préparer le café; Use SAVOIR for knowing some information.; JE is pronounced slowly as a long 'shhhh' sound. But you must avoid making it a separate syllable. It's not 'shuh-say'. It's 'shhhhhsay' or 'shay' (very informal).

question: I do not know. (when you don't have the information)
answer: Je ne sais pas.; Pronounced 'shay-pah' in conversation. Abbreviated NSP in writing.

question: I do not know. (when you're not familiar with the person/topic)
answer: Je ne connais pas.; Use CONNAÎTRE for familiarity - not for information.

question: I did not know that.
answer: Je ne LE savais pas.; Use SAVOIR because we are talking about information instead of familiarity. Use the general article LE (meaning it) to reference the information.

question: I know that it is correct. + I know how to do it.
answer: Je sais que c'est correct. + Je sais comment le faire.; Use SAVOIR (does not use direct object) to describe knowing how to do something or to introduce dependent phrase. Use CONNAÎTRE (uses direct object) to describe being familiar with a person or thing. You cannot say: Je connais comment...

question: I know the man. + I know the concept.
answer: Je connais l’homme. + Je connais le concept.; Use SAVOIR (does not use direct object) to describe knowing how to do something or to introduce dependent phrase. Use CONNAÎTRE (uses direct object) to describe being familiar with a person or thing. You cannot say: Je connais comment...

question: to 'do it cold' (e.g. to watch a movie without knowing the plot)
answer: passé du froid

question: I did something illegal without knowing it.
answer: J'ai fait quelque chose d'illégal sans le savoir.; sans le savoir is how you express 'without knowing' (not sans la connaissance).

question: Knowing that she is always late...
answer: Sachant (participe présent) qu'elle est toujours en retard...

question: I understand.; Specify pronunciation.
answer: Je comprends ('shhhhhkohm-pruh' slowly). It is NOT 'shuh-kohm-pruh'.; JE is always pronounced 'shhh' when spoken and it runs directly into the next consonant. It is never its own syllable. But it is also not rushed. The goal is to make the sound correctly - NOT to say it more quickly. The slow shhhh (instead of a quick 'zshuh') will make the speech more fluid and easier to understand by others.

question: I heard/understood incorrectly.
answer: J'ai mal entendu.; Use the adverb MAL and the verb ENTENDRE (to hear).

question: a misunderstanding
answer: un malentendu; J'ai mal entendu. = I heard/understood incorrectly.; NB: malcompréhension does not exist! You can use: une incompréhension = an inability or refusal to understand / to do something justice

question: Do you understand English? (informal/formal)
answer: Comprends-tu anglais? / Comprenez-vous anglais?

question: You speak English well. + I speak french poorly.
answer: Vous parlez BIEN anglais. + Je parle MAL français.; bien = the adverb for good (well); mal = the adverb for bad (poorly)

question: I speak broken French.
answer: Je parle un français limité.; This is the most idiomatic way to say 'broken French'.

question: I did not understand anything.
answer: Je ne comprenais rien.

question: I did not understand much.
answer: Je ne comprenais pas grand chose.; This is the most idiomatic way to express this... using imparfait and pas grand chose (instead of beaucoup)

question: I did not understand everything. + I understood most of the sentences.
answer: Je ne comprenais pas tout. + Je comprenais la plupart DES phrases.; la plupart is like a fraction or percentage so it does not follow the rules of quantities. Use the partitive prepositions (du / de la / des) to agree with the gender/number of the object of the preposition.; NB: In this case the entire subject ('la plupart des phrases') is a plural subject - not singular.

question: I understood a lot.
answer: J'ai très BIEN compri.; Do not use beaucoup in this case.

question: I did not understand. + I did not understand well.
answer: Je n'ai pas compris. + Je n'ai pas BIEN compris.; Adverbs are placed between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé (with PAS).; NB: The subject pronoun JE can be shortened to the sound 'sh' (in front of any verb) and the vowel is dropped completely so you lose an entire syllable. e.g. Je n'ai pas compris. ('shay-pah-cohm-prhee')

question: I do not understand what they say.
answer: Je ne comprends pas ce qu'ils disent.; QUE contracts with any word starting with a vowel.

question: I do not understand them. + I cannot understand them.
answer: Je ne LES comprends pas. + Je ne peux pas LES comprendre.; In the latter there are two verbs POUVOIR + COMPRENDRE. LES (them) relates to comprendre - not pouvoir. So the pronoun LES is placed before comprendre - not before pouvoir.

question: It's still difficult for me (despite...).
answer: Ça reste difficile pour moi.; Translating STILL depends on the context (e.g. the continuation of a time period vs emphasis). In this case 'ça reste' is a good choice even though we are using still for emphasis.; peu à peu... AND au fur et à mesure... can also be used to mean a continuation.

question: I still only understand some sentences.
answer: Je continue de NE PAS comprendre quelques phrases.; Translating STILL depends on the context (e.g. the continuation of a time period vs emphasis). In this case use the verb CONTINUER (to continue). Use DE to link to the additional verb.; To negate an infinitive place both NE and PAS before the infinitive.; peu à peu... AND au fur et à mesure... can also be used to mean a continuation.

question: I still can't hear the difference.
answer: Je n'entends toujours pas la différence.; Translating STILL depends on the context (e.g. the continuation of a time period vs emphasis). In this case TOUJOURS is a good choice instead of adding a second verb.; With only one verb NE and PAS are in their standard places to negate the phrase.; peu à peu... AND au fur et à mesure... can also be used to mean a continuation.

question: My ears are not used to french.
answer: Mes oreilles ne s'habituent pas au français.

question: My oral comprehension is not good.
answer: Mon comprehension oral n'est pas très bonne.; Adding pas to an adjective totally negates it and makes it negative instead of neutral. e.g. pas parfait does not mean 'not perfect' it actually means 'the opposite of perfect' e.g. pas formidable does not mean 'not great' it means 'the opposite of great'.

question: Did you understand the exercise?
answer: Familiar: T'as pige l'exo?; Formal: Tu as comprends l'exercise?; NB: T'as is a contraction of the subject TU and the verb AS. This contraction is really common in conversation but you should not do it in formal communication.

question: I continue to try. + I continue to do something.
answer: Je continue D'essayer. + Je continue À faire quelque chose.

question: I am getting better (at some skill). + I will get better (at some skill).
answer: Je m'améliore. + Je vais m'améliorer.; SE AMÉLIOR = to improve (oneself). We must use the verb reflexively in this case because the object (what is improving) is not explicit.; Alternative: Je deviens (DEVENIR = to become) meilleure.

question: I will improve (speaking french). + I will improve (dancing).
answer: Je vais améliorer mon français. + Je vais améliorer ma danse.; AMÉLIOR = to improve. We do not use the verb reflexively in this case because the object (dancing/speaking) is explicit.

question: to get worse
answer: s'empirer; Use the reflexive version of verbs when we mean say 'get' in English because the subject is also the object.; Alternative: DEVENIR pire (literally: to become worse). This is a very familiar/casual way to express this. You do not need to use a reflexive pronoun with DEVENIR because the verb assumes that the subject is also the object.

question: The crowd is worsening. (formal and informal versions)
answer: Soutenu (formal): La foule s'empire. (SE EMPIRER) + Familiére (informal):La foule devient pire.

question: I get worse. (formal and informal versions)
answer: Soutenu (formal): Je m'empire. (SE EMPIRER) + Familiére (informal): Je deviens pire.

question: It got worse.
answer: Ça s'est empiré (s'empirer).

question: I will get it (eventually understand something).
answer: Je compredrai.; I will understand - using futur simple. This is a good way to express this sentiment.; Remember that the subject pronoun JE can be shorted to sound like 'sh' (in front of any verb) so you lose at least one syllable: Je comprends. ('shcohm-prah').

question: It takes time to understand.
answer: Ça prend du temps pour comprendre.; This is an idiomatic expression in french that is very similar to the expression in english.

question: how quickly the people speak
answer: à quel point les gens parlent vite; à quel point is an idiomatic phrase that emphasizes the frequency or volume of something - how much something (some verb) happens

question: I like X. + I really like X. + I really really like X.
answer: J'aime X. + J'aime bien X. + J'adore X.; All of these phrasings are appropriate at any level of speaking/writing (informal and formal). But generally AIMER (alone) is used for people: Je t'aime. AIMER BIEN and ADORER are used for objects including compound verbs.

question: I like to dance. + I like red wine.
answer: J'aime bien danser. + J'aime bien le vin rouge.; You do not need any preposition after aimer or adorer to join with another verb. e.g. J'adore danser.

question: I don't like rose wine. + I don't like to sing.
answer: Je n'aime pas de vin rosé. + Je n'aime pas chanter.; Negation of the verb AIMER is completely appropriate when you are expressing that you do not like some inanimate object. But if you were trying to express that you do like an inanimate object do not use AIMER alone. Instead use AIMER BIEN or ADORER.

question: I don't like peanut butter.
answer: Je n'aime pas le beurre de cacahouète.

question: I don't like to have too many things in the apartment.
answer: Je N'aime PAS AVOIR trop de choses dans l'appartement.; When you negate a compound verb (one conjugated verb + one infinitive) then you do not add a preposition (like DE) in between the two verbs - PAS is sufficient.

question: I like cocktails a lot.
answer: J'aime BEAUCOUP les cocktails.; This is how you express that you like something a lot.; Beaucoup is modifying the verb in this case (instead of indicating a quantity of the thing that is liked). You are not saying 'I like a lot of cocktails'. So there is no DE between beaucoup and the noun (les cocktails).

question: I like a lot of cocktails.
answer: J'aime BEAUCOUP DE cocktails.; Beaucoup is a quantity in this case (instead of modifying the verb aimer). You are not saying 'I like cocktails a lot.' So you must use BEAUCOUP DE (with the generic preposition).

question: My husband likes to cook a lot.
answer: Mon mari aime BEAUCOUP cuisiner.; In this case beaucoup is an adverb (modifying the verb: cuisiner). So we do not use preposition DE.

question: I like both.
answer: J’aime bien les deux.; Always use an article before a noun (deux). Use AIMER BIEN or ADORER for objects. Use AIMER (alone) for people.

question: I like it.
answer: J'aime bien. This is the best option. Omit the pronoun (for the thing that you like) completely in this case.; You could also say: J'aime ça. But that is not idiomatic french.

question: She likes her. + She likes it (la fromage).; Explain the exception in choosing the object pronoun.
answer: Elle l'aime. + Elle aime bien. OR Elle aime bien ça. (NOT Elle l'aime.) This is a special case where we sometimes omit the object pronoun completely in french. AIMER is intended to be used for people (not objects). So in the first sentence we can replace her with the pronoun LA. In the second sentence the object is an inanimate object so we use ça (or omit it completely) instead of using the COD pronom (la/le).

question: He hates her. + He hates it (la fromage).; Explain the exception in choosing the object pronoun.
answer: Il la deteste. + Il deteste ça. (NOT: Il la deteste.); This is a special case where we sometimes omit the object pronoun completely in french. DETESTER is intended to be used for people (not objects). So in the first sentence we can replace her with the pronoun LA. In the second sentence the object is an inanimate object so we use ça (or omit it completely) instead of using the COD pronom (la/le).

question: I enjoy writing.
answer: Je prends du plaisir à écrire.; The best way to express this sentiment in french is: PRENDRE + DU PLAISIR + À + the desired thing or action; This is an exception to how generally connect two verbs because it uses À instead of DE.

question: I enjoy it.
answer: J'y prends du plaisir.; Use pronom Y to represent the object because PRENDRE DU PLAISIR triggers À before the object when you are not using a pronoun.

question: I really like it when the people around me are having a good time.
answer: J'aime bien / J'adore quand les personnes autour DE moi passent un bon moment.; Use autour DE because all directional prepositions use DE (e.g. à côté DE).; Use MOI (instead of me) because there is a preposition before this pronoun.

question: I really like being surrounded by others (indicating you are a social person).
answer: J'aime bien / J'adore quand des personnes m'entourent. This uses the verb ENTOURER (to surround). Use ME pronoun (instead of MOI) because there is no preposition between ENTOURER and its object.; Less idiomatic alternative: J'adore être entouré(e) PAR des personnes. = I like being surrounded BY people. Preposition PAR (= by way of) explains causation in terms of the manner or the place.

question: I like to learn about a new culture.
answer: J'aime bien connaître une autre culture.

question: to see the world from another culture's perspective
answer: voir les aspects d'un autre culture / d'une autre personne

question: I enjoyed their culture.
answer: J'ai bien aimé leur culture.; Use aimer bien to express enjoyment. If you use profiter de (e.g. Je profite de leur culture...) then you must explain exactly what benefit you receive from experiencing the culture.

question: I like to be immersed in a new culture.
answer: J'aime bien m'immerger dans une nouvelle culture.; Use the verb S'IMMERGER (to immerse oneself).; 'dans une culture' would be a bit vague. It is better to specify what culture you are talking about in this case.; un séjour en immersion = a long stay abroad with the purpose of immersing in a different culture; un séjour linguistique = a stay abroad to improve a foreign language

question: I really like being surrounded by the parisian culture.
answer: J'aime bien être entouré(e) PAR DE la culture parisienne.; NB: Using 'de la culture' (instead of just 'de culture') leaves the expression a bit open in a good way. There is a sense that you might enjoy other cultures too. For example if you said: J'aime bien être entouré(e) PAR la culture parisienne. (without de) ...This connotes that your enjoyment is limited (or more targeted) to this specific culture - not extended to others.

question: the empire that surrounded the world
answer: l'empire qui entourait (imparfait) le monde

question: I want to integrate into a community.
answer: Je voudrais m'intégrer dans une collectivité.; S'INTÉGRER = to integrate or assimilate

question: I know of him. + I know of it (le gorgonzola).; Explain the exception in choosing the object pronoun.
answer: Je LE connais. + Je connais. (NOT Je le connais.); This is a special case where we sometimes omit an object pronoun completely in french. CONNAÎTRE is intended to be used for people (not objects). So in the first sentence we can replace him with the pronoun LE. In the second sentence the object is an inanimate object so we use ça (or omit it completely) instead of using the COD pronom (la/le).

question: Do you like X? (formal and informal)
answer: Aimez-vous X ? / Aimes-tu X ?

question: a formal way to ask: Do you like it? (used by venders when presenting an item).
answer: Ça vous plaît ?

question: The bedroom pleases me. (a common way to express pleasure in french)
answer: La chambre me plaît. PLAIRE is the verb. Add the reflexive pronoun (me) when the person being pleased is implied.; PLAIRE is irregular: je plais + tu plais + il plaît + nous plaisons + vous plaisez + ils plaisent

question: I please my boss.
answer: Je plais À mon chef.;PLAIRE is the verb. It is irregular. Use À when the person being pleased is explicit.

question: Who is your (formal) favorite actor / actress (masculine)?
answer: Quel est votre acteur préféré / actrice préféréE ?

question: Who is your (informal) favorite singer (masculine)?
answer: Quel est TON chanteur préféré / TA chanteuse préféréE ?

question: Who is your (formal) favorite band?
answer: Quel est votre groupe préféré ?; le groupe is masculine

question: Do you have a preferred neighborhood?
answer: Avez-vous une préférence de quartier?

question: I prefer chocolate desserts. + I prefer to read.
answer: Je préfère les desserts au chocolat. + Je préfère lire.; There is no preposition between PRÉFÉRER and a second verb.

question: You adore the band The Donnas.
answer: Tu adores le groupe The Donnas.; use the article and noun - no preposition

question: I adore clothes.
answer: J'adore vêtements.

question: I appreciate jazz and rock.
answer: J'apprécie le jazz et le rock.

question: How do you express 'I appreciate you'?
answer: Do not translate directly. Just say: J'apprécie. (without an object pronoun)

question: I appreciate your point of view.
answer: J'apprécie ton/votre point de vue.

question: I appreciate the meal.
answer: Le repas est trés apprecié.; In this case you must explicitly express the object (the meal). So you cannot use the verb apprécier. Instead use the adjective (apprecié) to describe the meal.; Une repas has an S even when singular.

question: I'm a fan of Wu-Tang.
answer: Je suis fan de Wutang.; use DE preposition before the object

question: I am passionate about hiphop/punk.
answer: Je suis passionné de musique hip hop / de musique punk.; use DE preposition before the object

question: idiomatic way to say: His passion is jazz.
answer: Le jazz le passionne.

question: My musical tastes are quite broad.
answer: Mes goûts musicaux sont plutôt larges.

question: What kind of music do you listen to to relax?
answer: Quel genre de musique écoutes tu pour te détendre?

question: that kind of dance
answer: ce genre de danse; ce genre de... = that kind of...

question: I would like to take that kind of trip again.
answer: Je voudrais refaire ce genre de voyage.

question: idiomatic way to say: I will check it out. (when someone recommends a song/artist); Specify pronunciation.
answer: Je le ('zszszszluh') checkerai ('cheh-khray').; The JE is followed by an L so it's a long 'zszszs' instead of 'shhhhhh'. CH in checkerai is pronounced like an english CH because this is an anglicisme. The last two syllables collapse - drop the E.

question: to sing + to rap
answer: chanter + rapper; RAPPER can be spelled with one or two Ps.

question: the lyrics + the beat (of a song)
answer: les paroles + le beat (many words associated with creative work are taken from English); la parole = the leading monologue; donner la parole à quelqu'un = to hand to conversation over to someone

question: a song + a hymn
answer: une chanson + un hymne ('heeMN' really pronounce both the M and N); un hymne is used more broadly in French than English. A song that is very popular (often political) and sung by many people can be called un hymne.

question: a rythm; Specify pronunciation.
answer: un rythme ('reeTM'); Rythme is pronounced as one syllable. You really hit both the T and the M at the end but you must avoid adding an extra syllable. It is not 'ree-tmuh'.; Rythme is used to mean cadence as well.

question: upbeat + catchy (to describe music)
answer: entretenant + entraînant(e)

question: soulful (to describe music)
answer: plein d'entrain

question: danceable (to describe music)
answer: dansant(e); Dansant(e) is a real and commonly used adjective in french - unlike the english version which sounds forced.

question: live (in real time); e.g. a live broadcast
answer: en (temps) direct OR en temps réel ('ray-elle' NOT 'ray-uhl'); The words change based on context. live (not recorded) = en direct. live music = la musique EN live / au concert.

question: live (not recorded)
answer: en direct; The word changes based on context. live (in real time)  = en temps réel. live music = la musique EN live / au concert.; Direct(e) can also be used to describe a person that is direct in their communication. e.g. Elle est directe.

question: live music
answer: Two options: 1) la musique EN live  2) la musique AU concert; I listen to live music. = J'ecoute DE LA musique EN live / AU concert.; The words change based on context. live (not recorded) = en direct. live (in real time)  = en temps réel.; donner un concert en public = to perform live music for the public

question: to broadcast
answer: diffuser

question: I am a costume-lover.
answer: Je suis amatrice de costumes.; use DE preposition before the object; un costume = a man's suit or a costume (depends on context)

question: I am crazy about...
answer: Je suis fou/folle (m/f) DE danse.; Use DE before the object.

question: leisure/hobbies
answer: les loisirs

question: interests + an interest
answer: les goûts ('goo') is idiomatic french for interests + un intérêt is commonly used to me an interest - like a hobby; NB: If you pronounce the T it is a different word: une goutte (a drop e.g of rain)

question: an area of interest
answer: un centre d'interêt

question: my interest in art
answer: mon intérêt POUR l'art

question: I'm interested in modern art and sculpture.
answer: Je m'intéresse À l'art moderne et à la sculpture ('skool-toor'; do NOT pronounce the P.).; This uses the verb intéresser reflexively. Use à before the object.

question: It interests no one. (a way to say that something is boring)
answer: Ça n'intéresse personne.

question: to have fun
answer: se amuser

question: I have fun watching movies. / It makes me happy to watch movies.
answer: Je m'amuse quand je regarde des films.; Use the reflexive form SE AMUSER to express this.

question: idiomatic way to expresss: for work + for fun
answer: pour le travail + pour le plaisir; Do not forget the articles.

question: Travelling is one of my hobbies.
answer: Voyager fait partie de mes loisirs.

question: interested
answer: intéressé(e); This is a common pattern with adjectives. Elle est intéressée. = She is interested. Elle est intéressant. = She is interesting.

question: interesting
answer: intéressant; This adjective can mean 'interesting' but it often means 'with lots of opportunity' (e.g. un marché immobilier intéressant = an attractive real estate market); This adjective follows the common pattern: Elle est intéressée. = She is interested. Elle est intéressant. = She is interesting.

question: It is interesting that...
answer: C'est intéressant que... ; This triggers the subjonctif mood for the phrase that follows because it is expressing an opinion.

question: He is allergic to shellfish + walnuts + hazelnuts.
answer: Il est allergique (with soft g) AUX crustacés ('cru-sta-sets') + noix ('nua') + noisettes ('nu-ah-zet').

question: She is allergic to pollen.
answer: Elle est allergique AU pollen.

question: What is the difference between these words and how are they pronounced differently: noix + noir
answer: noix = walnut ('nwa' because the X is silent) + noir = black ('nwar' because the R is not silent)

question: Go ahead. (when you are opening the door for someone or letting them go ahead of you)
answer: Vas y. (informal; pronounced 'vah-zee') + Allez y madame/monsieur. (formal; pronounced 'ah-lay-zee')

question: How was it? (informal)
answer: Ça a été? (sa-EH-tay) ...really common and shortened; There is an implied 'bien' in the phrase. The full formal version might be '(Est-ce que) ça a (bien) été ?'

question: It's nice.
answer: C'est sympa.; This comes from the word sypathique which means friendly/pleasant/nice - not sympathetic.

question: It's great. Give at least 3 options.
answer: C'est génial. C'est super. C'est formidable. Incroyable!/Remarquable! C'est magnifique. C'est fabuleux. C'est extraordinaire. C'est top (like the English word).; NB: pas top = not very good

question: It's perfect. + It's cool.
answer: C'est parfait. + C'est chouette ('shweht').; Chouette (same m/f) means brilliant or cool but in a kind way.; You could also say: C'est cool. ...but this is very anglais.; NB: la chouette = owl.

question: It tastes great.
answer: C'est délicieux. ('day-lee-sow')

question: It was good.
answer: C'etait bien.; literally: It went well. This is idiomatic french.; Bien is an adverb (well) that describes a verb. So we do not use bon/bonne/bons/bonnes (the adjective for good) in this case.

question: It was a good day.
answer: C'etait une bonne journée.; We use the feminine journée because we are referring to the things that happened during the day (duration). Do NOT say: C'etait un bon jour. That would imply that there is something special about the day regardless of what happened - like a lucky date.

question: It was a good weekend.
answer: C'était un bon week-end (masculine).; Use bon/bonne/bons/bonnes because good is an adjective that modifies the noun. We do not use bien (well) which would need to modify a verb.

question: It will be X. + It would be X.
answer: Ça sera X. (futur simple) + Ça serait X. (conditionnel présent)

question: It's not bad.
answer: C'est pas mal.; Take care because 'pas mal' can also mean: quite a lot.

question: It's bad.
answer: C'est mauvais. ('say-mow-vay')

question: blah (when you have a negative reaction to something)
answer: bof

question: It's horrible.
answer: C'est horrible. ('se-toe-reebl') OR Quelle horreur!

question: It sucks./Its rubbish.
answer: C'est nul(le).; nul(le) = zero as an adjective

question: disappointed + disappointing
answer: déçu(e) + décevant(e); décevoir = to disappoint or to make depressing

question: I am disappointed.
answer: Je suis déçu.

question: What a disappointment!
answer: Quelle déception!; the disappointment = la déception

question: a deception
answer: une tromperie; NB: déception = disappointment (faux ami)

question: a pet peeve
answer: une bête noire

question: idiomatic way to express: I'm fed up. / Enough is enough.
answer: J'en ai assez.; literally: I have enough of it.

question: idiomatic way to express: I can't get enough (of something).
answer: Je n'en sais jamais assez.; Literally: I can't know enough about it.

question: What is an alternative way to express 'not interesting' (that avoids ennuyant and ennuyeux)?
answer: C'est monotone.

question: the annoyance
answer: l'énervement (masculine); Watch out because énervé(e) means angry - not annoyed.

question: annoying
answer: Depends on context. The best way to express 'it is annoying': C'est chiant(e). This is slightly informal. It connotes that the thing pisses you off / is shitty. It is appropriate for most situations (formal and informal). But if you are in a very formal situation then choose a different expression.

question: She is annoying (like rubbing you the wrong way).
answer: Elle est désagréable.; Use this when the person is speading a bad energy.; Alternative: lourd(e) means heavy but it can also mean annoying when someone is insisting on something a lot.

question: He is annoying (like a pain in the ass).
answer: Il est pénible.; Alternative: lourd(e) means heavy but it can also mean annoying when someone is insisting on something a lot.

question: to bother / to annoy
answer: Three verbs: 1) DÉRANGER (to bother/mess up; the opposite of RANGER = to put things back in order) 2) ÉNERVER = to annoy (the verb). Watch out because énervé(e) (the adjective) means angry - not annoyed. 3) GÊNER (to bother/hinder/trouble). Gêner connotes a physical sensation but it can be used figuratively. 4) S'AGACER 5) PERTURBER

question: That noise annoys me.
answer: Ce bruit m'agace.

question: The cat annoys Ellen. + The cat annoys her.
answer: Le chat agace Ellen. + Le chat l'agace.

question: I am annoyed.
answer: Je m'énerve.; The translation of this adjective is not direct. Options: 1) ne supporter pas: Je ne supporte pas le chien. = The dog really annoys me. 2) S'ÉNERVER; NB: Do not use the adjective énervé(e). That means angry - not annoyed.

question: He is annoyed.
answer: Il s'énerve.; Je m'énerve.; The translation of this adjective is not direct. Options: 1) ne supporter pas: Je ne supporte pas le chien. = The dog really annoys me. 2) S'ÉNERVER; NB: Do not use the adjective énervé(e). That means angry - not annoyed.

question: The sound annoys me.
answer: Le son me gêne.; Use GÊNER (to hinder) reflexively to express this.

question: the boredom
answer: l'ennui

question: It's boring.
answer: C'est ennuyant(e) ('uh-nee-yohn(t)') OR ennuyeux ('uh-nee-yow') / ennuyeuse ('uh-nee-yooz'). Both words mean boring (not annoying).; ENNUYANT(E) is a newer and more commonly-used word than ENNUYEUX/EUSE. And there are some cases where ennuyeux/euse sounds bizarre. So defer to ennuyant(e).; Alternative definitions: ENNUYANT(E) describes something that is temporarily boring/annoying. ENNUYEUX/EUSE describes something that is actively or persistently boring/annoying.

question: Two idiomatic ways to express: It was boring.
answer: 1) neutral: Ça m'a laissé froid. (literally: It left me cold.) 2) very harsh/dismissive: Je me suis fait chier. (literally: I shat myself ...because it was so boring.)

question: It bores me. + It doesn't bore me.
answer: Ça m'ennuie. + Ça ne m'ennuie pas.; ENNUYER is commonly used to describe something that bothers/annoys - even though the translation is closer to 'to bore'.

question: It bored him.
answer: C'était ennuyeux pour lui.

question: to be bored
answer: This is expressed as a verb (instead of an adjective): S'ENNUYER ('suhn-noowee-yay').; Do not use the adjective ennuyé(e). This means to have a problem and you really don't know what to do about it. e.g. Je suis ennuyée. DOES NOT MEAN I am annoyed.

question: I am bored.
answer: Je m'ennuie.; In French we use a verb (S'ENNUYER) to express this instead of an adjective.

question: She is bored.
answer: Elle s'ennuie.; Use a verb (S'ENNUYER) instead of an adjective to express this in French.; S'ENNUYER ('suhn-noowee-yay'). The middle syllable has two vowel sounds but they are squished together and pronounced rapidly almost as a single syllable.

question: When I am bored I read.
answer: Quand je m'ennuie je lire.; Use a verb (S'ENNUYER) instead of an adjective to express being bored or annoyed in French.

question: What do you do when you are bored?
answer: Qu'est-ce que tu fais quand tu t'ennuies?; Use a verb (S'ENNUYER) instead of an adjective to express being bored or annoyed in French.

question: to worry about something
answer: S'INQUIÉTER DE quelque chose (milder) ...or... SE PRÉOCCUPER DE quelque chose (stronger); S'OCCUPER = to be busy with something (not to worry about it)

question: a worry/concern
answer: une inquiétude (milder) OR une préoccupation (stronger) OR un souci (informal); e.g. pas de soucis = no worries / no problem

question: worried / concerned
answer: inquiet(e); The T is only pronounced in the feminine version. This is how you tell the difference between the adjective form and the verb (s'inquiéter) because the T is always pronounced when conjugating the verb.

question: It worries me. + It doesn't worry me.
answer: Ça m'inquiète. + Ça ne m'inquiète pas.

question: Il worries the others.
answer: Il inquiète les autres.; S'INQUIÉTER = to be bothered by (the subject) is the most common way to use this verb. But we can use INQUIÉTER alone = to bother (the object). So when you want to describe an independent subject and object then you do not use the verb reflexively.

question: The boss doesn't care. / It doesn't bother the manager.
answer: Ça ne dérange pas le patron.; DÉRANGER = to bother

question: It bothers me. + It doesn't bother me./I don't mind.
answer: Ça me dérange. + Ça ne me dérange pas.; Use DÉRANGER reflexively to express this.; NB: Ça m'embète. = It's annoying / not cool / bothering me. (more colloquial)

question: He doesn't care about the details.
answer: Il ne se soucie pas des détails.; This uses SE SOUCIER (to worry oneself or bother oneself with something). It's the same base as pas de soucis (no worries / no problem).

question: He doesn't worry about anything.
answer: Il ne s'inquiète de rien.

question: There's nothing specific that bothers me.
answer: Il n'y a pas une chose précise qui me dérange. / ...qui m'inquète.

question: idiomatic way to express: It's really on my nerves.
answer: Ça me prend la tête.; Use this when something has been bothering you for a while. If instead you mean that there is something new that is on your mind: Ça me monte à la tête.

question: idiomatic way to express: It really bothers us.
answer: Ça nous prend la tête.; Use this when something has been bothering you for a while. If instead you mean that there is something new that is on your mind: Ça nous monte à la tête.

question: idiomatic way to express: I will keep it in mind.
answer: Je le ('zszszszluh') garde à l'esprit.; When JE is followed by an L it does not sound like 'shhhh'. Instead it sounds closer to an English J 'zszszszs'. But it is still a long slow sound without forming a separate syllable.

question: idiomatic way to express: It's all in my head.
answer: C'est dans ma tête.

question: It's on my mind.
answer: Ça me monte à la tête.; Alternative: C'est dans mon ésprit.; Do NOT use cerveaux unless you mean the physical brain.

question: to meddle
answer: se mêler

question: the embarrassment
answer: la gêne (from GÊNER = to hinder)

question: embarrassed
answer: embarrassé(e) OR gêné(e)

question: embarrassing
answer: embarrassant; This is a common pattern with adjectives: Il est embarrassé. = He is embarrassed. Il est embarrassant. = He is embarrassing.

question: quiet + muted + silent
answer: calme (also means calm) + muet/muette (m/f) + silencieux/silencieuse (m/f)

question: calm + not calm
answer: calme/tranquille/zen (all same m/f) + inquiet/inquiète (m/f); Alternative for calm: résistant au stress

question: the calm + the serenity
answer: le calme + la sérénité; Alternative for both: la quiétude; serene = serein(e)

question: idiomatic way to express: to keep one's cool (to not get angry)
answer: garder son sang froid

question: to look after someone + to take care of someone
answer: se occuper de quelqu'un + prendre soin de quelqu'un; S'OCCUPER can also be used for 'to deal with'. It's more about management. PRENDRE SOIN is more about care.

question: I deal with the clients.
answer: Je me occupe DES clients.; S'OCCUPER de quelque chose = to be busy with something or to look after something. It is also used for business settings so this is the correct choice for managing clients.

question: I take care of my clothes.
answer: J'ai prends soin DE mes vêtements.; PRENDRE SOIN is a better choice (than S'OCCUPER) for taking care of something. It triggers the preposition DE.

question: to hold a position (in a company)
answer: occuper un poste

question: to be busy with something + to deal with something
answer: être occupée AVEC quelque chose + s’occuper DE quelque chose; S'OCCUPER always triggers DE: S'OCCUPER + DE + Noun or Verb. It can mean to be busy with something + to look after something + to deal with something.

question: We were busy with paperwork (e.g. for immigration)
answer: On était occupé AVEC les documents (or use slang: la paperasse).; Use occupé(e) as an adjective when you mean someone is busy with something. Use the verb S'OCCUPER if instead you mean that someone is dealing with something.

question: She is busy with the requests.
answer: Elle est occupée AVEC des demandes.; Use occupé(e) as an adjective when you mean someone is busy with something. Use the verb S'OCCUPER if instead you mean that someone is dealing with something.

question: We're dealing with the paperwork.
answer: Nous nous occupe DES documents (ou DE LA paperasse).; Use S'OCCUPER to mean 'dealing with'. It always triggers DE: S'OCCUPER + DE + Noun or Verb; S'occuper can mean to be busy with something + to look after something + to deal with something.

question: I'm dealing with filing the paperwork.
answer: Je m'occupe DE classement des documents.; S'OCCUPER always triggers DE: S'OCCUPER + DE + Noun or Verb. It can mean to be busy with something + to look after something + to deal with something.

question: He's dealing with the children. + He's dealing with teaching the children.
answer: Il s'occupe des enfants. + Il s'occupe d'enseigner aux enfants.; S'OCCUPER always triggers DE: S'OCCUPER + DE + Noun or Verb. It can mean to be busy with something + to look after something + to deal with something.

question: idiomatic way to say: I'll bring the wine! / I'll take care of the wine! (when deciding who will bring what to a party)
answer: Je m'occupe d'ammener du vin.; S'OCCUPER + DE + Noun or Verb.; S'occuper can mean to be busy with something + to look after something + to deal with something.

question: idiomatic way to say: I'll take care of it! (to take it off of someone else's plate)
answer: Je m'en occupe.; S'OCCUPER always triggers DE so the pronoun to use is EN. S'occuper can mean to be busy with something + to look after something + to deal with something.

question: I am busy. (Don't bother me.)
answer: Je suis occupé(e).; NB: avoir du pain sur la planche = to have a lot on your plate / a lot to do (idiomatic expression)

question: very busy / fully booked (in a schedule)
answer: chargé(e); Literal translation: Charged. Loaded like a weapon.; a busy schedule = un agenda chargé

question: overwhelmed
answer: accablé(e) OR débordé(e); NB: An alternative expression is être sous l'eau = to be under water

question: hectic
answer: trépidant(e)

question: I changed my mind. + I did not change my mind.
answer: J'ai changé d'avis / d'idée. + Je ne changerai pas d'avis.

question: the anger
answer: la colère

question: angry
answer: en colère OR colèrique OR énervé(e); Watch out because ÉNERVER means 'to annoy'. It does not mean 'to anger'.; EN can be a pronoun or a preposition (as in en colère). EN (as a preposition) indicates the interior of something or a state of mind. e.g. en métro + en ville + en rage

question: to become angry
answer: se mettre en colère

question: to harass + the harassement
answer: harceler + le harcèlement; an harasser = un(e) harceleur / harceleuse

question: to be very bothered (to the point of 'losing it')
answer: décomposé(e); This is a step further than dérangé(e)

question: It tastes good. + It's delicious. + It's appetizing.
answer: C'est bon/bonne. + C'est délicieux/délicieuse. + C'est appétissant(e).

question: It's very tasty/flavorful.
answer: C'est très gouteux.

question: the flavor
answer: la saveur (the specific type of flavor; e.g. strawberry ice cream) OR le goût ('tastiness' in general)

question: We ate well.
answer: Nous avons (très) bien mangé.; Bien is the adverb that modifies the verb manger. Generally the adverb is placed before the verb it modifies. Because bien is an adverb it does not adapt to agree (in number or gender) to the verb it describes - unlike adjectives.

question: I am hungry.
answer: J'ai faim ('fah'; Same pronunciaion as fin. The M is silent.).; la faim = the hunger; It's really important to not pronounce the M in faim. Otherwise it sounds like femme.

question: You are thirsty.
answer: Tu as soif. ('swaf'); NB: This kind of statement is commonly pronounced: T'as soif/peur/etc. In spoken french people often contract the subject TU and the verb AS. But you should not do that in formal communication.

question: to be right / They are right.
answer: avoir raison / Ils ont raison.

question: to be wrong / We are wrong.
answer: avoir tort / Nous avons tort.

question: to make mistakes
answer: faire des fautes

question: a mistake + a typo / an error
answer: une faute + une erreur

question: A familiar term used to describe something wrong with a computerized device.
answer: un bug; This is a familiar term that means something like 'on the fritz' - when sometimes it works and sometimes it does not. This term in French is not used in the same way that 'bug' is used in English for software development.

question: idiomatic way to say: It's my fault.
answer: C'est ma faute. OR C'est de ma faute.; The latter is very common but both are correct.

question: hopefully...
answer: aven un peu de chance

question: The chances are good that...
answer: Il y a de bonne chance que...; Do not try to say something like: Mes chances sont éléves. That is not idiomatic french.

question: to take a chance + I will take my chance at skiing.
answer: tenter ma/ta/sa chance + Je tenterai ma chance POUR faire du ski.; TENTER means something like try/test/attempt.

question: Good luck!
answer: Two options: 1) Bon Courage! is generally used to encourage someone when the activity is physical and they have some control over the situation. 2) Bonne chance! is used more for intellectual activities and when the outcome is generally dependent on luck.

question: lucky + unlucky (m/f)
answer: chanceux / chanceuse + malchanceux / malchanceuse

question: to have good luck + She has good luck.
answer: avoir DE LA chance + Elle a DE LA chance.

question: You have a lot of luck. (two ways)
answer: Tu as beaucoup DE chance. + Tu as bien DE LA chance.; In the first case you saying the person literally has (AVOIR) a quantity of something (beaucoup DE chance with generic DE). In the second phrase you are using the verb 'avoir DE LA chance' (to have luck - not a quantity) and adding BIEN to modify the verb.

question: to have bad luck
answer: avoir la malchance; Alternatives: avoir le malheur OR avoir la maladresse; Do not use: avoir pas de la chance (the opposite of good luck). This is not idiomatic.

question: to bring good luck (like a lucky charm)
answer: apporter la chance / bonheur

question: to protect against bad luck + to bring bad luck (like superstitions)
answer: protoger la chance + porter malheur

question: fingers crossed
answer: croisons les doigts

question: by chance / randomly
answer: au hasard ('oh-ehs-ah'; almost like O.S.A. but the A at the end is soft)

question: a random choice
answer: un choix aléatoire; NB: aléatoire can only be used to connote mathematical randomness. For example you cannot say des choses aléatoire to mean 'some things'.

question: idiomatic way to express random stuff that doesn't really matter
answer: tout et n'importe quoi

question: on average
answer: en moyenne; la moyenne = an average; NB: The masculine form (le moyen) means something different - more like a way or a means of doing something

question: an average-sized room
answer: une pièce moyenne

question: a range (of numbers) + a range (e.g. of products)
answer: une fourchette (literally: a fork) OR un écart + une gamme

question: a gap (literal or figurative)
answer: un écart OR un fossé; Use fossé to describe an age gap / the difference in age between two people.; NB: une fosse = a physical pit in the ground

question: Why?
answer: Pourquoi? ('poor-kwa')

question: What is the difference between Pour quoi? and Pourquoi?
answer: Pour quoi? translates to What for? - respond with POUR + INFINITIVE = in order to X.; Pourquoi? translates to Why? - responde with PARCE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB.

question: because
answer: Many options: 1) parce que ('par-se-kuh')   2) car   3) en effet    4) puisque ('pwee-squh' actually 2 syllables) Use when the reason is fairly obvious/evident. It is preferred for exams.; Use parce que (instead of à cause de or grâce à) for most scenarios and especially when you follow with a phrase. e.g. Because I went to the store... = Parce que je suis allé(e) au magasin...; NB: Comme can be used to mean 'because'. e.g. Comme il fait beau... = Because the weather is nice...

question: So... / Therefore... (conversational bridge hinting at causation)
answer: Many options: 1) ainsi... This must be placed at the beginning of the phrase. It is slightly formal. It is preferred (in comparison to donc / alors) for exams - oral and written. 2) alors... 3) donc... ('donk') Can be placed in multiple places. Watch out because DONK means fuck or damn. 4) du coup ('dewww-koo') This is very familiar and mean 'as a result'. This is a great word to understand the difference between french U sound (the first syllable - low in the mouth - lips in tight O shape) and OU sound (the second syllable - higher in the mouth - like english 'oo'). 5) C'est pour ça que... 6) si bien que... 7) de sorte que... 8) à tel point que... 9) C'est pourqoui... 10) par/en conséquence... is a little formal.

question: Because of X...
answer: Generally use one of two expressions depending on the context. 1) À cause de + noun: used when the consequence is negative. 2) Grâce à + noun: (literally 'thanks to...') used when the consequence is positive. 3) A more casual approach: par rapport à (e.g. I said it because of your face. = Je disais ça par rapport à ton visage.); NB: Use à cause DES + plural noun. Use grâce AUX + plural noun.; Alternative: Par consequent... This is a better way to start a sentence (as opposed to Parce que...).

question: with negative connotation: Because of technology... + Because of cars...
answer: À cause DE LA technologie... + À cause DES voitures...; Use DE for singular nouns and DES for plural nouns.

question: with positive connotation: Thanks to technology... + Thanks to donations...
answer: Grâce À LA technologie... + Grâce AUX dons....; Use À for singular nouns. Use AUX for plural nouns.

question: due to...
answer: due à...; e.g. La perte est DUE À la maladie. = The loss is due to disease.; Alternative: C'est dû à quoi? = What is this due to?

question: idiomatic way to say: That's why...
answer: C'est pour ça...; e.g. That's why I was late. = C'est pour ça j'étais en retard.

question: Based on...
answer: en fonction de...

question: Due to circumstances...
answer: En raison des circonstances... OR Les choses étant ce qu'elles sont...

question: Given that... (expresses causation)
answer: Étant donné que...

question: Given that most of the students had not studied` the professor delayed the test.
answer: Etant donné que (= give that...) la plupart des élèves n'avaient pas étudié (plus que parfait)` le professeur a retardé l'examen.

question: Claiming that... (expresses causation where the cause is contested)
answer: Sous prétexte que... (literally: Under the pretext that...); This expresses a cause but the cause is contested.

question: She arrived late claiming that there was lots of traffic.
answer: Elle est arrivée en retard sous prétexte qu'il y avait beaucoup de circulation.; Sous prétexte que... = Claiming that... / Under the pretext that... It expresses a cause that is contested.

question: Lacking X... (expresses causation)
answer: Faute de X...

question: Lacking supplies` the project was delayed.
answer: Faute de fournitures`le projet a été retardé (la voix passive because the project was delayed BY someone).; Faute de X... = Lacking X...

question: This artist is known for their incredible concerts.
answer: Cet artiste est connu pour ses concerts incroyables.; This is a way to show causation with POUR + NOM.

question: They were imprisoned for steeling a necklace.
answer: Ils ont été emprisonnés pour avoir volé (infinitif passé) un collier.; This is a way to show caustion with POUR + INFINITIF (infinitif passé in this case because the cause - the theft - already happened).; When you use a verb + ing in english (e.g. swimming + having) it often translates to infinitif passé in french.

question: for example
answer: par exemple ('par-ex-ompl') OR notemment; Par exemple is abbreviated as ex: (not e.g.). Notemment is more idiomatic and can also be translated as 'including...'.; Preposition PAR (= by way of) explains causation in terms of the manner or the place. POUR expains causation in terms of goals.

question: a written example
answer: un exemple écrit / un modèle écrit; Exemple is also the correct word when you describe a sample problem.

question: an extract (of a text)
answer: un extrait; Alternative: une partie d'un texte (masculine)

question: also
answer: aussi ('oh-si')

question: additionally...
answer: Many option: en supplémentaire + DE plus (not 'en plus') + additionnellement + outre ('ootr' which can also mean 'across from') + ...; NB: People say 'en plus' to mean 'additionally...' but this is not correct french. The correct expression is 'de plus' which can be used in writing and speaking.

question: In addition to the things that you just mentioned...
answer: En plus des choses que tu as expliqué...

question: more and more...
answer: de plus en plus...

question: idiomatic way to express: last but not least...
answer: enfin et surtout...

question: like this
answer: comme ça

question: idiomatic way to express: ...` isn't it? ...` aren't you?
answer: ...` n'est ce pas ('neh-spah')

question: How do you ask: Is it X?
answer: Est-ce X? ('ehsss'); Remember that Est-ce (Is it?) is the inverse of C'est (It is.) So... It is difficult. = C'est difficile. Is it difficult? = Est-ce difficile?.; You construct the simple question by replacing C'est with Est-ce.

question: How do you ask: Was it X?
answer: Est-ce que c'était X?; It is possible to ask this with simple inversion: Était-ce X? (akin to Est-ce X? au présent) but this is very bizarre in French. Do not use it. If you need to ask the question with the past tense (Was it x?) then use the common form with Est-ce que + the affirmative form of what you want to ask.

question: How do you ask: Is that X?
answer: Est-ce que c'est X?; Literally: Is it that it is X?; e.g. Is that bizarre? = Est-ce que c'est bizarre?

question: What is this and how do you pronounce it?: Est-ce que...?
answer: This is a super common and informal way to begin a yes/no question.; The whole thing is pronounced 'ehssss-kuh' - the s sound is long at the beginning.; Est-ce que... indicates the beginning of a yes/no question - it is not asking 'how' or 'what'.; A potential translation of est-ce que: Is it that which...?; NB: The subject and verb NEVER reverse if you use Est-ce to ask the question (Est-ce + subject + verb); If you want to speak more formal french then use the reversal of subject and verb (plus upward intonation) to pose a question (instead of using Est-ce que...?).

question: How do you ask: What is ...?
answer: Generally: Qu'est-ce que ...? ('kes-kuh'); This is always followed by subject + verb. Do not invert the order when forming the question.; NB: Do not always use QUE to translation 'what'. In french it matters whether you are asking for a subject that is doing the action (use QUE) or a direct object with a preposition (use QUOI).

question: What is this and how do you pronounce it?: Qu'est-ce que...?
answer: The whole thing is pronounced 'kes-kuh'. It is a contraction of QUE + EST-CE QUE.; This is generally how you ask: What is...? The response is NOT yes/no. You are asking for a noun.; NB: In french it matters whether you are asking for a subject (QUE) or a direct object (QUOI).

question: What did I say?
answer: Qu'est-ce que j'ai dit?

question: Did I answer your question?
answer: Est-ce que ma réponse répond à ta question?; Alternatives: Est-ce que j'ai répondu à ta question? or Est-ce que ça répond à ta question?

question: What are we eating? We are eating X.
answer: Qu'est-ce qu'on mange. On mange DU X.; NB: 'Que' and 'on' merge together using apostrophe ('kohn'). And always use DU when prefacing something being eaten.

question: What do you study? (formal and informal)
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous étudiez / tu étudie?; tu étudie is pronounced 'too-uh-tood' ...present singular verb forms are usually short with downward intonation

question: What are you doing this evening? (formal and informal)
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous faites / tu fais su soir?

question: How do you ask: Which is ...?
answer: Quel est...? ('kel-ay-...') but it adapts to the gender and number of what you are asking about so there are four possbilities: Quel? (masc sing) Quelle? (fem sing) Quels? (masc plural) Quelles? (fem plural); All four forms are pronounced exactly the same: 'kel'.

question: What is your (informal) profession?
answer: Quelle est ta profession?; Use QUELLE because profession is feminine and singular.

question: What kind/type is it? (e.g. type of car or dance or music)
answer: Quel genre est-il? ('kel-jon-ray-til'); Use QUEL because genre is masculine and singular.

question: What type of jackets do you have?
answer: Quel genre de veste avez-vous? OR Vous avez quel genre de veste?; If you use Quel then you have to invert the subject verb; OR you can make a statement (subject + verb) and use intonation to make it a question

question: of this type
answer: tel... This is an adjective with the following forms: tel/telle/tels/telles

question: an outfit of this type
answer: un telle tenue; Tel is an adjective that adapts to the noun it modifies: tel/telle/tels/telles.

question: What color is the dress?
answer: DE quelle couleur est la robe?; Use DE QUEL instead of QUEL because we use a preposition in english: What is the color OF the dress? The presence of the preposition in english indicates that we need to use DE QUEL... in French.

question: What colors are you (formal) wearing?
answer: DE quelles couleurs vous portez?; Use QUELLES because couleures is plural and feminine.; couleur is pronounced 'kool-oor' like heurre

question: Who is ...? / Who is it?
answer: Qui est ...? ('kee-ah-...')/ Qu'est-ce? ('kes'); It doesn't matter whether the 'who' is the subject or direct object of the verb. Always use QUI.

question: Whose is ...?
answer: À qui est ce sac?; To change from 'who' to 'whose' just add the preposition à.

question: How is...?
answer: Comment ...? ('como')

question: Where is ...? / Where is it?
answer: Où est ...? ('ooh-ay-...') / Où est-il? ('ooh-ay-eel')

question: What is the difference between où and ou?
answer: OÙ (with accent) means where when you are asking a question or using a pronoun.; OU (without accent) means or (when there is a choice between two things).; Both words sound the same ('oo').

question: When is ...? / When is it?
answer: Quand est ...? ('kon-ah-...')/ Quand est-ce? ('kon-tes'); NB: quand is a general word for 'when' whether you are making a question or a statement. lorsque is a slightly more formal word that you can use instead of quand.

question: When do you (informal / formal)...?
answer: Quand est-ce que tu/vous...?; NB: Quand ends in consonant sound (D) and est-ce begins with vowel sound (E) so you must link the words when speaking ('koh-Des-kuh'...)

question: When will you go there?
answer: Quand est-ce que tu vas y aller ?; Structure interrogative word (quand) + (qu')est-ce que + subject + verb. Do not use inversion when you need an interrogative word.

question: When will you leave (for the trip)?
answer: Quand est-ce que tu vas partir ?; Structure interrogative word (quand) + (qu')est-ce que + subject + verb. Do not use inversion when you need an interrogative word.

question: How many times per week / per month?
answer: Combien de fois par semaine / par mois?; NB: Do not answer this question with 'beaucoup de fois' because it is not idiomatic. Use plusieurs fois or souvent instead.

question: How often?
answer: À quelle frequence?; Alternatives: Tout les combien de temps ...? Quand ...?

question: I go to the cinema a few times per month
answer: Je vais plusiers fois par mois au cinema.; Take care on the order: adverb of frequency + actual frequency + object; Use 'plusieurs fois' instead of 'quelques fois' because the latter is not idiomatic.

question: There were a few times when I...
answer: Il y avait plusiers fois OÙ je...; Use OÙ (instead of quand) when speaking about a location or a point in time.

question: How many years?
answer: Combien D'années?; Use combien for how many and how much. Use combien + generic DE because you are asking about a quantity of something. Use années instead of ans because the quantity is indefinite/inexact.

question: How many people will live in this house?
answer: Combien de personnes vont vivre (futur proche) dans cette maison?

question: What are the three levels of speaking/writing in French? How are questions formed at each level?
answer: 1) soutenu: formal e.g. Use inversion to form a question.  2) passe partout (aka courant): can be used anywhere in both formal and informal situations. e.g. Use Est-ce que... to form a question. No inversion.  3) familiére: informal. Only use with close friends. e.g. Use quoi to form a question. No inversion.

question: What are three ways to ask a closed (yes/no) question?
answer: 1) soutenu (formal with inversion): VERB + DASH + SUBJECT ? (e.g. Vas-tu? = Are you going?); Often uses a dash between verb and subject with added T for pronunciation as needed.; 2) Passe partout (aka interrogative/courante): EST-CE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB? Remember that a noun ALWAYS follow EST-CE QUE. No inversion of subject/verb when using est-ce que! (e.g. Est-ce que tu vas? = Are you going?); 3) Familiére (aka affirmative): SUBJECT + VERB?  You must use intonation to make it sound like a question. Only use this structure with friends in very casual situations.

question: What are three ways to ask an open (not a yes/no question)?
answer: It is the same three options as closed questions. To make the question open we add an interrogative word (que + quand + où + pourquoi + comment...). Add it at the beginning of the closed soutenue and passe partout formats. Add it at the end of the familiére format.; 1) Soutenue: MOT INTERROGATIVF + VERB + DASH + SUBJECT ? e.g. Où vas-tu? = Where are you going? 2) Passe Partout: MOT INTERROGTIF + EST-CE QUE (not qu'est-ce que) + SUBJECT + VERB? e.g. Où est-ce que tu vas? = Where are you going?; 3) Familiére: SUBJECT + VERB + MOT INTERROGATIF? e.g. Tu vas où? = You go where?

question: How many times have you listened to it? Ask in two ways: soutenu + passe partout.
answer: Soutenue: Combien de fois l'as-tu écouté ?; Passe partout: Combien de fois est-ce que tu l'as écouté ?; When you need a specific interrogative word (e.g. comment + quand + où) simply add it to the beginning of the soutenue (inversion) and passe partout (est-ce que - not qu'est-ce que) formats.

question: How did you get home?
answer: Comment (est-ce que) tu es rentré(e) ?; To use an interrogative word (e.g. comment + quand + où) in a question simply add it to the beginning of the soutenue (inversion) and passe partout (est-ce que - not qu'est-ce que) formats.; You can see that 'est-ce que' actually becomes optional. If you omit it you have the familiar form (using intonation).

question: How do you know whether to use QUE or QUOI when asking 'what' in a question?
answer: In french it matters whether you are asking for a subject (use QUE) or an object (use QUOI). Often qoui is preceded by a preposition either because the verb requires it or because the object is part of a prepositional phrase.; An example with QUE: What is the thing on the table? = QU'est-ce que la chose sur la table ? 'What' is the subject that is doing the action (being on the table).; An example with QUOI: You found what? = Tu as trouvé quoi ? 'Tu' is the subject. 'What' is the object.; Ultimately it depends on how you structure the question. e.g. passe partout (Qu'est-ce...) or familiére (subject + verb + object ...using intonation).

question: What would you say? Ask this in three ways: soutenue + passe partout + familiére.
answer: 1) soutenu (inversion): Que dirais-tu? QUE = what when using inversion to ask a question. 2) passe partout (qu'est-ce que): Qu'est-ce que tu dirais? 3) familiére (quoi): Tu dirais quoi?

question: What is it? Ask this in three ways: soutenu + passe partout + familiére.
answer: 1) soutenu: Qu'est-ce? (rarely heard); 2) passe partout: Qu'est-ce que c'est? ('kes-kuh-say') literally means: What it is? Use QUE (instead of quoi) becuase the 'what' represents a subject (not the object).; 3) Familiére: C'est quoi? Literally: It is what? 'What' is the object and être does not require a preposition so use QUOI.

question: What is it like? (when you are asking someone to describe a location etc.)
answer: DE QUOI ça a l'air?; Literally: 'Of what' is it like? Use DE QUOI because the 'what' is an object (not the subject) and the verb (avoir l'air de...) requires a preposition.

question: What is it about? (like when you see someone with a book and you are curious what it is about) Ask this in three ways: soutenu + passe partout + familiére.
answer: 1) soutenu: De quoi s'agit-il? This is rarely used. DE QUOI because the 'what' is an object and S'AGIR requires DE.; 2) passe partout: Qu'est-ce que ça raconte?; 3) familiére: Ça raconte quoi? QUOI without preposition because the 'what' is a direct object of the verb.

question: Do you (formal) know of / are you familiar with X?; Ask this in two ways: soutenu + passe partout.
answer: 1) soutenu (inversion): Connaissez-vous X? 2) passe partout (interrogative; est-ce without inversion): Est-ce vous connaissez X?

question: What are you doing? Ask this in three ways: soutenu + passe partout + familiére.
answer: 1) soutenu: Que fais tu?; 2) passe partout: Qu'est-ce que tu fais?; 3) familiére: Tu fais quoi?

question: What did you do last week?; Ask this in two ways: passe partout + familiére.
answer: 1) passe partout: Qu'est-ce que tu as fait la semaine dernière?; 2) familiére: Tu as fait QUOI la semaine dernière?; NB: dernier/dernière (m/f): When placed before the noun it means the last in a series but when placed after the noun it means the previous one.

question: What did you do last month?; Ask this using an extra pronom tonique for emphasis
answer: Qu'est-ce que tu as fait le mois dernière` toi?; In French we place elements on relief (mettre en relief) to emphasize them. Use pronoms tonique to emphasize a person in this way. We want to emphasize TU. So use the pronom tonique TOI.

question: I don't know what to do.
answer: Je ne sais pas quoi faire.; Use QUOI (instead of que) because the 'what' is an object (not the subject). There is no preposition before quoi because the verb (savoir) does not require a preposition.

question: I didn't know what to do. vs I didn't know what I had to do.
answer: Je ne savais pas QUOI faire. vs Je ne savais pas CE QUE je devais faire.; In the first phrase 'what' is a direct object of the verb so we use QUOI. In the second phrase the 'what' is actually a subordinate clause so we need a conjunction like CE QUE to represent an antecedent ('what') that is totally absent / undefined.

question: I know something. + You know what?
answer: Je sais quelque chose (direct object). + Tu sais QUOI (direct object) ?; Use QUOI (instead of que) when asking the question because the 'what' is an object (not the subject) in this format. We do not need À or DE before quoi because the verb SAVOIR does not require either for this meaning.

question: I think the worst. + You think what?
answer: Je pense AU pire (à + indirect object). + Tu penses À QUOI (à + indirect object) ?; Use QUOI (instead of que) when asking the question because the 'what' is an object (not the subject) in this format. We need the preposition À because the verb PENSER requires it for this meaning.

question: I fear the bear. + You fear what?
answer: J'ai peur DE l'ours (de + indirect object). + Tu as peur DE QUOI (de + indirect object) ?; Use QUOI (instead of que) when asking the question because the 'what' is an object (not the subject) in this format. We need the preposition DE because the verb (AVOIR PEUR DE...) requires it.

question: What are you thinking about?
answer: Vous pensez à quoi? or À quoi pensez vous?; Literally: Of what are you thinking? 'You' is the subject. 'What' is the object.; Use À (instead of DE) because PENSER À means to think about something / to have it on the mind. (PENSER DE means to have an opinion about something.); Use À QUOI (instead of ce que) because the object (what) can stand on its own.

question: What do you think of it? (e.g. after you have spoken and you are asking for someone's opinion)
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous EN pensez? OR Qu'est-ce que tu EN penses?; Use pronom EN because we mean PENSER DE (to have an opinion about something) - instead of PENSER À (to think about something / to have it on the mind).

question: Do you think the same?
answer: Penses-tu la même chose? / Est-ce que tu penses la même chose?; Alternative: Est-ce que tu LE penses aussi?

question: What's up?
answer: Quoi de neuf?; Literally: 'Of what' is new? Use DE QUOI because the 'what' is an object (not the subject) and requires a preposition.; Neuf means 'new' in some circumstances.

question: What else?
answer: Quoi d'autres? ('qwa-doh-truh'); LIterally: 'Of what' else? Use DE QUOI because the 'what' is an object (not the subject) and requires a preposition.

question: What do you need?
answer: De quoi as tu besoin?; Literally: 'Of what' do you have need? Use DE QUOI because the 'what' is an object (not the subject) and requires a preposition.

question: What do you do for fun?
answer: Qu'est-ce que tu fais pour t'amuser? OR Qu'est-ce que tu fais pour le plaisir?;Use S'AMUSER.

question: What makes you feel good?
answer: Qu'est-ce qui fait que tu te sens bien?; Use QUI instead of que because there is no explicit subject.

question: What is it that interests you?
answer: Qu'est-ce qui t'intéresses?; Use QUI instead of que because there is no explicit subject.

question: What is it that interests you about X?
answer: Qu'est-ce qui t'intéresses DANS X?; NB: ce qui is pronounced 'ski' in conversation.

question: Is the water blue? + I know if (whether or not) the water is blue.
answer: L'eau est-elle bleue ? + Je sais SI l'eau est bleue.; When asking a yes/no question we use EST-CE QUE. To change a closed question into a statement: est-ce que becomes SI.

question: What is in the water? + I know what is in the water.
answer: Qu'est-ce qu'il y a dans l'eau ? + Je sais ce qu'il y a dans l'eau.; When asking an open (not a yes/no) question we use QU'EST-CE QUE. To change an open question into a statment: qu'est-ce que becomes CE QUE.

question: Is it the rainy season?; Ask this in two ways: soutenu + passe partout.
answer: 1) soutenu (inversion): EST-CE la saison des pluies?; 2) passe partout (interrogative; est-ce without inversion): EST-CE QUE c'est la saison des pluies?

question: Your name is Marc. + Is your name Marc? (using soutenu/inversion)
answer: Tu t'appelles Marc. + T'appelles-tu Marc?; When using inversion with a reflexive verb the reflexive pronoun is placed before all verbs.

question: Why do you wake up early? (using soutenu/inversion)
answer: Pourquoi TE réveilles-tu tôt?; When using inversion with a reflexive verb the reflexive pronoun is placed before all verbs.

question: How do you use a proper noun (instead of a pronoun) when asking a question using the soutenu/formal form? e.g. Is Patrick Irish?
answer: Patrick est-il irlandais?; To use the soutenu form when the subject is not a pronoun you must repeat the subject as a pronoun for the inversion: SUBJECT NOUN + VERB + DASH + SUBJECT PRONOUN.

question: Use the soutenu (inversion) form to ask: Is she french? + Is Sarah french?
answer: Est-elle française? (simple inversion when subject is a pronoun) + Sarah est-elle française? (insert pronoun to enable inversion and place the proper noun at the beginning of the question)

question: Use the soutenu (inversion) form to ask: Is he orange? + Is the cat orange?
answer: Est-il orange? (simple inversion when subject is a pronoun) + Le chat est-il orange? (insert pronoun to enable inversion and place the proper noun at the beginning of the question)

question: What is a euphonic T? When do you use it?
answer: euphonic T = a T that is inserted between words to aid in pronunciation. The major use case is asking a question using inversion (soutenu). If the verb ends in a vowel then you insert the T so that the pronoun subject is easier to pronounce. e.g. Does he have a dog? = A-t-il un chien? because we cannot write A-il.

question: Do we need a cat? Use inversion/soutenu to ask the question. Use on (instead of nous).
answer: A-t-on besoin d'un chat?; Explanation: We need a cat. = On a besoin d'un chat. Using inversion: A-on besoin d'un chat. But we cannot hyphenate two vowels together. So we add the euphonic T to aid in pronunciation: A-t-on; This happens when we use inversion to ask a question and the conjugated verb ends in a vowel (which is often the case in passé composé).

question: Does she speak german? Use inversion/soutenu to ask the question.
answer: Parle-t-elle allemand?; Explanation: She speaks German. = Elle parle allemand. Using inversion: Parle-elle allemand. But we cannot hyphenate two vowels together. So we add the euphonic T to aid in pronunciation: Parle-t-elle; This happens when we use inversion to ask a question and the conjugated verb ends in a vowel (which is often the case in passé composé).

question: Did he eat the bird? Use inversion/soutenu to ask the question.
answer: A-t-il mangé l'oiseau?; Explanation: He ate the bird. = Il a mangé l'oiseau. Using inversion: A-il mangé l'oiseau. But we cannot hyphenate two vowels together. So we add the euphonic T to aid in pronunciation: A-t-il; This happens when we use inversion to ask a question and the conjugated verb ends in a vowel (which is often the case in passé composé).

question: Did the tiger eat the bird? Use inversion/soutenu to ask the question.
answer: Le tigre a-t-il mangé l'oiseau?; The tiger ate the bird. = Le tigre a mangé l'oiseau. Using inversion: Le tigre a-il mangé l'oiseau. But we cannot hyphenate two vowels together. So we add the euphonic T to aid in pronunciation: Le tigre a-t-il; This happens when we use inversion to ask a question and the conjugated verb ends in a vowel (which is often the case in passé composé).

question: You (formal) watched the movie. + Did you watch the movie? (using soutenu/inversion)
answer: Vous avez regardé le film. + Avez-vous regardé le film?; When using inversion and the verb is passé composé you hyphenate with the auxiliary (not the past participle).

question: Is the chicken good? Ask this using passe partout form.
answer: Est-ce qu'il est bon le poulet?; NB: The QUE and subject IL get pushed together with apostrophe to avoid two vowels together. qu'il ('keel') is pronounced as a single syllable. Always ignore an apostrophe for pronunciation.

question: Specify pronunciation of: Quand est-ce que tu vas? + Quand es tu libre? Explain the difference.
