answer: DE l'autre côté; Make sure to pronounce the E with accent ('koh-tay') because 'koht' is a totally different word: la côte = the coast.

question: the coast + the Amalfi coast; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: la côte (OR la litoral) + la côte Amalfitaine; This is only one syllable 'kohT'. The E is silent. This is important because 'koh-tay' is a totally different word: à côté de = next to

question: on the west coast (of America)
answer: sur la côte ouest américaine

question: the rib + the ribs
answer: la côte + les côtes; NB: This is the same word for coast.

question: on the right + on the left
answer: à droite + à gauche; Do not say à LA gauche or à LA droite. Do not use the article.

question: to the right of...
answer: à droite DE...; e.g. à droite DU musée = to the right of the museum; Do not say à LA gauche or à LA droite. Do not use the article.

question: to the left of...
answer: à gauche DE...; e.g. à gauche de la banque = to the left of the bank; Do not say à LA gauche or à LA droite. Do not use the article.

question: straight ahead
answer: tout droit; NB: This is a fixed french expression that uses TOUT regardless of the number/gender of what it refers to.

question: the center of London + in the middle/center of the country
answer: le centre DE Londres + dans le centre DU pays ('pay-ee')

question: I live close to the center of the city.
answer: J'habite près DU centre ville

question: idiomatic way to express: right in the middle (e.g. of town)
answer: en plein centre ville + en plein milieu; Neither of these expressions (in this form) use a preposition.; You could use these to describe specific cities (but not countries) with a preposition. e.g. en plein centre DE Napoli

question: idiomatic way to express: right in the middle of Paris
answer: en plein centre DE Paris

question: the city-center + the city center of Barcelona
answer: au centre ville (no preposition) + au centre de Barcelone; There is no à or article in front of the city in this case.

question: the north + the south + the east + the south; Specify the gender and pronunciation of each.
answer: le nord (masc; D is silent) + le sud (masc; D is pronounced) + l'est (fem; T is pronounced) + l'ouest (fem; T is pronounced)

question: the north + It is one hour north of X.
answer: C'est à une heure AU nord de X.; nord is masculine (à + le = au)

question: the south + It is one hour south of X.
answer: C'est à une heure AU sud de X.; sud is masculine (à + le = au)

question: the east + It is one hour east of X.
answer: C'est à une heure À l'est de X.; est is feminine (à + la does not contract)

question: the west + It is one hour west of X.
answer: C'est à une heure À l'ouest de X.; ouest is feminine (à + la does not contract)

question: It is located in the north/south/east/west of the country.
answer: Il est situé au nord/sud/est/ouest du pays.

question: It is located in the east / in the west (of a region).
answer: C'est situe à l'est / à l'ouest.

question: in the northeast of the city; Specify pronunciation.
answer: au nord-est ('nor-ehsT') de la ville; AU because nord is masculine (à + le = au); The D on nord is always silent even when vowel followsl. The T in est is always pronounced.

question: on the north/south/east/west side of the room
answer: sur le côté nord/sud/est/ouest de la pièce

question: toward
answer: Depends on context: 1) vers = in the physical direction of X  2) envers = an attitude or behavior toward X; vers can also mean 'around' in the context of time and dates. e.g. vers 16h = around 4pm

question: through
answer: It depends on context.; 1) PAR (= by way of) is less aggresive. e.g. Je regarde PAR la fenêtre. = I look through the window. Je passe PAR le quartier. = I pass by the neighborhood. 2) À TRAVERS is more aggressive with emphasis on crossing or literally going through one thing in order to get to another thing. e.g. I throw the ball through the window. = Je lance la balle à travers la fenêtre.; TRAVERSER generally means to cross through something but it can mean to travel across (e.g. to cross a river on a ferry or to cross the road on foot).

question: to go by (something) + to go through (something)
answer: PASSER + PAR + noun (e.g. Je passe par le quartier. = I pass by the neighborhood.) + TRAVERSER + noun (e.g. Je traverse le quartier en voiture. = I drove through the neighborhood.); NB: When you use TRAVERSER you are emphasizing the action of crossing something / going through it (e.g. to cross the road). The focus is on the destination.; CROISSER = to run into someone unexpectedly

question: I'm on the way!
answer: Je suis sur le chemin.

question: The ferry crosses the bay.
answer: Le bateau navette traverse la baie.; TRAVERSER generally means to cross through something but it can mean to travel across (e.g. to cross the road). The emphasis is on the destination.; CROISSER = to run into someone unexpectedly

question: here + around here + over there
answer: ici ('ee-see') + là + là-bas; NB: là can be used to mean 'at that moment'. e.g. C'était là que... This can mean It was there that... OR It was at that time that...

question: surrounding / around
answer: autour DE; If you mean instead that you walked 'around' a city (meaning through it) then use DANS instead.

question: to surround
answer: entourer; Make sure to distinguish the pronunciation of ENTOURER from that of ENTERRER (to bury). Hint: ENTOURer likely has the same root as ENTOURage.

question: to be surrounded by
answer: entouré(e)

question: The fence surrounds the garden.
answer: La cloture entoure le jardin.; Use the verb ENTOURER.

question: The garden is surrounded by the fence.
answer: Le jardin est entouré PAR la cloture.; Use the adjective entouré(e). Preposition PAR (= by way of) explains causation in terms of the manner or the place.

question: the surroundings
answer: les environs / les alentours; environner = to be surrounding; être entouré(e) = to be surrounding

question: indoors + outdoors
answer: à l'intérieur + en dehors / en extérieur / à l'extérieur / en plein air; hors = outside

question: the open air (great outdoors)
answer: la grand air

question: out of control
answer: hors de contrôle; to control = CONTRÔLLER; hors = outside

question: out of order
answer: hors service

question: He is standing.
answer: Il est debout. OR Il reste debout.; There is no verb for 'to stand' in french. You must add 'debout' to a verb to explain that someone is standing. It is closer to upright and can also be used to staying awake (instead of going to sleep).

question: The dog is to the left of the person.
answer: Le chien est à guache de la personne.

question: The person is standing to the left of the dog.
answer: Le personne est debout à guache du chien.; Watch out: In french this means that the person is standing to the dog's left - not the left that is the perspective of the viewer.

question: where she stands (on that issue)
answer: où elle en est (literally: where she is on it); Alternatively you could spell out the object of the phrase: où elle est sur cette question; Use simply être. You cannot use verbs like rester or être debout (to stand) to describe a person's view on an issue (as we do in English).

question: between + between X and Y
answer: entre + entre X et Y; Entre is the entire preposition. There is no DE following it. e.g. Entre toi et moi (between you and me). NOT entre de toi...

question: I worked 4 years total as a waitress between other jobs.
answer: J'ai travaillé 4 ans au total comme serveuse souvent entre d'autres emplois.; NB: Use 'souvent' instead of 'beaucoup de fois' because it is much more idiomatic.

question: among
answer: parmi; Parmi is used to indicate something that occurs among a sub-group. e.g. La diminution apparaît plus forte parmi les élèves pauvres. = The decrease appears stronger among poor students.; Parmi is less exclusionary than entre. If you are making a choice or describing an activity that is strictly limited to the sub-group then use entre instead of parmi. e.g. une dispute entre frères = an argument among/between brothers

question: in + inside
answer: dans (preposition meaning 'in') + dedans (adverb meaning 'inside')

question: in front of / in front of the table
answer: devant ('duh-von') / devant la table; There is no preposition DE after devant.; Using devant implies an order. e.g. Je suis assis devant Paul. = I am sitting in front of Paul. - like in a theater or on a bus where some seats are in front of others.

question: facing
answer: en face DE; Do not forget the preposition DE.; en face is different from devant (in front of) because it implies two things facing eachother. e.g. Je suis assis en face DE Paul. = I am sitting across from Paul. - like at a table where seats are facing one another.

question: in front of us + facing us
answer: devant nous + en face DE nous; Use DE with en face but not with devant.

question: in front of the Duomo + on the facade of the Duomo
answer: en face du Duomo + sur la facade du Duomo

question: Faced with this situation...
answer: Face à cette situation...; Literally: Facing this situation...

question: behind + behind the table
answer: derriér + derriér la table

question: It's behind me.
answer: C'est derrière moi.

question: on top of (touching); Specify the pronunciation.
answer: sur; Pronounced with the high-pitched 'ooouh' that you make by first singing 'eeee' and then rounding the lips. And then there is a soft but guteral 'gch' sound at the end for the 'r'.; Sur implies contact between the two objects.

question: above (not touching)
answer: au-dessus de OR en dessus de (same meaning); NB: below (not touching) looks very similar with one letter difference: au-dessous de

question: The apple is on the table. (touching) + The ceiling is above the floor.(not touching)
answer: La pomme est sur la table. + Le plafond est au-dessus du sol. (de + le = du)

question: It's 'on top'.
answer: C'est dessus.

question: idiomatic way to say: I'm working on it. I'm on top of it.
answer: Je travaille dessus.; Literally 'I work on top.'

question: above the sea
answer: au dessus du niveau de la mer; You cannot translate this directly. You have to say that you are above 'the level' of the sea.

question: under (at a short distance and possibly hidden); Specify the pronunciation.
answer: sous; Pronounced with the low-pitched 'oo' like being punched in the stomach. No ending consonant or sound.; NB: sous does not necessarily imply that the two objects are in contact. That is different from sur which does imply contact.

question: below and not touching (at some distance)
answer: au-dessous de OR en dessous de (same meaning); NB: above (not touching) looks very similar with one letter difference: au-dessus de

question: The apple is under the table. + The floor is below the ceiling.
answer: La pomme est sous la table. + Le sol est au-dessous de la plafond.

question: It's 'underneath'.
answer: C'est dessous.

question: underground
answer: souterrain(e) = adjective; le souterrain = the underground

question: at the top + at the bottom
answer: en haut ('ohn-o') + en bas; NB: en haut does not have a liaison so the N falls in the first syllable 'ohn-o'.; Alternatives for the top: le sommet (the summit) + la cime (the tip top - like of a tree)

question: sweating
answer: transpiré(e); Alternative: en‿eau. This uses a liaison so the N is pronounced in the second syllable ('oh-no').

question: upstairs + downstairs
answer: à l'étage + en bas

question: How do you say that you are waiting downstairs/outside of someone's building (when meeting up)?
answer: Je t'attends en bas (de l'immeuble).

question: I went up the stairs. + I went upstairs.
answer: Use the verb MONTER with auxiliare être (to ascend). Je suis monté(e). + Je suis allé(e) à l'étage.; Monter with auxiliare être (and NO object) = to go up / to take oneself up. Monter with auxiliare avoir (and COD) = to take upstairs (or assemble) some object (COD).; Do not use an object if you mean to go up. e.g. Je monte. = I go upstairs. Je monte les escaliers. = I assemble / put up the stairs.

question: I went down the stairs. + I went downstairs.
answer: Use the verb DESCENDRE with auxiliare être (to descend). J'ai descendu les marches. + J'ai descendu les étages. OR Je suis descendu.; NB: descendre uses avoir as the auxiliary when you have a direct object. But is uses être when the verb is followed by nothing or a prepositional phrase.

question: I got on the train. + I got off the train.
answer: Use MONTER/DESCENDRE with auxiliare être for these cases: Je suis monté(e) DANS le train. + Je suis déscendu(e) DU train.; Both require prepositions after the verb because if there was a COD then that would change the meaning of the verb. e.g. Je monte (no COD). = I go up/upstairs.  Je monte le train (COD). = I put up (or assemble) the train.  Je monte DANS le train. = I get (go up) on the train.

question: The sun sets.
answer: Use the verb DESCENDRE (goes down). Le soleil descend.

question: to go back down + to go back up
answer: redescendre + remonter; For both of these cases: Use auxiliare être and do not add a COD (because you want to indicate the state of being). If you say: Je remonte la montagne (COD). = I put the mountain back up. So you must simply say: Je remonte. = I go back up. You can add a prepositional phrase (e.g. sur la montagne) to indicate on what you are ascending.

question: high + low
answer: haut(e) + bas/basse

question: backwards (in terms of movement or direction)
answer: There is no direct translation that is an adjective. Options: 1) de la fin au début (literally from front to back) 2) use the verb régresser (e.g. l'économie régresse = the economy moves backward / regresses / de-evolves)

question: upside down
answer: à l'envers; This can be used to mean backwards but it is not a direct translation.

question: at the beginning + first of all
answer: au début + d'abord

question: the beginning
answer: le début

question: in the middle (of something)
answer: au milieu + DE; e.g. au milieu DU mot = in the middle of the word (de + le = du)

question: the middle paragraph
answer: le paragraphe du milieu

question: the previous question + the following question
answer: la question précédente + la question suivante

question: the month before + the week before
answer: le mois précédent + la semaine précédente

question: the next question + the next month
answer: Generally: la question suivante + le mois prochain; Whether you use suivant(e) or prochain(e) depends on tense and context. Use suivant (or d'apres) in the past tense. e.g. the next question that he asked. Use procain(e) only when projecting into the future. e.g. The party will be next month.; If a list or series has already been established then use suivant(e) to indicate the following item. If you are talking about the next time something happens in the future then use prochain(e).

question: Specify the pronunciation of prochain vs prochaine.
answer: The last syllable of the masculine prochain is super nasal and the N is silent. This is very different from the feminine prochaine which is quick / non-nasal and the N is pronounced.

question: the last question + the last month
answer: la dernière question + le mois dernier; Use dernier/derniére for both cases. This adjective is irregular in that is is placed before the noun instead of after.

question: in the next year + in the next years
answer: dans l'année prochaine + dans les prochaines années; The adjective changes places when the noun is made plural!

question: at the end of his/her studies
answer: à la fin DE ses études

question: I will stop the course in 2 weeks.
answer: J'arrêterai le cours AU BOUT DE deux semaines.; au bout de... is the best phrase to use for 'at the end of...'

question: at the end of...
answer: à la fin ('fon') de... OR au bout de...; NB: au fond can also mean at the end but it is typically used when talking about depth.; Alternative: à l'extrémité DE...

question: at the back (of a photo or piece of furniture)
answer: au fond; e.g. at the back of the armoire = au fond de l'armoire

question: the ending
answer: la terminaison

question: definite articles for masculine + feminine + plural nouns
answer: le/la/les; If the noun starts with a vowel then you replace le/la with l' and pronounce the verb as if it starts with L - ignore the apostrophe when speaking

question: indefinite articles for masculine + feminine + plural nouns
answer: un (masculine..make a smile when you speak it like 'aahn') + une (feminine...make a closed o-shape with mouth like 'oo-yn' and really pronounce the n separately it's almost like two syllables...like bier in german) + des (for all plurals regardless of gender; pronounced 'day')

question: femine masculine plural
answer: féminin masculin pluriel

question: How do you determine which french nouns formed from verbs (e.g. ouvrir to ouverture) are feminine or masculine based on suffix?
answer: Masculine nouns end in -age OR -ment. Feminine nouns end in -(a)tion OR -(s)ion OR xion OR -ade OR -ure.; Ending in E is not helpful because there are feminine and masculine nouns that end in E.

question: How do you determine which french nouns formed from adjectives (e.g. large to largesse) are feminine or masculine based on suffix?
answer: Feminine nouns end in -(i)té OR -eur OR -ise OR -ance OR -ence OR -esse.; It is common that nouns formed from adjectives are feminine because often the noun is formed by selecting the feminine form of the adjective and then adding a suffix.

question: When should there be an apostrophe instead of spelling out le/la?
answer: when the noun starts with a vowel OR when the second letter is a vowel and the first letter is not pronouned (e.g. h); l'académie instead of la académie; l'ordinateur instead of le ordinateur; l'hôtel

question: Aside from a definite article (the) when do you use le/la/l'?
answer: These are also the pronouns for ils/elle when he/she/it is the direct object of a verb; e.g. I read it. = Je le lis. (I + it masculine + read conjugated in present tense)

question: a word + a syllable
answer: un mot ('mow') + un syllable

question: a vowel + a consonant
answer: une voyelle ('voy-ehl') + une consonne

question: a noun + a verb
answer: un nom + un verbe

question: things to do
answer: des choses a faire

question: Date of Birth (for forms)
answer: date de naissance

question: birthday
answer: date d'anniversaire

question: marriage anniversary
answer: anniversaire de mariage

question: engagement (to be married)
answer: les fiançailles; les fiançés = the people engaged to be married

question: a wedding + the wedding rings
answer: un mariage + les alliances

question: a funeral
answer: les funerailles OR l'enterrement

question: the nationality + the citizenship
answer: la nationalité + la citoyenneté

question: U.S. nationality + French nationality
answer: la nationalité états-unienne + la nationalité française; The adjective for 'American' when you want to specify United States: états-unien(e) OR étasunien(e)

question: What is your nationality?
answer: Quelle est votre/ta nationalité?; nationalité is feminine so Quelle and votre/ta must agree with it.

question: I am American.
answer: Je suis américain (m) / américainne (f).; the 'n' is pronounced very lightly and only in the feminine version.; Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French. But when you use a noun that refers to a person then you capitalize: La Française... = the french woman...

question: You are French.
answer: Tu es français (m) / française (f).; masculine pronounced 'fran-say'; feminine pronounced 'fran-seZ'; Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French. But when you use a noun that refers to a person then you capitalize: La Française... = the french woman...

question: a french man + a french woman + the french people
answer: le Français + la Française + les Français; One of the only times that you capitalize these kinds of descriptors is when you use them as a noun that refers to a person. Otherwise français(e) is an adjective that is not capitalized. e.g. Il est français. Elle parle français.

question: How is the name of a language related to nationality?
answer: There are masculine and feminine versions of every nationality. The language is always the masculine version.; e.g. Il est allemand. Elle est allemande. Elle parle allemand.; 'allemand' is how you translate German when you mean the language.; BUT the word for language is feminine (la langue). So if you want to say the entire phrase 'the german language' then it is a feminine noun with a feminine adjective: la langue allemande.

question: a french/argentine passport
answer: un passport français/argentin; Un visa is also masculine.

question: the confirmation of citizenship in France (if you were not born there)
answer: la naturalisation; alternative: la acquisition de la nationalité

question: the right of citizenship if you are born in France
answer: le droit du sol

question: I am French-American.
answer: Je suis franco-américain(ne).; Regardless of whether you were born French or American... the order of this combination is always franco + americain(ne).; Alternative: Je suis de nationalité française et américaine.

question: I do not come from Paris.
answer: Je ne viens pas de Paris.; To make a statement negative: Add NE directly after the subject (pronouns never come between the subject and NE). Then add PAS after the conjugated verb (or the auxiliary in the case of passé composé).

question: I do not live in Berlin.
answer: Je n'habite pas à Berlin.; If the verb starts with a vowel or the first pronounced sound is a vowel (no 'h' in france) then use N' instead of NE.

question: I have family in Sweden.
answer: J'ai de la famille en Suède.; AVOIR + 'de la famille' is an idiomatic way of expressing that some of your family is in a location.

question: I don't see well.
answer: Je ne vois pas bien.; Adding pas to an adjective totally negates it and makes it negative instead of neutral. e.g. pas parfait = the opposite of perfect; Remember that when you use negation NE is optional especially when spoken.

question: I speak English.
answer: Je parle ('shhhhhhparl') anglais. OR Je parle en anglais. Either is correct - like in english (I speak English. OR I speak in English.); NB: In french we always use an article in front of noun. Speaking a language (using the verb parler) is the only exception. When using parler we do not say/write... Je parle l'anglais. But any other time you use the name of a language (or any other noun) then you always add an article in front of it.

question: I do not speak Mandarin.
answer: Je ne parle pas mandarin.; Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French.

question: I speak a little Spanish + French + German.
answer: Je parle ('shhhhhparl') un peu espagnol et français et allemand.; JE is pronounced slowly as a long 'shhhh' sound. But you must avoid making it a separate syllable. It's not 'shuh-parl'. It's 'shhhhhparl'.

question: a french class + a dance class
answer: un cours de français + un cours ('koohr') de dance;  NB: cours looks plural ending in S but it is singular.; Do not use 'classe' for this. Une classe refers to class heirarchy (e.g. 1st class) or the specific time that you are in school.

question: I go to french class. + I take a french class.
answer: Je vais EN cour de français. + Je prends ('shhhhhpruh') un cours de français.; Do not use à for going to class. That is used for going to a city etc. - somewhere you visit.

question: a french A2 class
answer: un cours du A2; 'french' is understood

question: a class + a race + a yard; Specify pronunciation.
answer: All of these words sound similar but have different meanings.; un cours ('koohr') = a class / a course of action / an errand; une course ('coors') = a race; une cour ('coor') = a yard / a courtyard; la compétition de course à pied = the foot race

question: a messenger / a courier
answer: un corsier

question: the level + the levels
answer: le niveau + les niveaux; e.g. mon niveau de français = my level of french

question: a skill + a high level of skill
answer: une compétence + un haut niveau de compétence

question: a collection of deep skills
answer: un ensemble de compétences approfondies

question: a higher level
answer: un niveau supérieur; NOT plus haut

question: of high quality
answer: une qualité élevée OR De haute qualité

question: a class at a good level (for me)
answer: un cours À un bon niveau

question: at most + at least
answer: (tout) au plus + au moins

question: at least one month; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: au moins (very nasal 'mwah') un mois (non-nasal 'mwah'); Literally the only difference between the sound of moins and mois is the nasality of the vowel. Adding the N to the OI changes it from a sound in the mouth to a sound in the nasal cavity.

question: some + several
answer: certaines + plusieurs

question: When some people... and other people...
answer: Quand certaines personnes... et d'autres personnes...

question: a bit + a little bit
answer: un peu + un petit peu; These are quantities so they are always followed by the generic preposition DE/D' and without any article. e.g. un peu d'information (NOT des informations)

question: a lot / many
answer: beaucoup; If you use beaucoup as a quantity (e.g. a lot of fish / many fish) then you must add the generic preposition DE/D' (without articles)between beaucoup and the object of the preposition (e.g. beaucoup de poisson). Omit articles completely because we are expressing a quantity.; If you use beaucoup to modify a verb (e.g. We drank a lot.) then it is an adverb and must come before the verb (e.g. Nous avons beaucoup bu.).

question: There are a lot of hospitals and cliniques in this city.
answer: Il y a beaucoup D'hôpitaux et DE cliniques à cette ville.; When there are two or more nouns (hospitals and cliniques) that refer to the same quantity (many / a lot of) then all of the nouns must be prefaced by the generic DE.

question: in many cases...
answer: dans de nombreux cas...; numerous = nombreux (pl masc) /  nombreuses (pl fem); This works like beaucoup in that it triggers the generic DE (like a quantity).; Both of these are plural adjectives. There is no way for this adjective to be singular.; You can only use the feminine form (nombreuses) if ALL of the items are feminine.

question: How do you pronounce: Il y a ('eeyah') cinq chaises.
answer: In conversation Il Y A is shortened to 'eeyah'.

question: not much (like when someone asks you what you have been doing and there is little to report)
answer: pas grand chose OR rien d'especial; e.g. Je n'ai pas fait grand chose. / J'ai fait rien d'especial.; Do not use the phrase 'pas beaucoup' - this does not make sense in french.

question: nothing extravagant
answer: rien d'extravagant

question: too much + too much money
answer: trop ('troh') + trop D'argent; (like beaucoup) Trop is a quantity and it can be used on it's own.; When used as a quantity then it is always followed by the generic DE (without articles).

question: There are too many of them.
answer: Il y EN a trop.; When you specify of what there is too much then you use DE (e.g. trop de bouteilles). So when you do not specify the noun then you replace it with pronom EN.

question: extra; Specify pronunciation.
answer: supplémentaire ('soo-play-mOH-tehr'); EN is a nasal 'ohn' sound but the N is silent.; e.g. une semaine supplémentaire = an extra week

question: so nice
answer: tellement gentil(e) OR si gentil(e); Tellement and Si are the words that add emphasis like 'so' in english.; There is no preposition required if it proceeds an adjective or adverb.

question: so much (stuff)
answer: tellement DE choses OR si de choses; Tellement and Si are the words that add emphasis like 'so' in english.; You must add DE if it proceeds a noun. You must explicitly state the object (choses).

question: so many activities
answer: tellement D'activités OR si d'activités; Tellement and Si are the words that add emphasis like 'so' in english.; You must add DE if it proceeds a noun. You must explicitly state the object (activités).

question: idiomatic way to say: She's very very (sooooo) nice etc. (any adjective).
answer: Elle est tellement agréable.; Tellement is the word that adds emphasis like 'so' in english.

question: I do quite a lot of things.
answer: Je fais pas mal de chose.; NB: 'pas mal' can mean not bad but it can also mean quite a lot.

question: She eats apples. Which word is assumed in English but cannot be assumed in French?
answer: Elle mange DES pommes.; Partitive article is the name for the word that describes an uncountable or unknown (an undefined) quantity of something. (This is different from a defined or specified quantity like beaucoup DE X.) In this example the partitive article is 'some' and it is optional in English. She eats (some) apples. But in French the partitive article is never optional.

question: What are the partitive articles in French?
answer: These are contractions of DE + an article (le/la/les) that are used in front of any undefined (or unknown or uncountable) quantity (e.g. J'ai DES frais. = I have strawberries.). The partitive articles are: du/d' (masculine) + de la/de l' (feminine) + des/d' (plural); This is different from the generic DE that is used for defined quantities (including lack of something). e.g. un peu D'huile + pas DE pommes.

question: Is there (some/any) coffee / onion?
answer: Est-ce qu'il y a DU café / D'oignon?; When the quantity is undefined use the partitive articles (du / de la / des) instead of the generic de.; These nouns are masculine so we use DU. DU contracts to D' when the noun starts with a vowel.

question: Is there (some/any) meat / water?
answer: Est-ce qu'il y a DE LA viande / DE L'eau?; When the quantity is undefined use the partitive articles (du / de la / des) instead of the generic de.; These nouns are feminine so we use DE LA. LA contracts to L' when the noun starts with a vowel.

question: Are there (some/any) lemons / onions?
answer: Est-ce qu'il y a DES citrons / DES oignons?; When the quantity is undefined use the partitive articles (du / de la / des) instead of the generic de.; The gender of the plural noun does not matter. DES never contracts when the noun starts with a vowel because DES ends with a consonant.

question: the water
answer: l'eau; eau is feminine. But la eau contracts to l'eau to avoid back-to-back vowels.; This is pronounced really strongly 'loh'.; -eau is pronounced as a strong 'oh' - like the words chateau and bateau.

question: two glasses of water (explain the pronunciation difference)
answer: deux verre D'eau; The O sound in deux is higher in the mouth. The O sound in d'eau is lower in the mouth; d'eau = DE + EAU. Use generic DE + EAU (instead of de + la + eau) because verre is a specified quantity.

question: The water is good. + a glass of water +  + I drink water.
answer: These exhibit the three different ways to talk about water.; 1) L'eau est bonne. = The water is good. We are using the noun with its article (LA contracts to L').; 2) un verre d'eau = a glass of water. The glass is a specified quantity so we use the generic DE without anarticle. (DE contracts to D'.); 3) Je bois DE l'eau. = I drink water. The verb BOIRE is always followed by DE but it is not a quantity indicator. So you also have to give the object of the verb (water) it's article (la). DE + LA + EAU = de l'eau.

question: She eats a lot. + She ate a lot.; Note the location of 'beaucoup' in both cases.
answer: Elle mange beaucoup. + Elle a beaucoup mangé.; If beaucoup describes the verb (manger) - as it does in both of these sentences - instead of the object (e.g. beaucoup DE frais)... then beaucoup must follow the conjugated portion of a verb. That means that 'beaucoup' falls between the two parts of passé composé in this case.

question: You (informal) eat a lot of apples.; Which preposition is required?
answer: Tu manges beaucoup DE pommes.; 'A lot' in this case does not modify the verb (manger) here. It describes the quantity of apples (just like 'a kilo'). When quantity is specified use the generic DE (instead of partitive articles).

question: He ate a lot. + He ate a lot of apples.; Note the location of 'beaucoup' in both cases.
answer: Il a BEAUCOUP mangé. + Il a mangé BEAUCOUP de pommes.; Both examples are passé composé so there are two parts to the verbs. In the first case BEAUCOUP modifies the verb (manger) so it must follow the conjugated portion of the two-part verb. In the second case BEAUCOUP modifies the object (pommes) so it must be placed after the entire verb.

question: There is coffee. + There is a box of coffee.
answer: Il y a DU (de + le) café. + Il y a un carton DE café. (le café); The former has an undefined quantity so we use the partitive article DU (de + le) for the masculine café.; The latter has a defined quantity so we use generic DE.

question: There is salad + There is a pack of salad.
answer: Il y a DE LA salade. + Il y a un paquet DE salade. (la salade); The former has an unspecified amount so we use the partitive article DE LA for the feminine salade.; The latter has a specified amount/quantity so we use generic DE.

question: There is a jar of strawberry jam.
answer: Il y a un pot DE confiture de fraise. (la confiture); The quantity is defined so use the generic DE (or D').

question: There are a dozen cookies.
answer: Il y a une douzaine DE biscuits. (les biscuits); The quantity is defined so use the generic DE (or D').

question: There is a handful of blueberries.
answer: Il y a une poignée DE myrtilles (les myrtilles); The quantity is defined so use the generic DE (or D').

question: group words for: a dozen + a set of roughly 10 (tens)
answer: une douzaine ('doo-zehn') + une dizaine ('dee-zehn'); e.g. des dizaines de personnes = tens of individuals; If you want to communicate something that is greater than 10 and less than 100 then you could say: plusieurs dizaines = several tens (30 or 40 or 50 etc).

question: a decade
answer: une décennie

question: approximately 10 years
answer: une dizaine d'années; une dizaine is the group word for roughly 10 - similar to a dozen (une douzaine) for 12.

question: a set of roughly 100 (hundreds) + a set of roughly 1000 (thousands)
answer: une centaine ('son-tehn') + un millier ('mee'lyay'); e.g. des centaines de milliers de cuillères = hundreds of thousands of spoons

question: You have blue eyes. + You have beautiful eyes.; Explain what happens to the partitive article.
answer: Tu as DES yeux bleus. + Tu as DE beaux yeux.; Beaux is an irregular adjective becuase it is placed before the noun. When we place an adjective before a noun...the plural partitive article (des = de + les) changes to a generic preposition (de) and the article is dropped completely.

question: Three ways to say: There are no apples.
answer: 1) Il n'y a pas DE pommes. = There are no apples. 2) Il n'y a plus DE pommes. = There are no more apples. 3) Il n'y a zero DE pommes. = There are zero apples.; In all three cases the quantity is defined in some way (negative qualities are still defined). So we must use the generic DE instead of partitive articles (du / de la / des).

question: There is milk. + There is no milk. + There is only milk.
answer: Il y a DU lait. + Il n'y a pas DE lait. + Il n'y a que DU lait.; In the first and third phrases the quantity is undefined so use partitive article DU for masculine lait. In the second phrase the quantity is negative (which is defined) so use the generic DE lait.; NE + PAS = none; NE + QUE = only

question: There is oil. + There is no oil. + There is only oil.
answer: Il y a DE L'huile. + Il n'y a pas D'huile. + Il n'y a que DE L'huile.; In the first and third phrases the quantity is undefined so use partitive article DE LA for feminine huile. In the second phrase the quantity is negative (which is defined) so use the generic D'huile (contract DE because the object starts with a non-aspirational H).; NE + PAS = none; NE + QUE = only

question: There are eggs. + There are no eggs. + There is only eggs.
answer: Il y a DES œufs. ('dez-oo'; fs is silent) + Il n'y a pas D'œufs. +  Il n'y a que DES œufs.; In the first and third phrases the quantity is undefined so use partitive article DES for plural œufs. In the second phrase the quantity is negative (which is defined) so use the generic D'œufs.; NE + PAS = none; NE + QUE = only

question: It's only ... (e.g. It's only one day.)
answer: Ce N'est QUE... (e.g. Ce n'est qu'un jour.); This is a very idiomatic way of speaking. It looks like QUE replaces PAS but that is not what is happening because this is not a negative statement. Generally if you omit PAS then negation does not occur.; que + un = qu'un (pronounced 'kahn' not 'koon') because QUE contracts.; C'est seulement... is an alternative but less idiomatic.

question: It's ONLY 30 minutes.
answer: Ce N'était QUE 30 minutes.; NE + QUE emphasises... ONLY a friend. It looks like QUE replaces PAS but that is not what is happening because this is not a negative statement. Generally if you omit PAS then negation does not occur.

question: He/she is ONLY a friend.
answer: Ce N'est QU'un ami.; NE + QUE emphasises... ONLY a friend.  It looks like QUE replaces PAS but that is not what is happening because this is not a negative statement. Generally if you omit PAS then negation does not occur.; Use CE instead of il/elle. This is an idiomatic phrase.; que + un = qu'un (pronounced 'kahn' not 'koon') because QUE contracts.

question: Jean has (some) money. + Jean has no money.
answer: Jean a DE L'argent. + Jean n'a pas D'argent.; In the first phrase the quantity is undefined so use partitive article DE LA for the feminine argent. In the second phrase the quantity is negative (which is defined) so use the generic DE.

question: I play sports. + I do not play sports.
answer: Je fais DU sport. + Je ne fais DE sport.; In the first phrase the quantity is undefined so use partitive article (de + le = DU sport); In the second phrase the quantity is negative (which is defined) so use the generic DE.

question: In futur proche: We are going to play tennis. + We are not going to play tennis.
answer: On va faire DU tennis. + On ne va pas faire DE tennis.; PAS is being used as an adverb to negate the verb. So we must respect the use of the generic DE when the verb is negated. This is contrasted with the use of the partitive article (de + le = DU) when the verb is not negated.; Remember that when you use negation NE is optional especially in spoken french.

question: She likes talking with clients. + She does not like talking with clients.
answer: Elle aime bien parler avec DES clients. + Elle n'aime pas parler avec DES clients.; In both cases we use the partitive articles (du / de la / des) - instead of the generic DE - because the clients are sequestered away from the verb in a prepositional clause ('with the clients'). When we negate the sentence by using PAS as an adverb the prepositional phrases are not impacted by the negation.

question: We respond to emails. + We do not respond to emails.
answer: Nous répondons AUX e-mails. + Nous ne répondons pas AUX e-mails.; In both cases we use the partitive article (au / à la / aux) - instead of the generic DE - because the emails are sequestered away from the verb in a prepositional clause ('to the emails'). When we negate the sentence by using PAS as an adverb the prepositional phrases are not impacted by the negation.

question: We are professors. + We are not professors.
answer: Nous sommes (des) professeurs. + Nous ne sommes pas (des) professeurs.; In this case we do not use the generic DE before the object (professeurs) when the phrase is negated because we are using PAS as an adjective (literally: We are no professors.) - not as an adverb.; It's helpful to memorize: When a noun follows the verb ÊTRE...and when the statement is negated... then we do NOT change from a partitive article (le/la/les or un/une/des) to a non-partitive article (de/d').

question: You are an actor. + You are not an actor.
answer: Tu est (un) acteur. + Tu n'est pas (un) acteur.; In this case we do not place the generalized DE before the object because we are using PAS as an adjective (literally: You are no actor.).; It's helpful to memorize: When a noun follows the verb ÊTRE...and when the statement is negated... then we do NOT change from a partitive article (le/la/les or un/une/des) to a non-partitive article (de/d').

question: We find a place to park a car. + We do not find a place.
answer: On trouve un endroit pour garer une voiture. + On ne trouve pas D'endroit.; The second phrase is negated by using PAS as an adverb. So we must use the generic DE (not d'un endroit or du endroit.).

question: We risk finding a monster. + We risk not finding a place.
answer: On risque de trouver un monstre. + On risque NE PAS trouver D'endroit.; When the infinitive verb is negated (instead of the conjugated verb) then place both NE and PAS directly before the infinitive verb.; When a statement is negated by using PAS as an adverb then we must replace partitive articles with the generic DE (even if the negated verb is in the infinitive form).

question: If he leaves now... he risks losing his money.
answer: S'il part maintenant... il risque DE perdre son argent.; The formula is: subject + RISQUER (conjugated) + DE + INFINITIVE.

question: If I do not study... I risk failing the exam.
answer: Se je n'étudie pas... je risque D'échouer l'examen.; The formula is: subject + RISQUER (conjugated) + DE + INFINITIVE.

question: to be plagued by
answer: en proie ('uhn-prwa'); e.g. Je suis en proie à tomber malade. = I am at risk of falling ill.

question: He never wants to go out.
answer: Il NE veut JAMAIS sortir.; JAMAIS (adverb) replaces PAS (adverb) to express never (which is still negation).; Jamais is always an adverb.; NB: When JAMAIS is not paired with NE then it means ever (instead of never).

question: There are pears. + There are never pears.
answer: Il y a DES poires. + Il n'y a jamais DE poires.; JAMAIS (adverb) replaces PAS (adverb) to express never (which is still negation).; Jamais is always an adverb so we generalize the object by replacing partitive articles with generic DE/D'.

question: I eat an insect. + I never eat an insect.
answer: Je mange un insecte. + Je ne mange jamais d'insecte.; JAMAIS (adverb) replaces PAS (adverb) to express never (which is still negation).; Jamais is always an adverb so we generalize the object by replacing partitive articles with generic DE/D'.

question: She never went to Vietnam.
answer: Elle N'est JAMAIS allée au Vietnam.; In passé composé (or any tense that uses an auxiliary) PAS/PLUS/RIEN/JAMAIS are placed directly after the auxiliary (the conjugated portion) and before the participe. PERSONNE is different in that it is placed directly after the participe.

question: She is going to go to Vietnam. + She is never going to go to Vietnam.
answer: Elle va aller au Vietnam (futur proche can be directly translated from English). + Elle NE vas JAMAIS aller au Vietnam.; JAMAIS (adverb) replaces PAS (adverb) to express never (which is still negation).; au Vietnam is a prepositional phrase what is sheltered from the negation so we do not change AU to generic DE.; When there are two verbs (one conjugated + one infinitive) PAS/PLUS/JAMAIS (all adverbs) - and even RIEN - are placed directly after the conjugated verb. PERSONNE is a pronoun so it is placed directly after the final verb (the infinitive).;

question: They are always on time. + They are never on time.
answer: Ils sont TOUJOURS à l'heure. + Ils NE sont JAMAIS à l'heure.; The inverse of toujours (always) is jamais (never).; JAMAIS (adverb) replaces PAS (adverb) to express never (which is still negation).; à l'heure is a prepositional phrase that is sheltered from the negation so we do not change À LA to generic DE.; NB: Jamais can also be the inverse of encore and déja.

question: Have you already lied to your parents? + I never lied to my parents.
answer: As tu déjà menti à tes parents? + Je n'ai JAMAIS menti à mes parents.; The inverse of déjà (already) is jamais (never).; JAMAIS (adverb) replaces PAS (adverb) to express never (which is still negation); à mes parents.is a prepositional phrase that is sheltered from the negation so we do not change À to DE.; NB: Jamais can also be the inverse of toujours and encore.

question: no more / no longer; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: non plus ('pleww'); S is silent because plus is used as an adverb here.; When PLUS is used as a negative adverb it means frequency of zero. It can replace PAS in the NE + PAS syntax. Use it when you want to negate a statement where the action has stopped.

question: me neither; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: moi non plus ('pleww'); S is silent because plus is used as an adverb here.

question: I can eat. + I cannot eat more.
answer: Je peux manger. + Je NE mange PLUS ('pleww').; S is silent because plus is used as an adverb here.; NE + PLUS (no more / no longer) is a negative adverb. PLUS replaces PAS in the NE + PAS syntax.; NE + PLUS (doing something no more / no longer) is the opposite of STILL going something.

question: He continues to sleep. + He sleeps no more.
answer: Il continue de dormir. + Il NE dort PLUS ('pleww').; S is silent because plus is used as an adverb here.; NE + PLUS (no more / no longer) is a negative adverb. PLUS replaces PAS in the NE + PAS syntax.; NE + PLUS (doing something no more / no longer) is the opposite of STILL going something.

question: I still have money. + I do not have any more money.
answer: J'ai encore DE L'argent. + Je N'ai PLUS D'argent.; NE + PLUS (no more / no longer) is a negative adverb. PLUS replaces PAS in the NE + PAS syntax.; In the first phrase the quantity is undefined so we must use partitive articles (de la). In the second phrase the quantity is negative (which is defined) so we must use generic DE.

question: In which scenarios is the word PLUS pronounced without the S ('pleww')?
answer: Pronounce the S if you are uncertain. Consider the lack of an S-sound as an exception.; 1) ADVERB/ADJECTIVE: When plus is used as an adverb OR adjective - positively or negatively - it is pronounced 'pleww'. e.g. plus grand (= bigger) + plus vite (= faster) + non plus (= no longer).; 2) Negative quantity: Il n'y a plus ('pleww') de lumière. = There is no longer any light.; 3) A quantity with figures: Il y a plus ('pleww') de 500 euros.

question: In which scenarios is the word PLUS always pronounced with an S ('plewws')?
answer: 1) PLUS DE + NOM: Il y a plus de jupes.; 2) Addition: 3 + 7.; Pronounce the S if you are uncertain. Consider the lack of an S-sound as an exception.

question: I can eat apples. + I can eat more apples. + I cannot eat more apples.
answer: Je peux manger DES pommes. + Je peux manger PLUS DE pommes. +  Je NE peux PAS manger PLUS DE pommes.; In this case PLUS is used in the positive sense (which creates a defined quantity using generic DE). In the last phrase we use NE + PAS to negate the verb.

question: I can eat 2 more apples. + I cannot eat 2 more apples.
answer: Je peux manger deux pommes supplémentaires. + Je NE peux PAS manger deux pommes DE PLUS.; In this case PLUS is used in the positive sense (which creates a defined quantity using generic DE). In the last phrase we use NE + PAS to negate the verb.

question: We learn more things. + We learn more.
answer: On apprend PLUS DE choses. + On EN apprend PLUS.; In the latter phrase we did not specify the object (what is learned). This is impossible in French. We must reference it with either 'plus DE choses' OR the pronom EN. Pronom EN replaces a quantity of something or the complement of a verb following DE.

question: to take a break + to not take a break
answer: faire une pause + ne pas faire une pause; To negate an infinitive both NE and PAS are placed before the infinitive verb.; This is most commonly done when providing a definition.

question: I am happy to call. + I am happy to not call.
answer: Je suis content(e) d'appeler. + Je suis content(e) de NE PAS appeler.; To negate an infinitive both NE and PAS are placed before the infinitive verb.

question: She takes a break. + She does not take a break.
answer: Elle fait une pause. + Elle NE fait PAS une pause.; To negate a conjugated verb (not in the infinitive) separate NE and PAS on either side of the conjugated verb.

question: Using the formal you: Take a break! + Don't take a break!
answer: Impératif mood: Faites une pause. + NE faites PAS de pause.; To negate a conjugated verb (not in the infinitive) separate NE and PAS on either side of the conjugated verb.

question: Explain how negation using an adverb is different from negation using an adjective.
answer: PAS can be used as a negative adverb (to negate a verb) or as a negative adjective (to negate a noun - like aucun(e)).; Using PAS as a negative adverb: I do not see cats. = Je NE vois PAS DE chat. (When a negative adverb is used the quantity becomes defined so we must use generic DE.); Using PAS as a negative adjective: I see no cats. = Je NE vois PAS un chats. (The quantity is still undefined so we use partitive articles instead of generic DE.); NB: PAS should only be used as a negative adjective with nouns that can be quantified (e.g. cats). Use AUCUNE(E) for nouns that are difficult to quantify (e.g. happiness).

question: none
answer: aucun(e) depending on the gender of the noun that it represents; AUCUN(E) can be used as a negative pronoun (on its own) or a negative adjective (modifying a noun).; NB: PAS can also be used as a negative adjective - but not as a negative pronoun.

question: None (of the characters) are nice.
answer: AUCUN (des personnages) N'est gentil(le).; In this case AUCUN(E) is a negative pronoun (standing on its own). But we still need NE to complete the negation.; Because aucun(e) is not being used as an adverb we do not have to use generic DE - so we keep the partitive article (DES).

question: no/zero cats
answer: aucun chats; In this case aucun(e) is being used as an adjective - not an adverb. So we do not have to use generic DE.

question: No answer is bad.
answer: AUCUNE réponse N’est mauvaise.; In this case AUCUN(E) is a negative adjective. But we still need NE to complete the negation.; Aucun(e) is not an adverb so we do not have to add generic DE to the noun (answer).

question: No plane is flying today.
answer: AUCUN avion NE vole aujourd’hui.; In this case AUCUN(E) is a negative adjective. But we still need NE to complete the negation.; Aucun(e) is not an adverb so we do not have to add generic DE to the noun (plane).

question: I did not make any mistakes.

question: Explain how PERSONNE and RIEN are different from PAS and JAMAIS and PLUS (when negating a phrase).
answer: PAS + JAMAIS + PLUS are all negative ADVERBS that are used (with NE) to negate a verb. But PERSONNE (no one) and RIEN (nothing) are negative PRONOUNS that mean quanity zero of humans (personne) or non-human things (rien). These pronouns simultaneously replace and negate a noun (not a verb). So PERSONNE and RIEN can be either the subject or object of the verb - but not an adverb.; NB: PAS can be used as a negative adverb or as a negative ADJECTIVE (like AUCUN(E)).

question: nothing

You cannot say: Il n'y a rien de poires because REIN is not an adverb.; Rien (nothing) is the opposite of tout (everything).

question: Explain the two words that mean: better

question: It's a better place. + It's a better life.

answer: Use the same adverb or adjective that you would choose for 'better'. Use the adjective options - LE/LA/LES MEILLEUR(E)(S) - because 'best' is an adjective describing the subject of the phrase.

question: Camille and Chloé are the best. + Marc and Jacques are the best.
answer: Camille et Chloé sont LES MEILLEURES (fem pl). + Marc et Jacques sont LES MEILLEURS (masc pl).; Use the adjective options - LE/LA/LES MEILLEUR(E)(S) - because 'best' is an adjective describing the subject of the phrase.

question: The best thing is... + The best man is...
answer: La meilleure (fem sing) est... + Le meilleur (masc sing) est...; meilleur(e)(s) are irregular adjectives that comes before the noun.

question: The best houses are... + The best cats are...
answer: ; Les meilleures maisons (fem pl) sont... + Les meilleurs chats (masc pl) sont...; meilleur(e)(s) are irregular adjectives that comes before the noun.

question: the best choice
answer: le meilleur choix

question: It's the best that I can do.
answer: C'est le mieux que je puisse faire.; This phrase triggers the subjonctif (puisse instead of peux).

question: Everyone makes the best choice for themselves.
answer: On fait le meilleur choix pour soi-même. OR On fait tous des choix qui nous semblent les plus appropriés.

question: idiomatic way to say: to each their own
answer: 1) les goûts et les couleurs: best option - very neutral and respectful of the tastes of others 2) à chacun son goût: a little aggressive - similar to 'we will agree to disagree' - it is used as a way to shut down an argument

question: idiomatic way to say: I'm staying out of it. (when you want to remove yourself from a debate or decision)
answer: Je m'abstiens.; The verb is S'ABSTENIR. The literal translation is: I abstain.

question: She has gained the upper hand (the advantage) in the debate.
answer: Elle a emporté l'avantage dans ce combat.; EMPORTER l'avantage = to have/gain the advantage; The verb EMPORTER (= to take) can be used figuratively in this way but then it is more commonly used for expressions like this: Le coeur l'emporte sur la raison. ...when you buy something you can't afford or fall in love with someone unreasonable. The generic pronom (le) in front of the verb is required because the verb EMPORTER must have a direct object (in addition to the prepositional phrase 'sur le...'). When the COD is not specified we use generic LE.

question: I was not drinking last night.
answer: Je me suis abstenue de boire hier soir. OR Je me suis abstenue d'alcool hier soir.; The verb is S'ABSTENIR.

question: bad + poorly/badly
answer: mal/mauvais (adjective) + mal (adverb); mal/mauvais is irregular in that it is placed before the noun that it describes.

question: Explain the two words that mean: worse
answer: 1) PLUS MAL is an adverb. Use it when describing a verb. It is the oppossite mieux (better/more well). 2) PIRE/PIRE/PIRES/PIRES are adjective. Use them when describing a noun. They are the opposite of meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meilleures (better/more good).

question: In addition to pire(s)... what is another adjective that can be used to mean 'worse'?
answer: PLUS + mauvais/mauvaise/mauvais/mauvaises can be used instead of simply pire/pires when 'worse' is an adjective that describes a noun.; e.g. Le chat est pire (masc sing) que le chien. = Le chat est PLUS mauvais (masc sing) que le chien.

question: Jacques sings worse than Marc.
answer: Jacques chante PLUS MAL que Marc.; Use plus mal (instead of pire/pires) because 'worse' is an adverb describing 'sings'. Adverbs do not need to agree (in number and gender) with a noun.; Pire (worse) and mal (poorly/badly) are irregular adverbs. They do not follow the general rules for transforming an adjective to an adverb.

question: The dogs sing worse than the cats.
answer: Les cheins chantent PLUS MAL que les chats.; Use plus mal (instead of pire/pires) because 'worse' is an adverb describing 'sing'. Adverbs do not need to agree (in number and gender) with a noun.

question: The cat is worse than the dog.
answer: Le chat est PIRE (masc sing) que le chien.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the cat'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: The house is worse than the apartment.
answer: La maison est PIRE (fem sing) que la appartement.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the house'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: The cats are worse than the dogs.
answer: Les chats sont PIRES (masc plural) que les chiens.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the cats'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: The houses are worse than the apartments.
answer: Les maisons sont PIRES (fem sing) que les appartement.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the houses'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: Explain the two words that mean: worst
answer: Use the same adverb or adjective that you would choose for 'worse'. And you must add an article (le/la/les) because 'the worst' is always a noun.; The two options: 1) LE PLUS MAL when you are describing someone/thing that is the worst at doing some verb. Adverbs do not adapt (in number and gender) to the verb. It is the opposite of le mieux (the best). 2) LE/LA/LES PIRE(S) are adjectives used to describe a noun - when some thing is 'the worst' of the group. Adjectives must adapt (in number and gender) to the noun they describe. These are the opposites of le meilleur / la meilleure / les meilleurs / les meilleures.

question: In addition to le pire / la pire / les pires... what is another way to express 'the worst'?
answer: le PLUS mauvais / la PLUS mauvaise / les PLUS mauvais(es) can be used when 'the worst' references a noun. e.g. La maison est la pire (fem sing). = La maison est la PLUS mauvaise (fem sing).

question: Chloé sings the worst.
answer: Chloé chante LE PLUS MAL.; Use le plus mal (instead of le/la/les pire(s)) because 'worst' refers to the verb 'sings'. Le plus mal does not need to agree (in number and gender) with a noun.

question: Simone and Camille sing the worst.
answer: Simone et Camille chantent LE PLUS MAL.; Use le plus mal (instead of le/la/les pire(s)) because 'worst' refers to the verb 'sing'. Le plus mal does not need to agree (in number and gender) with a noun.

question: The banana is the worst. + The tea is the worst.
answer: La banane est la pire (fem sing). + Le thé est le pire (masc sing.); Use le/la/les pire(s) because 'worst' references a noun instead of an action.

question: The tomatoes are the worst. + The lemons are the worst.
answer: Les tomates sont les pires (fem plural). + Les citrons sont les pires (masc plural).; Use le/la/les pire(s) because 'worst' references a noun instead of an action.

question: conjugate 'to be'
answer: être: je suis + tu es ('ay') + il/elle/on est ('ay') + nous sommes + vous êtes ('vooz-eht')+ ils/elles sont ('ssson')

question: When is est (conjugated 'to be') pronounced as 'ayt' instead of 'ay'?
answer: when the adjective following it starts with a vowel; e.g. Ils est intelligente; If the t in est was not pronounced is would be two vowels together and that is not how french is spoken; But otherwise the t at the end of est is never pronounced.

question: When is et (and) pronounced as 'ayt' instead of 'ay'?
answer: Never. Never make the t sound - even when the next word starts with a vowel; e.g. Elle est grande et intelligente - the pronounciation of et does not change.

question: conjugate the verb 'to have'
answer: avoir: j'ai + tu as + il/elle/on a + nous avons + vous avez + ils/elles ont

question: conjugate the verb 'to do' / 'to make'
answer: faire: je fais + tu fais + il/elle/on fait + nous faisons + vous faites + il/elles font

question: What is the difference between FAIRE and SE FAIRE?
answer: FAIRE = to do / to make. SE FAIRE = to get done. SE FAIRE + VERB = to make (someone) do something.; Making the verb reflexive (in this case) is a way to emphasize the verb or to describe pain (e.g. Mes genoux me font mal. = My knees are hurting me.).

question: The trip made her grow up.
answer: Le voyage l'a fait (se faire) grandir.; FAIRE = to do / to make. SE FAIRE = to get done. SE FAIRE + VERB = to make (someone) do something.; In this case SE FAIRE + GRANDIR = to make (someone) grow up.

question: What is the radical of a verb?
answer: The radical is the base of a verb - it generally does not change as the verb is conjugated within the same tense. But the radical may change from one tense to another (e.g. past vs future); NB: For group 1 (-er) and group 2 (-ir) verbs the 'radical du présent' is the part of the infinitive minus ER and IR.; Conjugation for group 3 verbs is more complicated. e.g. The 'radical du futur' for ALLER is IR (nous irons).

question: How do you conjugate group 1 verbs (regular -ER verbs) in present tense?
answer: endings: je -e (only pronouce the radical) + tu -es (silent) + il/elle/on -e (silent) + nous -ons (pronounced like nasal 'on') + vous -ez (pronounced like 'ay') + ils/elles -ent (-ent is ALWAYS silent in verbs but it forces the pronunciation of the previous letter)

question: What is the intonation on the conjugated forms for first person singular (je)?
answer: the intonation is always downward and shortened; e.g. je travaille sounds like 'ju tru-vay' not 'ju trav-a-ye'.

question: How do you pronounce the ending for the nous form of -ER verbs?
answer: the ending for nous is -ons ('ohn' very nasal without much of an 'n' sound on the end); this is the same sound as the on in il/elle/on ..when we use the casual form of 'we' when speaking

question: What is the only verb ending in -ER that is totally irregular?
answer: aller (to go)

question: What are some variations or small irregularities that occur when conjugating -ER verbs and which forms to they impact? (disregard the totally irregular verb ALLER)
answer: 1) In some cases there is an accent change in the second syllable when conjugating -ER verbs au présent (e.g. acheter + préférer); 2) For -YER verbs the Y can stay a Y or it can change to I before adding the endings. Either spelling is 100% correct but the pronunciations are slightly different. If we keep the Y in the spelling then the 'y' sound is heard more in the pronunciation.; When there are irregularities in conjugating -ER verbs au présent all forms are impacted EXCEPT nous and vous forms - those two forms are conjugated exactly as you would expect for -ER verbs.

question: How do you conjugate group 2 verbs (regular -ir verbs) in present tense?
answer: endings: je -is ('ee') + tu -is ('ee') + il/elle/on -it ('ee') + nous -issons ('ee-soh'; nasal and pouty) + vous -issez ('ee-say') + ils/elles -issent ('ees' -ent is ALWAYS silent in verbs but it forces the pronunciation of the previous consonant); NB: Sortir is not a regular -IR verb.

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to finish'.
answer: finir (regular -ir verb): je finis + tu finis + il/elle/on finit + nous finissons + vous finissez + ils/elles finissent ('fi-nees'; The double S changes the sound of the I and -ent is always silent on verbs.)

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to choose'
answer: choisir (regular -ir verb): je choisis + tu choisis + il/elle/on choisit + nous choisissons ('shwa-Zee-Sohn'; The single S makes a Z sound. The double S makes a Z sound because in between vowels.) + vous choisissez ('shwa-See-Say') + ils/elles choisissent; Alternative: OPTER

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to grow up'
answer: grandir (regular -ir verb): je grandis + tu grandis + il/elle/on grandit + nous grandissons + vous grandissez + ils/elles grandissent ('gran-dees'; -ent is silent on verbs); NB: Avoid confusion with GROSSIR which means to put on weight.

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to see'.
answer: voir: je vois ('vwa') + tu vois + il voit + nous voyons + vous voyez + ils voient; NB: ENVOYER is conjugated similar - though not exactly - to VOIR (just add EN in front of them).

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to receive'.
answer: recevoir; past participle: reçu; NB: This is VOIR with a prefix. So the conjugation of RECEVOIR (using radical REÇ) mirrors the conjugation of VOIR (using radical V). Except the nous and vous forms use radical REC (without C cédille). je reçois + tu reçois + il reçoit + nous recevons + vous recevez + ils reçoivent

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to like'.
answer: aimer: j'aime + tu aimes + il/elle/on aime + nous aimons + vous aimez + ile/elles aiment

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to want'.
answer: vouloir de: je veux ('voo' at the top of the mouth - NOT the deep U sound) + tu veux ('voo') + il/elle/on veut ('voo') + nous voulons ('voo-lon') + vous voulez ('voo-lay') + ils/elle veulent ('vuhl'; the -ent is not pronounced in verbs); NB: veux and veut are NOT pronounced 'voo'; VOUS - the subject pronoun - is pronounced 'voo'; VEUX and VEUT are pronounced like something between 'vuh' and 'voo' (same as PEUX) so that it is possible to distinguish them from VOUS; past participle: voulu

question: How do you pronounce... I want + I go + I see?
answer: Je veux ('voo' but higher in the mouth similar to 'vuh') + Je vais ('vay') + Je vois ('vwa')

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to go'.
answer: aller: je vais + tu va + il/elle/on va + nous allons + vous allez +ils/elles vont

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to come'.
answer: venir: je vien ('vyon') + tu viens ('vyon') + il/elle/on vient ('vyon') + nous venons ('vo-non') + vous venez ('ve-nay') + ils/elles viennent ('vyen'; NB: The double N changes the sound of the vowel that precedes the pair. 'vy' becomes 'vyeh'.); ISSUER is an alternative.

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to do' / 'to make' (something).
answer: faire: je fais ('fay') + tu fais ('fay') + il/elle/on fait ('fay') + nous faisons + vous faites + ils/elles font ('fon')

question: to rejuvinate (e.g. a building or face) + rejuvitated
answer: refaire + refait(e)

question: to refresh (e.g. a building or face) + refreshed
answer: rafraîcher + rafraîchi(e)

question: to renovate (a building or face) + renovated
answer: rénover + rénové(e)

question: to complete the tasks (or TODO list)
answer: cocher/remplir/faire les tâches; COCHER = to cross/mark off; REMPLIR = to fill but is often used to mean 'complete'; NB: finir (to finish) could work but it is not the best option.

question: to talk/to speak + to talk about x + to speak to someone
answer: parler + parler DE quelque chose + parler À quelqu'un; PARLER (to speak) is different from DIRE (to say).; Alternative: parler à propos de quelque chose

question: I spoke to James about the film.
answer: Je parle À James DU film.; PARLER + À = to speak to (someone); PARLER + DE = to speak about (something); de + le = du

question: to say (something) / to tell (something - that is not a long story); Conjugate it.
answer: DIRE; je dis + tu dis + il dit + nous disons + vous dites + ils disent; past participle: dit

question: Tell (formal) me when it's over.; Specify pronunciation.
answer: Dites-moi ('deeT-mwa') quand c'est fini.; Dites-moi ('deeT-mwa') is formal impératif (vous). If you do not pronounce the T then it sounds like dis-moi which is informal (tu form).

question: Tell (informal) me what happened.; Specify pronunciation.
answer: Dis-moi ('dee-mwa') ce qui s'est passé.; Dis-moi ('dee-mwa') is informal impératif (tu). If you want to address the person formally (vous) then you must pronounce the T in dites-moi ('deeT-mwa').

question: You were saying. (indicatif imparfait) + You might say. (conditionnel présent)
answer: Tu disais. + Tu dirais.; Infinitive: DIRE. Remember that the radical/base used in future tenses is usually the one that uses an R.

question: I wasn't going to tell you.
answer: Je N'allais (aller in imparfait) PAS te le dire.; le is a pronoun that stands of the thing that is being told (or not told)

question: I said to myself... (a way to express that I was thinking something)
answer: J m'ai dit. Use DIRE reflexively: SE DIRE.

question: I have to tell you about my trip to Milan!
answer: Je dois te parler à propos de mn voyage à Milan.; In this case 'parler à propos d'un sujet' is a better choice than dire (to tell).

question: Where do you see yourself in 5 years? I see myself doing X.
answer: Où vous voyez vous dans 5 ans? Je me vois faire X.; Use VOIR reflexively: SE VOIR.

question: Idiomatic way to say: You sound like X. (e.g. my mother + a politician)
answer: On croirait entendre X.; Use On (not Tu/Vous). This is a way to make a joke / rib someone.

question: to make someone feel a certain way / to make something change
answer: RENDRE; Meanings include: to render + to produce some effect; RENDRE is also used to mean 'to pay' when we express: to pay a visit to someone + to pay hommage to someone; We do not use FAIRE for these scenarios in french.

question: He makes me sick.
answer: Il me rend malade. = He makes me sick.; RENDRE = to produce some effect; Other examples where RENDRE is the correct verb: They make me tired + confused + crazy + nervous.

question: That accent makes/drives me crazy.
answer: Cet accent me rend fou/folle (m/f).; RENDRE = to produce some effect

question: Artists make life better.
answer: Des artistes rendent la vie meilleure.; RENDRE = to produce some effect

question: The sun makes me tired.
answer: There are two ways to express this: 1) Using RENDRE: Le soleil me rend fatigué(e). 2) Using the verb FATIGUER (to fatigue) in a reflexive way: Le soleil me fatigue.

question: We must make the room dark.
answer: On doit pouvoir rendre le salon plus sombre.; RENDRE = to produce some effect

question: I will render my decision.
answer: Je vais RENDRE ma décision.

question: to make something useful
answer: rendre quelque chose util

question: It makes me sad.
answer: Ça me rend triste.; RENDRE = to produce some effect

question: It makes me feel good.
answer: Ça me fait du bien.; This is the idiomatic to express the sentiment. Do not use SENTIR in this case.; Alternative: Ça me rend heureuse.

question: It feels good to be alone.
answer: Ça fait du bien d'être seul(e).; Ça fait du bien de + infinitive = It feels good to...

question: It makes me think.
answer: Ça me fait réfléchir.; Generally RÉFLÉCHIR is not used reflexively. And that is the case here. The pronom ME refers to the verb FAIRE as in 'it makes me... do something'.

question: conjugate 'to take'
answer: prendre is irregular; je prends ('shhhhhpruh') + tu prends ('pruh') + il/elle/on prend ('pruh') + nous prenons ('pruh-non' ...nasal ending)+ vous prenez ('pruh-nay') + ils/els prennent ('prehn'; non-nasal ENN because of the double NN); NB: The double N in prennent changes the sound of the first syllable.; past participle: pris; JE is pronounced slowly as a long 'shhhh' sound. But you must avoid making it a separate syllable. It's not 'shuh-pruh'. It's 'shhhhhpruh'.

question: to make a decision
answer: prendre une décision OR rendre une décision; Use prendre - not faire - in most cases. Rendre une décision is more like announcing the decision.

question: to decide + to decide to do something
answer: décider is the infinitive; past participle: décidé; I decide to do something = Je décide + DE + INFINITIVE VERB. e.g. I decide to try. = Je décide d'essayer.; Generally use DE to connect two verbs (conjugated verb + DE + infinitive verb). In some specific cases we use À instead of DE.

question: You decide to run.
answer: Tu décide DE courir.; Generally use DE to connect two verbs. In some specific cases we use À instead of DE.

question: She told me to wait.
answer: Elle m'a dit D'attendre.; Generally use DE to connect two verbs. In some specific cases we use À instead of DE.

question: I agree to go.
answer: J'accepter DE aller.; accepter = agree to;Generally use DE to connect two verbs. In some specific cases we use À instead of DE.

question: We ask to leave.
answer: On demande DE partir.; Generally use DE to connect two verbs. In some specific cases we use À instead of DE.

question: to order (food)
answer: commander; NB: When you are actually ordering food you use PRENDRE e.g. Je prends des fraises. = I'll take some strawberries. But the verb that describes the action of ordering is COMMANDER - not PRENDRE.

question: to get back on the road
answer: REprendre la route; Use the verb prendre. Emphasize the repetitiveness of the action by adding RE prefix.

question: to keep + to save
answer: garder (to keep) + sauver (to save); Use garder for keeping / storing wine. Use sauver for saving the planet.

question: conjugate 'to be able to'; often used as a helper verb (e.g. I can wait. You can work.)
answer: pouvoir: je peux ('juh pooh') + tu peux ('pooh') + il/elle/on peut ('pooh') + nous pouvons ('pooh-von') + vous pouvez ('pooh-vay') + ils/elles peuvent ('puhv'; the -ent is NOT pronounced in verbs)

question: How can you express being able to do something without using POUVOIR?
answer: Je suis capable DE faire quelque chose.; Je suis capable. is a good alternative to Je peux. ...because the latter is lacking an object so it is not really a complete phrase.

question: conjugate 'to have to' / 'must' (do something)
answer: devoir followed by infinitive of action verb: je dois X ('dwa') + tu dois X ('dwa') + il/elle/on doit X ('dwa') + nous devons X ('duh-von') + vous devez X ('duh-vay') + ils/elles doivent X ('dwav')

question: It's required.
answer: C'est obligatoire.

question: I must read.
answer: Je dois ('dwa') lire.; Use the verb devoir and add the infinitive form of whatever you must do (e.g. lire).

question: I must go to the store.
answer: Je dois aller au magasin.;  Use the verb devoir and add the infinitive form of whatever you must do (e.g. aller).

question: How do you pronounce: They must eat.?
answer: Ils doivent manger. ('eel-dwa-manj-ay'); remember -ent is often dropped when pronouncing the third person plural

question: to need (something)
answer: avoir besoin DE (quelque chose); NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when a thing/object is needed.; If the object is an animate object (a person) then use NÉCESSITER instead.; If the object is an action (you need 'to do' something) then use DEVOIR + INFINITIVE instead.

question: I need the coffee. + You need the table.
answer: J'ai besoin du café (de + le = du). + Tu as besoin de la table.; NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when the object is inanimate.

question: We need a boat. + She needs a dress.
answer: On a besoin d'un bateau. + Elle a besoin d'une robe.; NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when the object is inanimate.

question: He needs privacy. + He would need privacy.
answer: Il a besoin d'intimité. + Il aurait besoin d'intimité. (conditionnel présent)

question: What is the difference between DEVOIR and AVOIR BESOIN DE?
answer: Sometimes they can be used interchangeably but generally DEVOIR preceeds a verb and AVOIR BESOIN precedes a noun.; If you use DEVOIR followed by a noun then it means to owe - not to have to.

question: I owe you a euro.
answer: Je te dois un euro.; If you use DEVOIR followed by a noun then it means to owe - not to have to.

question: He owes money to the government.
answer: Il doit de l'argent au gouvernement.; If you use DEVOIR followed by a noun then it means to owe - not to have to.

question: Which three verbs are only conjugated in the 3rd person singular (il/elle)?
answer: falloir (to be required) + pleuvoir (to rain) + valoir (to be worth)

question: conjugate 'to know' (some information) AND give the past participle.
answer: savoir; past participle: su; conjugation: je sais ('shhhhhhhSay' one syllable) + tu sais + il/elle/on sait + nous nous + vous savons + ils/els savent ('sav')

question: How do you pronounce: They know the answer.
answer: Ils savent ('ee-sahv') la réponse.; In conversation the subject pronouns IL and ILS are shortened to sound like 'ee'.

question: How do you pronounce: He knows the answer.
answer: Il sais ('ee-say') la réponse.; In conversation the subject pronouns IL and ILS are shortened to sound like 'ee'.

question: to know (to be familiar with)
answer: connaître (+ noun); Do not use DE or AVEC. e.g. Elle connaît la ville. (She knows - is familiar with - the city.); connaître can mean to know a someone personally or to know OF that person.

question: I didn't know that.
answer: Je ne le connaissais/savais pas.; Use imparfait because you didn't know it before but now you do know it - something that was true in the past but is different now and it describes the context (not a discreet action)

question: If I didn't already know Frida...
answer: Si je ne connaissais pas déjà Frida...; Both PAS and DÉJÀ are necessary adverbs.; Use imparfait because you are describing the context (not a discreet action).; NB: When you use CONNAÎTRE to describe knowing a person it means that you actually knew the person (not just knowing 'of them'). To be more clear you should say: Si je ne connaissais pas déjà l'art de Frida...

question: I haven't seen/heard of that (before).
answer: Je n'ai jamais entendu parler de ça.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.; In this case passé composé is the best choic in french. Though in English we use plus que parfait (had seen/heard).; The 'before/already' is implied in french. We do not need to add 'déja' for this specific expression.

question: I haven't seen her in a long time. + I hadn't seen her in a long time (e.g. before we met last night).
answer: Je l'ai pas vu longtemps. (passé composé) + Je ne l'avais pas vu longtemps. (plus que parfait)

question: I studied at this school before.
answer: J'ai déja étudié à cette école avant.; Use DÉJA to express 'already'. It modifies the verb so it is placed between the auxiliary and the past participle in passé composé.

question: I went to the store already. + I already went there.
answer: Je suis déjà allé(e) au magasin. + J'y suis déja allé(e).; Passé composé is a good choice in this case because the statement is straightforward in the past. The speaker is not using past perfect (had been). Perfect means 'completed' when dealing with verb tenses.; Déja should fall between the two parts of the verb in both cases in french.; Déja is the word to use for a direct translation of 'already' or for when we use the word before to mean already. e.g. I went to the store (before).

question: I have seen it before. / I have already seen it.
answer: Je l'ai déja vu.; In this case always use passé composé and déja (the adverb) is placed between the auxiliary and past participle.

question: Were you (informal) in the Netherlands? + Were you there?
answer: Est-ce que tu as été aux Pays-Bas ('pay-ee-bah')? + Est-ce que tu Y as été?; Use pronom Y to reference a location.; Passé composé is a good choice in this case because the question is straightforward in the past. The speaker is not using past perfect (had been).

question: Were you (informal) in the Netherlands before/already? + Were you there before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu as DÉJA été aux Pays-Bas? + Est-ce que tu Y as DÉJA été?; Déja always lies between the two parts of the verb.; Déja is the word to use for 'already' or for 'before' in situations where it can be replaced with 'already'.

question: Have you gone/been to Germany before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu étais DÉJA allé(e) en Allemagne ('ah-lu-mehGN'; pronounced very differently from the language and the people)?; In this case ALLER and plus que parfait are the best choices in french.; Déja is the word to use for 'already' or for 'before' in situations where it can be replaced with 'already'. Déja always lies between the two parts of the verb.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: Have you gone/been there before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu Y étais DÉJA allé(e)?; Use pronom Y to reference a location.

question: Did you go there?
answer: Two options: 1) Est-ce que tu y est allé(e)? 2) Y est-tu allé(e)?
