answer: fondre + fondant(e)

question: to fry + to grill
answer: faire frire + faire griller

question: to sautee (food in a pan)
answer: faire sauter ('soh-tay'; au like bateau); SAUTER = to jump

question: to make bread/pizza
answer: faire du pain/pizza; Do not use cuisiner or preparer in this case.

question: to serve; Conjugate it.
answer: (se) SERVIR DE qqn/qqch; This verb is irregular.; je sers ('sehr') + tu sers ('sehr') + il sert ('sehr') + nous servons ('sehr-von') + vous servez ('sehr-vay') + ils servent ('sehrv')

question: to digest
answer: digérer

question: expression that means: I need to time to absorb the information.
answer: Two options: 1) neutral (could be good or bad news): J'ai pris le temps d'assimiler les informations.; 2) negative connotation (connotes that the information is problematic): J'ai besoin de temps pour digérer les (mauvaises) nouvelles.

question: to collect/assemble data (so that a machine can work on it)
answer: recueillir une info; Use réunir for gathering people. Use recueillir for collecting / gathering things.

question: to gather people together
answer: réunir; Use réunir for gathering people. Use recueillir for collecting / gathering things.

question: to bring + to bring back (an inanimate object)
answer: apporter + rapporter; RAPPORTER also means to reap (e.g. rewards and benefits); à rapporter chez soi = to bring home. This can be used figuratively to mean a 'takeaway'

question: to bring + to bring back (a person or animal or vehicle)
answer: amener + ramener; Use EMMENER when you mean 'to bring' a person along (e.g. to an event)

question: I bring my passport to the airport. + I bring you to the airport.
answer: J'AMÈNE mon passeport à l'aéroport. + Je T'EMMÈNE à l'aéroport.; Use AMENER to bring a thing. Use EMMENER to bring a person.

question: He brought me back. + He drove me back (to where we departed from).
answer: Il m'a ramené. + Il m'a reconduit.; amener = to bring; (r)amener = to bring (back); (re)conduire = to drive (back)

question: I brought some water. + I got some water.
answer: J'ai apporté de l'eau. + J'ai cherché de l'eau.; In English we use 'to get' in many scenarios. In this case it does not translate directly. And apporter (to bring) is not exactly what we mean in the second phrase.

question: to wear; I am wearing a red scarf.
answer: porter; Je porte une écharpe rouge.; NB: PORTER can mean to wear or to carry.

question: You are carrying the baggage/luggage.
answer: Tu portes les bagages.; les bagages (plural) is equivalent of luggage.

question: conjugate the verb 'to put on'
answer: mettre; je mets ('may') + tu mets ('may') + il met ('may') + nous mettons ('muh-ton') + vous ('muh-tay') + ils mettent ('met')

question: I am putting on a dark green sweater.
answer: Je mets ('may') un pull vert foncé.

question: to set the table
answer: mettre la table; to ask how many places to set: Combien de couverts? (literally: covers)

question: to put in + to take out (like hot pot)
answer: mettre + enlever; e.g. Tu mets et tu enleves. = You put stuff in and you take stuff out.

question: What is the difference between METTRE + SE METTRE + S'Y METTRE?
answer: METTRE: to place (a thing somewhere); SE METTRE: to place oneself (somewhere) or to put something on (like clothes); S'Y METTRE: to get on (with something); e.g. On peut s'y mettre. = We can get on with it. (e.g. preparing a meal); The pronom Y in s'y mettre is not a specific reference to a place. It just changes the meaning of the phrase.

question: idiomatic way to say: I have nothing to wear.
answer: Je n'ai rien à mettre.

question: idiomatic way to say: I want to get things in order / change my life.
answer: Je voudrais mettre de l'ordre dans ses affaires; literally: to put their affaires in order

question: What is the difference between CONTINUER and LAISSER?
answer: CONTINUER: to actively carry on doing something; LAISSER: to leave something behind or to let something go / let something continue on its own (more passive)

question: conjugate the verb 'to leave' (something behind)
answer: laisser ('le-say') - S sound because double s; je laisse ('les') + tu laisses + il laisse + nous Laissons + vous laissez ('le-say')+ ils laissent ('les')

question: (you formal) Continue cooking the meat.
answer: Laissez la viande.; Use the verb LAISSER which means to leave (it cooking).

question: I left for Paris to study.
answer: Je suis parti à Paris pour ètudier.; Use à to indicate where you left to; Use de to indicate whree you left from; suis parti is passé composé

question: to go out (at night) + to go out to (a bar)
answer: sortir (le soir/la nuit) + sortir DANS (un bar); Use SORTIR + DANS instead of Á when using the verb SORTIR.

question: to hang out with friends
answer: sortir avec des amis; Où est-ce que vous sortiez ? = Where did you hang out (as a kid)?

question: We should go out for dinner. + We should go out for a coffee.
answer: On devrait sortir DÎNER. + On devrait sortir PRENDRE un café.; SORTIR + INFINITIVE when you mean to go out in order to do something.

question: We should go out for a walk. + We should go out to a concert.
answer: On devrait sortir FAIRE une balade. + On devrait sortir un concert.

question: water comes out of the mouth
answer: l'eau sort DE la bouche; Use the verb SORTIR + DE when you mean 'going out of something'.

question: lots of water coming out
answer: beaucoup d'eau en sort (from SORTIR); Beaucoup/énormément de X is treated as a plural noun.

question: There is a leak coming from the neighbor above.
answer: Il y a une fuite VENANT du voisin du dessus.; Use the présent participe form of VENIR.

question: to water (a plant)
answer: arroser; This can also be used to describe covering a person or thing in water (dousing).

question: He jumped out of the building.
answer: Il a sauté du bâtiment.; In this case do not use SORTIR.

question: to party / to celebate; We partied.
answer: fêter; On a fêté.; NB: Sometimes fêtes refer to holidays but not in all cases.; Alternative: CÉLÉBRER = to celebrate and can be used in French as it is in English.

question: to throw a party
answer: faire DE la fête (larger party) / la soirée (smaller party); NB: teuf is a common verlan of fête.; You can communicate the difference between a large public party (une fête) and a smaller party at someone's home (une fête familiale / entre amis).

question: to have a housewarming party
answer: faire la pendaison de crémaillère; une crémaillère = a housewarming party

question: plans for the evening
answer: le programme de la soirée

question: Do you have plans?
answer: Est-ce que tu as des plans?

question: to dream (of something) + a dream
answer: rêver (DE qqch) + un rêve

question: a nightmare
answer: un cauchemar ('koh-shmahr')

question: to ski
answer: skier

question: to see a band
answer: voir un groupe de musique

question: to see eachother
answer: se voir; Make the verb VOIR reflexive.

question: to pack + unpack (when moving to a new place)
answer: faire les cartons + défaire les cartons; There is no analgous verb in french.; An alternative for unpacking: être dans les cartons (e.g. On et dans les cartons.)

question: to pack (for a vacation) + to unpack (clothes after a vacation)
answer: faire les valises + sortir les vêtements d'une valise.; There is no analagous verb for 'to pack/unpack'.

question: I packed (for holidays).
answer: J'ai fait MES valises / mes bagages.

question: to be called something + to call out
answer: se appeler + appeler; The first is reflexive so there will always be an additional word to indicate who is the object of the verb.; The second means to call to someone or call someone on the telephone - is not reflexive - just a normal ER verb.

question: conjugate 'to be called'
answer: It's reflexive: se appeler; remember that an extra 'L' is added in some of the forms; je m'appelle ('juh-ma-pel') + tu t'appelles ('too-ta-pel') + il/elle/on s'appelle ('el-sah-pel') + nous nous appelons ('nu-nu-zapluh') + vous vous appelez ('vu-vu-zah-play')+ ils/elles s'appellent ('el-sah-pel'); NB: Use s' when working with ON because same conjugation as il/elle.; NB: Only the nous and vous forms have a single L and have a different pronunciation.; NB: There are apostrophes when the pronoun (e.g. me/te/se) ends in a vowel because the verb starts with a vowel and we cannot have two vowels next to eachother.

question: Your name is X.
answer: Tu t'appelles X.; uses the reflexive form of the verb: se appeler

question: I call you X.
answer: Je t'appelle X.; uses the reflexive form of the verb: se appeler

question: Sophie calls her dog Charlie. (meaning that she named her dog Charlie)
answer: Sophie appelle son chien Charlie.; Use the verb appeller in its non-reflexive form to indicate that you are naming something.

question: I call Marc (on the telephone).
answer: J'appelle Marc.; Use the NON-reflexive form of the verb (appeler) to indicate that you are calling out to someone in the moment.

question: reflexive verbs
answer: verbes pronominaux; because a pronoun is part of the verb

question: What is the name for the pronoun used in reflexive verbs (e.g. me)
answer: le pronom réfléchi

question: What must be true if you see the word 'se' written in french?
answer: This is only written when using a reflexive verb. You know that whatever word follows 'se' is a reflexive verb.

question: to sit down; Give the participe passé.
answer: s'asseoir ('sa-swar') is a reflexive verb.; past participle: s'assis(e)(es) Reflexive verbs use être in passé composé and the past participle must agree with the subject.; NB: If you mean to have a figurative seat (e.g. the seat on a board or a 'seat' at the table) then use the verb SIÉGER.

question: I sit down.
answer: Je m'assois ('mah-swa').; Generally this verb (s'asseoir) is reflexive because you need to specify what is being sat down.

question: I am sitting.
answer: Je suis assis(e).; s'asseoir is the verb. assis(e) is the adjective.

question: She sits down. + She is seated.
answer: Elle s'assoit. + Elle est assis(e).; You can only use SE ASSEOIR in the present tense when the action is actually happening. If someone is seated (the action already happened) then use the adjective: assis(e).

question: She sat down. + He sat down.
answer: ; Elle s'est assise. + Il s'est assiss.; s'asseoir is reflexive so it requires the pronoun (se) and uses être in passé composé. AND the past participle must agree with the subject.; We are describing a discrete action here (potentially a conclusion to a story). So we use passé composé instead of imparfait.

question: I was sitting. + They were sitting.
answer: J'assoyais. + Ils assoient.; In this case we are describing a setting in the past using imparfait. The sitting down action was already completed so we are not describing an action. Therefore we do not need to use the reflexive form.

question: We were already seated.
answer: On était assis.; Use plus que parfait to describe a past event that occurred before some other past event.

question: to physically get lower
answer: se baisser ('bay-Say'); baisser (not reflexive) = to reduce or turn down (something); Make sure to pronounce baisser with an S sound. If you use a Z sound then it sounds like baiser ('bay-Zay') = to fuck.; Using the reflexive form of a French verb is often is how we translate English verbs where we use 'to get'.

question: to be standing
answer: être debout; Pay attention to the pronunciation. Debout ('duh-boo'; means upright) is very different from début ('day-bewww'; means at the beginning).

question: to stand up
answer: SE LEVER = to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed). Using the reflexive form of a French verb is often is how we translate English verbs where we use 'to get'.; Use ÉLEVER for raising something (like your arms over your head).

question: Conjugate and specify the pronunciation of the verb that means 'to get up'.
answer: SE LEVER = to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed).; je me lève ('shmuh-luhv') + tu te lèves ('too-tuh-luhv') + il se lève ('eel-suh-luhv') + nous nous lèvons ('noo-noo-luh-von') + vous vous lèvez ('voo-voo-luh-vay') + ils se lèvent ('eel-suh-luhv'); Je me contracts to 'shmuh'.

question: to stand up straight
answer: se tenir droit(e); This verb is more specific than SE LEVER which is to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed).

question: I stand up. + I am standing.
answer: Je me lève. + Je suis debout.; SE LEVER = to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed). DEBOUT (same m/f) is the adjective for being upright.

question: He stood up. + He was standing.
answer: Il s'est levé. + Il était debout.; SE LEVER = to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed). DEBOUT (same m/f) is the adjective for being upright.

question: They were standing.
answer: Ils étaient debout.; SE LEVER = to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed). DEBOUT (same m/f) is the adjective for being upright.

question: She gets up in the morning.
answer: Elle se lèves ('lev') le matin.; NB: Do not use a preposition to say 'in the morning' or 'in the evening' etc. Simply: le matin + le soir + etc

question: How do you pronounce: je me lève?
answer: The words run together and often E gets dropped: 'shmuh-luhv' OR 'shmuh-mluhv'; It can even be written as: J'me lève.

question: to wake up (different than getting up after sleeping)
answer: se réveiller = to wake up from sleep (when the eyes open); se lever = to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed)

question: I woke up early. + I got up (from bed) early.
answer: Je me réveille tôt. + Je me lève tôt.; Use tôt (early) in this case - instead of en avance (ahead of schedule).; se réveiller = to wake up from sleep (when the eyes open); se lever = to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed)

question: Did you just wake up?
answer: Est-ce que tu viens de te réviller?; Use passé recent. SE RÉVEILLER is reflexive.

question: I woke up at 6am.
answer: Je me suis réveillé(e) à 6h.; Je me contracts to 'shmuh'.; se réveiller = to wake up from sleep (when the eyes open); se lever = to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed)

question: What time did you wake up?
answer: A quelle heure tu t'es réveillée?; NB: In this case t'es is a required contraction of the pronoun TE and the verb EST. But in conversation it is not uncommon for the french to contract the subject TU and the verb EST. e.g. T'es en avance. = You're ahead of schedule. Do not use this contraction in formal communication but you will hear it orally and see it in informal communication.

question: What is the difference between lever and se lever?
answer: lever = to raise or lift someone/something; se lever = to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed); Using the reflexive form of a French verb is often is how we translate English verbs where we use 'to get'.

question: What is the difference between se lever and se relever?
answer: se lever = to stand up / get up (from some lower position like a chair or bed); se relever = to get up again (only after falling down); Using the reflexive form of a French verb is often is how we translate English verbs where we use 'to get'.

question: What is the difference between réveiller and se réveiller?
answer: réveiller = to wake up someone/something; se réveiller = to wake up (yourself)

question: to dress someone/something + to get dressed
answer: habiller + s'habiller (H is silent); s'habiller bien = to be dressed well; Using the reflexive form of a French verb is often is how we translate English verbs where we use 'to get'.

question: to get undressed
answer: se déshabiller (reflexive verb) OR dévêtir (from vêtements)

question: to dress up in costume
answer: se déguiser

question: She dressed well. + She did not dress well.
answer: Elle s'est BIEN habillée. + Elle NE s'est PAS BIEN habillée.; BIEN (and any adverbs) are placed in between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé - along with PAS.

question: idiomatic way to say: to get dressed up / dressed to the 9's
answer: SE METTRE sur son 31; e.g. Je me suis mis (conjugated METTRE) sur mon 31.; Alternative: s'habiller bien

question: The hat goes with the outfit.
answer: Le chapeau va avec la tenue.; Use ALLER (to go) just as we do in English to express things that 'go with eachother'.

question: naked
answer: nu(e); NB: en robe = to be covered completely

question: to put on makeup + to take off makeup
answer: se maquiller + se démaquiller; makeup = le maquillage

question: When I was in middle school I woke up early + showered + did my makeup and hair.
answer: Quand j'étais AU collège je me réveillais tôt + je me douchais + je me maquillais + je me coiffais.; Use imparfait to talk about a daily routine in the past. In almost every case imparfait sounds exactly like the infinitive: 'ay' + 'ay' + 'ay'... So try not to overthink it.

question: When I was in high school I shaved my legs + drove to school.
answer: Quand j'étais AU lycée je me rasais les jambes + j'allais à l'école EN voiture.; Do not use conduire in this case because you are not talking about one trip by car - you are talking about a daily routine in the past. So use imparfait of ALLER.

question: the sleep
answer: le sommeil

question: the nap
answer: la sieste; Do not add an A on the end. That is spanish: siesta.

question: Conjugate 'to sleep'.
answer: DORMIR is not a regular 2nd group/-IR verb. Nous dormONS. - not Nous dormissons. je dors + tu dors + il dort + nous dormons + vous dormez + dorment; The past participle of dormir is dormi. It uses avoir in passé composé.

question: What is the difference between dormir and se dormir?
answer: SE DORMIR does not exist!; dormir = to sleep; s'endormir = to fall asleep

question: What is the difference between endormir and s'endormir?
answer: endormir = to lull or to numb (to put to sleep)  s'endormir = to fall asleep

question: to be sleepy + to be asleep
answer: AVOIR sommeil + ÊTRE endormi

question: I slept well last night.
answer: Je passe une bonne nuit.; When we use PASSER (to mean spending time) we must use the feminine duration period (e.g. une année instead of un an)

question: to sleep in + I slept in.
answer: faire une grasse matinée + J'ai fait une grasse matinée.; Grasse does not have a direct translation - it is just part of this phrase that means to sleep in.

question: I did not get enough sleep. + I slept less. / I got less sleep.
answer: Je n'ai pas assez dormir. + J'ai dormi moins.

question: I get less sleep when other people stay at our place.
answer: J'ai moins DE sommeil quand d'autres personnes restent chez nous.; Use the noun for sleep in this case (le sommeil) with the verb AVOIR - instead of the verb (dormir).; NB: If you omit the DE then the meaning is very different. e.g. J'ai moins sommeil. = I need less sleep.

question: idiomatic ways to express: I did not sleep.
answer: J'ai fait une insomme. OR J'ai fait une nuit blanche.

question: idiomatic way to express going to sleep (like a child)
answer: dodo

question: idiomatic saying that means all I do is work and sleep - no fun
answer: C'est métro boulot dodo.

question: to curl up (like a cat)
answer: se blottir

question: to go to bed
answer: se coucher (reflexive verb); pronounced 'koo-shay'

question: I go to bed. + I fall asleep.
answer: Je me couche ('koosh'). + Je m'endors.; se coucher = to go to bed / to lie down; s'endormir = to go to sleep

question: I went to bed very late.
answer: Je me suis couché très tard.; Reflexive verbs use être in passé composé.

question: I stayed awake.
answer: Je suis resté éveillé(e).; éveillé(e) = awake. RESTER uses être in passé composé.

question: I stayed up (later into the night).
answer: Je suis restée debout.; Debout (same m/f) = standing/upright; e.g. She stands. = Elle est debout. OR Elle reste debout.; Alternative: éveillé(e) = awake

question: I want to sleep on the train and wake up in Berlin.
answer: Je voudrais dormir DANS le train (not sur) et me lever à Berlin.; dans le train / la voiture / le bus = in the train etc. If you use SUR then you mean that you are literally on the roof of those vehicles.

question: to wash something + to wash oneself
answer: laver + se laver; Alternative: (se) rincer

question: I washed the dog. + I washed my hands.
answer: J'ai lavé le chien. + J'ai me lavé LES mains.; NB: When you use a verb reflexively (se laver) then the object of the action should NOT be personalized (LES mains - not mes mains).

question: to take a shower
answer: se doucher (reflexive) OR prendre une douche

question: I do not take a shower.
answer: Je NE me douche PAS.;NB: For reflexive verbs the NE comes before both the verb and the associated pronoun. Like non-reflexive verbs the PAS comes after the verb when using a reflexive verb.

question: to shave
answer: se raser; the S sounds like a Z because between to vowels

question: to brush (hair or teeth)
answer: se brosser; NB: When you use a verb reflexively then the object should NOT be personalized. e.g. I brush my hair. = Je me brosse les cheveux. - not mes cheveux.; le brossage = the brushing

question: the toothpaste
answer: le dentifrice

question: the toothbrush
answer: la brosse à dents

question: the hairbrush
answer: la brosse á cheveux ('sheh-vooh'); EUX makes an 'oo' sound; The word for horse is chevaux which is 'sheh-voh'.

question: the hairdryer
answer: le sèche-cheveux ('sheh-vooh') OR le séchoir à cheveux

question: the curling iron
answer: le fer à friser

question: the shampoo + the conditioner; Specify pronunciation.
answer: le shampooing ('sham-pwa') + l'après-shampooing ('sham-pwa'); Never a 'wong' sound.

question: to find
answer: Two verbs are possible. They both work for people and things. 1) TROUVER when you find something that you didn't have or didn't know beforehand. e.g. when you find a bar you never knew about before 2) RETROUVER when you find something (or meet someone) that you lost or knew a long time ago. e.g. to find your keys that you had lost e.g. to see a friend that you have not seen in a very long time

question: I found a new teacher. I found a house.
answer: Use TROUVER without a reflexive pronoun: J'ai trouvé un nouveau professeur. + J'ai trouvé une maison.; NB: If you already knew the thing that you found (e.g. to find keys after losing them) then you must use RETROUVER instead of TROUVER. Trouver is only for people and things that you find for the first time.

question: I find myself in a new world. + I find myself funny.
answer: Use TROUVER reflexively: Je ME trouve dans un nouveau monde. + Je ME trouve drôle.; NB: If you mean that you found yourself after being lost then you must use RETROUVER instead of TROUVER.

question: Where does one find X? + Here you find X.
answer: On y trouve X? + On y trouve X.; These are common ways to talk about the location of things ('here we find X')

question: I find that the project is interesting. + I find the project interesting.
answer: Je trouve QUE le projet est intéressant. + Je trouve le projet intéressant.; These two structures are exactly the same in english and french: 1) TROUVER QUE + entire phrase 2) TROUVER + noun or adjective

question: I find that the position/post is fascinating. + I find the position fascinating.
answer: Je trouve QUE le poste est fascinant. + Je trouve le poste fascinant.; NB: passionnant = fascinating  passionné(e) = keen

question: to obligate / force
answer: obliger ('oh-blee-zshay'); Do not confuse oublier (to forget) with obliger (to obligate).

question: I force you (familiar) to do your homework.
answer: Je t'oblige à faire tes devoir.; Literally: I obligate you (to do something).

question: to insist on (doing something)
answer: insister POUR (faire quelque chose)

question: What are the four possible meanings/uses of the verb MANQUER?
answer: 1) MANQUER + Direct Object = to fail to be at/in/on something (the direct object); 2) MANQUER + DE + Direct Object = to lack something (the direct object); 3) MANQUER + DE + Verb = to fail to do something (the verb); 4) MANQUER + À + Indirect Object = to be missed emotionally by someone or something (the indirect object)

question: to miss (emotionally) something
answer: This cannot be translated directly because the subject and object are often inverted (comparing French and English) to express lacking/missing.; MANQUER + À + indirect object = to be missed (emotionally) by someone/something (the indirect object)

question: to be missed (emotionally) by someone/something
answer: MANQUER + À + indirect object; The subject and object are inverted (comparing French and English). e.g. My mother misses my brother. becomes... My brother is missed by my mother... = Mon frère manque À ma mère.

question: The dog misses (emotionally) the cat.
answer: Le chat manque au (À + le) chien.; The subject/object are inverted (comparing English and French). So the phrase must be transformed to: The cat is missed by (MANQUER + À) the dog.

question: I miss you.
answer: Tu ME manques.; The subject/object are inverted (comparing English and French). So the phrase must be transformed: You are missed by (MANQUER + À) me. The last word is an indirect object in this structure so we must use the COI pronom (me) and place it before the verb.

question: He misses his parents.
answer: Ses parents LUI manquent.; The subject/object are inverted (comparing English and French). So the phrase must be transformed: His parents are missed by (MANQUER + À) him. The last word is an indirect object in this structure so we must use the COI pronom (lui) and place it before the verb.

question: She misses California. + He misses California.
answer: La Californie LUI manque.; The subject/object are inverted (comparing English and French). So the phrase must be transformed: California is missed by (MANQUER + À) her/him. The last word is an indirect object in this structure so use the COI pronom (lui) in both cases and place it before the verb.

question: I miss X Y and Z.
answer: X Y et Z... Ils me manque.; The subject/object are inverted (comparing English and French). So the phrase must be transformed: X Y and Z are missed by (MANQUER + À) me. The last word is an indirect object in this structure so we must use the COI pronom (me).; You could say: X Y et Z me manque. But adding the duplicaative pronoun (ils) is more correct.

question: Do you miss home?
answer: Est-ce que ta maison te manque?; The subject/object are inverted (comparing English and French). So the phrase must be transformed: Is your home missed by (MANQUER + À) you? The last word is an indirect object in this structure so we must use the COI pronom (te) and place it before the verb.

question: Don't you miss Paris?
answer: Est-ce que Paris ne te manque pas?; The subject/object are inverted (comparing English and French). So the phrase must be transformed: Is Paris not missed by (MANQUER + À) you? The last word is an indirect object in this structure so we must use the COI pronom (te) and place it before the verb.; idiomatic alternative: Ça ne te manque pas à Paris?

question: to do without something
answer: se passer DE quelque chose; SE PASSER generally means to occur / to happen / to go (well or poorly). If you add DE before the object then you are saying 'to go without'.

question: the lack of something
answer: le manque DE quelque chose

question: to lack something
answer: manquer DE quelque chose; MANQUER + DE + Direct Object = to lack something in general (the direct object); NB: The general use case includes generic preposition DE because we typically mean a lack of something in general (like the lack of salt). If the direct object is specified (like a specific container of salt - instead of a general concept) then omit the generic DE.; Watch out because MANQUER + OBJECT (without DE) can also mean to fail be at/in/on something (e.g. like missing a train)

question: The soup lacks salt.
answer: La soupe manque DE sel.; MANQUER + DE + Direct Object = to lack something in general (the direct object); NB: The general use case includes generic preposition DE because we typically mean a lack of something in general. If the direct object is specified (like a specific container of salt - instead of a general concept) then omit the generic DE.; Watch out because MANQUER + OBJECT (without DE) can also mean to fail be at/in/on something (e.g. like missing a train)

question: I am missing documents. (e.g. in a dossier)
answer: Je manque DE documents; MANQUER + DE + Direct Object = to lack something in general (the direct object); NB: The general use case includes generic preposition DE because we typically mean a lack of something in general. If the direct object is specified (like a specific container of salt - instead of a general concept) then omit the generic DE.; Watch out because MANQUER + OBJECT (without DE) can also mean to fail be at/in/on something (e.g. like missing a train)

question: It lacks substance.
answer: Ça manque DE substance.; MANQUER + DE + Direct Object = to lack something in general (the direct object); Use the generic DE here because it lacks substance in general (not a specified object).

question: I'm running out of time.
answer: Je manque DE temps.; MANQUER + DE + Direct Object = to lack something in general (the direct object); Use the generic DE here because time is a general concept instead of a specified object.

question: There is a page missing from this book.
answer: Il manque une page dans ce livre.; MANQUER + DE + Direct Object = to lack something in general (the direct object) BUT in this case the direct object is specified (not a general concept). So we omit the generic DE from the pattern.

question: We're only missing/lacking a desert in France.
answer: Le France nous manque QU'un désert.; QUE is used or emphasis in this case - to indicate that it is missing ONLY a desert (nothing else).; In French the subject and object are often inverted (compared to English) when we express lacking/missing.; MANQUER + DE + Direct Object = to lack something in general (the direct object) BUT in this case the direct object is specified (a desert or the desert - not desert in general). So we omit the generic DE from the pattern.

question: to fail to be at/in/on something (e.g. to miss a meeting)
answer: manquer quelque chose (direct object); Do not use the generic preposition DE for this meaning. If we add DE then the meaning of MANQUER would change to 'to lack something'. e.g. Le repas manque DE saveur. = The meal lacks flavor.

question: You’re going to miss the train!
answer: Tu vas manquer le train !; MANQUER + Direct Object = to fail be at/in/on something (the direct object); If we added preposition DE then the meaning of MANQUER would change to 'to lack something'.

question: I missed the first meeting.
answer: J’ai manqué la première réunion.; MANQUER + Direct Object = to fail be at/in/on something (the direct object); If we added preposition DE then the meaning of MANQUER would change to 'to lack something'.

question: I missed the flight.
answer: J'ai manqué le vol.; MANQUER + Direct Object = to fail be at/in/on something (the direct object); If we added preposition DE then the meaning of MANQUER would change to 'to lack something'.; Informal alternatives: J'ai raté le vol. or J’ai loupé le vol. (LOUPER is very informal.)

question: informal to way to express: I missed my bus.
answer: J’ai loupé mon bus.; LOUPER is a less formal version of MANQUER (or RATER). LOUPER is commonly used in speaking but do not use it in writing.

question: informal way to express: She missed an opportunity.
answer: Elle a loupé une opportunité.; LOUPER is a less formal version of MANQUER (or RATER). LOUPER is commonly used in speaking but do not use it in writing.

question: You didn't miss anything.
answer: Tu n’as rien manqué.

question: idiomatic way to express: They missed the point.
answer: Ils passaient (imparfait) à côté de l'essentiel (or l'objectif).

question: to fail to do something
answer: manquer DE faire quelque chose; MANQUER + DE + Verb = to fail to do something (the verb) OR to miss some action/activity (must be represented by a verb); The negated form is more common: ne manquer pas de + verb = to be sure to / to not fail to do something

question: She failed to attend the meeting.
answer: Elle a manqué DE assister la réunion.; MANQUER + DE + Verb = to fail to do something (the verb)

question: He failed to go to the appointment.
answer: Il a manqué D'aller au RDV (rendez-vous).; MANQUER + DE + Verb = to fail to do something (the verb)

question: Be sure to thank them.
answer: Ne manquez pas DE les remercier.; 'to be sure to do something' is expressed by negating the following pattern: MANQUER + DE + Verb (= to fail to do something)

question: Be sure to visit the museum.
answer: Ne manquez pas DE visiter le musée.; 'to be sure to do something' is expressed by negating the following pattern: MANQUER + DE + Verb (= to fail to do something)

question: to regret
answer: regretter; Watch out because this can be a faux ami. REGRETTER has two meanings in French: 1) regretter DE X: to regret X   2) regretter X: to miss X.

question: I regret the mistake. + I miss France.
answer: Je regrette DE la faut. + Je regrette la France.; REGRETTER changes meaning when you remove the DE preposition.; Je regrette. = I'm sorry.

question: a regret; Specify pronunciation.
answer: un regret (T is silent); un remords (D and S are silent) = a deep regret for which you feel guilty/remorseful

question: to lose
answer: perdre; past participle: perdu; This works for losing a war (perdre une guerre) but it does not work for other types of loss. e.g. to lose weight = maigrir

question: a loss
answer: une perte; e.g. une perte de concentration = a loss of concentration; la perte des cheveux = the loss of hair

question: to forget / overlook; conjugate and give pronunciation
answer: oublier ('oh-blee-yay'): j'oublie ('zshoh-blee') + tu oublies ('toh-blee') + il oublie ('ee-loh-blee') + nous oublions ('noo-zoh-blee-on') + vous oubliez ('voo-zoh-blee-ay')+ ils oublient ('eel-zoo-blee'); Do not confuse oublier (to forget) with obliger (to obligate).

question: I will write it in order not to forget it.
answer: Je vais l'écrire pour ne pas l'oublier.

question: to take (an exam) + to retake (an exam)
answer: passer (does not mean 'to pass an exam' - just to take the exam) + repasser (to take it again)

question: to pass (an exam) + to fail (an exam)
answer: réussir + rater/echouer; Réussir literally means 'to succeed' but it is the correct verb to use for passing an exam.; Rater means to fail an exam but it is not the general verb for failing (échouer).

question: to fail
answer: It depends on context: 1) To lose a game or fail a class/exam in school: ÉCHOUER. RATER is specifically used for failing an exam. 2) When you fail to meet an obligation or do not have enough money to pay: MANQUER + DE + VERB.; échouer = to fail; échapper = to escape

question: a failure
answer: It depends on context: 1) un échec: to lose a game or fail a class in school.; 2) une défaillance: specifically for cases where there is a failure of will / a failure to live up to responsibilities. It can also be used to mean a failure of muscles (when they are fatigued).; défaillance is close to the english word 'default' but défaillance cannot be used as a verb.

question: a distrust / suspicion
answer: une méfiance OR une défiance; These are the french equivalents of mistrust and distrust (whose meanings are really similar in both English and French).; NB: This is different than une défaillance which means a failure of will or a structural failure.

question: He defaults on the debt.
answer: Il fait défaut sur la dette.; faire défaut = to fail / to default

question: to go bankrupt
answer: faire faillite

question: a loophole
answer: une faille dans le système is the best contextual translation.; une échappatoire is similar but I think it refers more to the action of escaping or evading in a clever way.

question: to escape
answer: s'échapper or s'évader

question: an escape
answer: une évasion; Take care to differentiate from une invasion (= an invasion)

question: an invasion + to invade
answer: une invasion + envahir

question: to avoid + to ignore
answer: éviter + s'ignorer (reflexive); Take care because IGNORER (non reflexive) simply means to be ignorant of something. S'IGNORER means to actively ignore something.

question: to jump
answer: sauter ('soh-tay' - au like bateau); to sautee food = faire sauter; SAUTER can also mean to skip something.; a jump/leap = un saut

question: to skip (e.g. a class)
answer: passer or sauter; SAUTER = to jump or skip over something (e.g. to jump a line)

question: to cheat
answer: tricher

question: My grades are bad.
answer: Mes notes sont mauvaises.; une note = a grade on an exam

question: I want to get better grades.
answer: Je voudrais obtenir de meilleures notes.; une note = a grade on an exam

question: They did not succeed (in anything - not necessarily an exam).
answer: Ils n'ont pas réussi.; NB: Be careful when saying someone succeeded in the past tense. Without context this may mean to succeed sexually. Unfortunately it applies more strongly when you are describing the actions of woman vs the actions of a man.

question: I succeeded in answering (the questions).
answer: J'ai réussi À répondre.; RÉUSSIR triggers the preposition À.; NB: Because there is an accent aigu on the É there are two vowel sounds ('ray-oo-seer'). If there were no accent (reussir) then EU together would make a single vowel sound.

question: success
answer: succés ('sook-say')

question: She is successful.
answer: Elle a beaucoup de succés dans ses affaires.; This is a better way to express that someone succeeded at some effort (other than passing an exam). ...instead of using RÉUSSIR.

question: the strength (physical)
answer: la force; NB: forcément is a common expression and it is a faux ami. It means something like 'for sure' or 'certainly' or 'with strong probability'. It does not mean 'with lots of force'.

question: strong + weak
answer: fort(e) + faible; NB: faible can mean a small(er) amount in French. It does not always literally mean weak.; affaibli(e) = weakened

question: a strength (of character/skill) + a weakness
answer: une force + une faiblesse; Alternatives: un point fort + un point faible

question: a characteristic + an aspect
answer: une caractéristique OR un attribut (= an attribute) + un aspect ('ahs-pay'; CT is completly silent); un attribut physique = a physical attribute

question: to meet up (with someone you already know)
answer: Two options: 1) (SE) VOIR is the most common. Use this for most cases. e.g. I will see my friend tonight. = Je vais voir mon ami ce soir.; 2) (SE) RETROUVER; retrouver is literally 'to regain' a thing (after being lost) or a person (when you meet up after not seeing them for a long time). e.g. After 10 years my old friend and I met up. = après 10 ans mon vieille amie et moi nous (reflexive pronoun) sommes rencontrés. Use the reflexive form in the last case because what you mean is we meet 'ourselves'.

question: I found my keys.
answer: J'ai retrouvé mes clés.

question: a meeting
answer: une réunion; une réunion = a meeting; un rendez-vous = an appointment (with a professional - a consultation; Never use this for a work or personal meeting/meet-up.); une réservation = a reservation for a dinner/event

question: to meet (someone for the first time)
answer: (se) rencontrer ('rohn-kohn-tray'); past participle: rencontré; Remember there are 2x Ns and TR sound. It is very different from raconter (to tell a story; 'ra-kohn-Tay' with an A sound in the first syllable).; (SE) RENCONTRER is only used reflexively when the object is not explicity - when the subject and the object are the same. e.g. We met (eachother).

question: to meet up in a planned way (with someone that you already know)
answer: (se) voir OR (se) retrouver; Use (SE) RETROUVER when you have not seen them in a really long time.; Only use these verbs reflexively when the object is not explicit. e.g. They met up (with eachother). = Ils se sont vu(e)s.; VOIR and RETROUVER use avoir as auxiliary but they must use être (and adapt the participe passé) when used reflexively.

question: to see someone (that you already know) by chance
answer: (se) croisser OR (se) revoir; Technically RENCONTRER (to meet someone for the first time) can also be used in this case. But it's more common to use the other verbs.

question: What is the difference between RENCONTRER and RENCONTRE?
answer: RENCONTRER (with final R) = to meet (someone for the first time)  RENCONTRE (without final R) = to encounter someone or something; RENCONTRER (with final R) can also mean to meet someone that you already know by surprise. But there are better verbs to use for that case. e.g. CROISSER or REVOIR

question: I met (for the first time) my friend.
answer: J'ai rencontré mon ami(e).; Use (se) rencontrer (instead of se voir or se retrouver) because you are meeting for the first time or by chance.; You do not need to use the verb reflexively in this case because the object is explicit. So use avoir as the auxiliary and the standard participe passé.

question: I met them (for the first time).
answer: Je les ai rencontré.; In french 'them' is a direct object of rencontrer so we use LES to represent the plural people.; Use (se) rencontrer because you are meeting for the first time or by chance.; You do not need to use the verb reflexively in this case because the object is explicit.

question: We met (for the first time) in Berlin.
answer: On s'est rencontrés à Berlin.; Use (se) rencontrer because you are meeting for the first time or by chance.; Use the verb reflexively because the object is not explicit (subject and object are the same). So use être (instead of avoir) and adapt the participe passé.

question: They (all men / all women) met (for the first time).
answer: Ils se sont rencontrés. / Elles se sont rencontrées.; Use the verb reflexively because the object is not explicit (subject and object are the same). So use être (instead of avoir) and adapt the participe passé.

question: How did you meet them?
answer: Comment tu les as rencontré?; Use rencontrer (instead of retrouver) because you are meeting for the first time. ;You do not need to use the reflexive form because both subject (tu) and object (les) are explicit - there is no implied 'eachother'.

question: Did you meet them all in France?
answer: Est-ce que tu les as tous rencontrés en France?; Use rencontrer (instead of retrouver) because you are meeting for the first time.; You do not need to use the reflexive form because both subject (tu) and object (les) are explicit - there is no implied 'eachother'.

question: idiomatic way to express: the new people that you meet (e.g. after moving to a new city)
answer: des nouvelles rencontres

question: I just saw my friend (the meeting was not planned).
answer: Je viens de croisser mon ami(e).; Use CROISSER or REVOIR for seeing a person that you already know by chance.

question: I met up with my friend (that I already knew).
answer: J'ai vu mon ami(e).; Use (SE) VOIR when meeting up with someone you already know in a planned way. Use it reflexively when the object is not explicit.

question: I met up with my friend (that I had not seen in a really long time).
answer: J'ai retrouvé mon ami(e).; Use (SE) RETROUVER when meeting up with someone you haven't seen in a long time. Use it reflexively when the object is not explicit.

question: We met up (friends that already knew eachother).
answer: Nous nous sommes vu(e)s.; Use (SE) VOIR when meeting up with someone you already know in a planned way.; In this case the object is not explicit (the subject and object are the same). So we use the verb reflexively which means that we use être (instead of avoir) and the participe passé must agree.

question: We will meet again.
answer: Nous nous verrons encore.; Use (SE) VOIR when meeting up with someone you already know in a planned way.; In this case the object is not explicit (the subject and object are the same). So we use the verb reflexively.

question: Pay attention to pronunciation: She will meet Marc (for the first time).
answer: futur simple: Elle rencontrera Marc. ('rohn-kohn-truh-ra'); All of the syllables are pronounced - you cannot drop any of them.; The first syllable is a classic french E - something between 'rohn' and 'ruhn'.

question: Pay attention to pronunciation: She will tell a story.
answer: futur simple: Elle racontera ('ra-kohn-tra') une histoire.; The first syllable should clearly sound like a french A (not a french E) like the English word 'racoon'. The penultimate syllable gets dropped (like medecin). This would not happen if there was an R directly after the T in the infinitive form.; The infinitive is raconter ('ra-kohn-tay'). The T is much clearer in the inifinitive.

question: physics + mechanics
answer: la physique + la mécanique

question: to be still / frozen
answer: figé(e); This is used to describe a screen when streaming stops.

question: mobile + static
answer: mobile + statique

question: a movement
answer: un mouvement

question: to move around physically or to start moving
answer: bouger; This verb can be used reflexively if an animate object is moving itself.; Bouger is not the best verb for moving from one location to another (déplacer) or for moving from one city to another for change of life (déménager).

question: to move from one location to another
answer: déplacer; This verb can be used reflexively if an animate object is moving itself.; Déplacer is not the best verb for moving around in a space (bouger) or for moving from one city to another for change of life (déménager).

question: I moved around the city (during the course of a day).
answer: Je me suis déplacé en ville.; SE DÉPLACER is the best verb to use for moving around in real time (instead of from one city to another - démanager) AND from place to place (instead of with your body in a room - bouger)

question: to move (from one city to another) / to relocate
answer: déménager = to move permanently from one city to another; Do not use this word for physical movement.; Alternative: s'installer à l'étranger

question: to move in (to a new house) + to move in together (as a couple)
answer: emménager + emménager ensemble; Watch out because AMÉNAGER (A with one M) means to arrange furniture.

question: He moved from Naples. He moved to Sardinia.
answer: Il a déménagé de Naples. + Il a emménagé à Bologne.; déménager = to move from a place. Use DE instead of À (though technically you could use À and add a destination).; emménager = to move to a new place. Use À.

question: idiomatic way to express: to leave the nest (when a young person moves away from their parents)
answer: quitter le nid

question: idomatic way to express: I like to (or I must) travel a lot.
answer: J'ai la bougeotte.; avoir la bougeotte (from BOUGER) = wanting constantly to travel and see new places

question: to install or put something up
answer: installer (without reflexive pronoun); Alternative: mettre en place (literally: to put in place). une mise en place = an installation

question: to settle (especially after a move)
answer: s'installer ('son-sti-lay'); a reflexive verb; l'installation = the settling (e.g. in a city)

question: My family moved a lot. (use passé composé)
answer: Ma famille a déménagé souvent.; Use 'souvent' instead of 'beaucoup de fois' because the latter is not idiomatic.

question: We moved every two years. (use imparfait)
answer: On déménageait tout les 2 ans.

question: temporary (like a pop-up) + timeless
answer: ephémère + intemporal

question: to force + You force me to make a decision.
answer: forcer + Tu me force à prendre une décision.

question: a job interview; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: un entretien d'embauche ('dohm-bowsh' ryhmes with bow like bateau chateau etc; Do not pronounce it 'boosh' because that sounds like the word for mouth.); un entretien (without specification) =  an appointment for discussion; Alternative: un entretien de recruitment

question: an interview of someone (journalism) that is planned
answer: un interview (journalism); NB: The word interview in french can only be used for this specific type of discussion. To say job interview: un entretien d'embauche.

question: an impromptu interview of someone (by a journalism in the street)
answer: un micro-trottoir

question: an interviewer (on television)
answer: un moderateur/présentateur/animateur AND une moderatrice/présentatrice/animatrice

question: I succeeded in the job interview.
answer: J'ai passé l'entretien d'embauche ('dohm-bowsh').

question: to confide (in someone)
answer: se confier (à quelqu'un)

question: to trust X
answer: To options: 1) faire confiance À quelqu'un (e.g. Je fais confiance au gouvernement.) 2) se fier ('fee-yay'); SE FIER sounds different than fier/fiére ('fyehr') - which is the word for proud.

question: to distrust / to be suspicious of X
answer: Three options: 1) ne faire pas confiance DANS (e.g. Je ne fais pas confiance DANS le livre.) 2) se défier: to distrust something/someone 3) se méfier ('may-fee-yay'): to be wary of something/someone

question: trustworthy
answer: Depends on context. 1) When someone is worthy of trust: être digne de confiance. e.g. Elle est digne de confiance.  2) Something is reliable or credible: être fiable; Pay attention to pronunciation. fiable ('fee-abl') means credible and sounds different from faible ('fehbl') which means weak.

question: suspicious (not trustworthy)
answer: suspect(e) OR méfiant(e)

question: questionable
answer: critiqable; literally: able to be critiqued or open to critique

question: critical
answer: critique; NB: In cases where adjectives are shared in english/french... if the english adjective has -AL suffix then this suffix does not exist in french.; The word is spelled the same whether you mean a noun (une critique = a critique of something) or an adjective (critique = critical).

question: idiomatic way to express: a pivotal point (e.g. in one's career)
answer: un moment chanière = an important moment in time; une charnière = a hinge

question: idiomatic way to express: X is important.
answer: Ça marque X.

question: to remember
answer: There are two possibilities: 1) SE SOUVENIR + de + some noun OR SE SOUVENIR + que + some phrase;  2) (SE) RAPPELER can be used for 'to remember' and 'to remind someone of something'. It does not require a reflexive pronoun AND it does not require any preposition between the verb and the object. When you use the reflexive pronoun it means to reflect back on.

question: How do you say: I remember him. Two ways: 1) with SOUVENIR 2) with RAPPELER
answer: 1) Je me souviens de lui. Always reflexive. Always require DE between verb and object. 2) Je me le rappelle. Literally: I remind myself of him. But the object is NOT a pronom tonique because the thing being recalled is a direct object of (SE) RAPPELER - without preposition DE.

question: I remember it.
answer: Je m'EN souviens. (juh-muh-soo-vyuh); SE SOUVENIR (to remember) is the verb and it is reflexive (me/m'); Pronom EN replaces 'it' because SE SOUVENIR is followed by DE. Do NOT use regular pronouns for the 'it'. e.g. Do NOT say: Je me le souviens.;  Pronom EN replaces a quantity of something or the complement of a verb following DE.

question: I remember the times before everyone had Google Maps.
answer: Je me souviens de l’époque (or DU TEMPS) où tout le monde avait Google Maps.; Alternative: Je me souviens de l’époque / du temps avant que tout le monde ait (subjonctif) Google Maps. AVANT QUE triggers subjonctif but après que does not.

question: I don't remember it.
answer: Je ne m'EN souviens pas.; Use pronom EN (instead of pronom Y) to refer to 'it' because SE SOUVENIR is always followed by DE when the object of the verb is more explicit.

question: I remember a little bit.
answer: Je m'EN souviens un peu. OR Je me souviens un peu DE ça.

question: I don't remember the conjugation.
answer: Je ne me souviens pas DE la conjugaison.; SE SOUVENIR (conjugated) + DE + the thing that was forgotten

question: I don't remember everything.
answer: Je ne me souviens pas DE tout.; SE SOUVENIR (conjugated) + DE + the thing that was forgotten

question: I will try to remember it.
answer: Je vais essayer DE m'EN souvenir.; Use DE between essayer and a second verb. Use EN to refer to the thing that you are remembering. The reflexive pronoun (ME) must adapt to the subject even though we are using the infinitive form (souvenir).

question: I would like to remember it.
answer: Je voudrais m'EN souvenir.; Vouloir does not require a preposition before the 2nd verb. Use EN to refer to the thing that you are remembering. The reflexive pronoun (ME) must adapt to the subject even though we are using the infinitive form (souvenir).

question: She remembers that I had a good day.
answer: Elle se souvient (or se rappelle) QUE j'ai passé une bonne journée.; SE SOUVENIR can use que (instead of de) when what follows is a complete phrase.; When using the verb PASSER (to mean spending time) you must use the duration periods (e.g. une soirée instead of un soir).

question: I remember Spain.
answer: Je me souviens DE l'Espagne. (not d'Espagne); You must use the preposition DE as well as the article for the country.

question: She reminded me of it five minutes later.
answer: Elle me l'a rappellé cinq minutes plus tard.; If you use a direct object (or COD) with RAPPELER then it means to recall / to remind someone of that thing.

question: She called me back five minutes later.
answer: Elle m'a rappellé cinq minutes plus tard.; If you do not use a direct object (or COD) with RAPPELER then it means to call someone back - like on the telephone.

question: idiomatic way to say: You told me about that.
answer: Tu m'en a parlé. Use PARLER (instead of DIRE) for this expression. EN is the general pronoun for the thing that was told.

question: Everything is ok.
answer: Tout est okay.

question: What do you remember?
answer: DE qoui te souviens tu?; Remember to use DE with souvenir every time that you refer to what is being remembered (unless you extract it with a pronoun).

question: You remember it. Do you remember it?
answer: Tu t'en souviens. Est-ce que tu te souviens?; NB: m' (which stands for me - reflexive pronoun) is replaced by t' (which stands for te)

question: It helps me to remember.
answer: Ça m'aide me souvenir.

question: a memory
answer: un souvenir OR une mémoire; The difference between these two is subtle. Souvenir describes something you experienced (often with another person). Mémoire speaks more the function of the brain - something that you memorized.

question: She has a good memory. (meaning good at remembering things)
answer: Elle a une bonne mémoire.

question: My memory (in general) is blurry. + The memory (specific) is blurry.
answer: Ma mémoire est floue. + Mon souvenir est flou.; une mémoire = the phenomenon of memory in general; un souvenir = a specific memory

question: to replace / Replace X with Y.
answer: replacer / Replacez X par Y.; The formal you (vous) is understood/omitted in the command.

question: What is the general rule for how a verb radical changes moving from past tenses to future tenses (regardless of verb mood)?
answer: Generally the past tenses use a shortened radical (sans R). e.g. parl for parler + av for avoir + dev for devoir + all for aller. This holds for indicatif imparfait and indicatif présent.; Generally the futur tenses use a longer radical (often including an R). e.g. parler for parler + aur for avoir + devr for devoir + ir for aller. This holds for conditionnel présent and indicatif futur simple / futur antérieur.; This means that when you hear a lot of R sounds then someone is generally speaking in a future tense (regardless of the verb mood).

question: What is the 'présent progressif' verb tense?
answer: Progressif means ongoing. So présent progressif emphasizes something that is happening / ongoing (literally) right now.; In English we use présent participe for progressive tenses (I am eating.). But in french the construction of progressive verbs is different.

question: How do you construct the 'présent progressif' verb tense?
answer: ÊTRE conjugated + en train de + INFINITIVE; e.g. Je suis en train de manger. = I am eating (literally right now).

question: She walks a lot. + She is walking.
answer: Elle marche beaucoup. / Elle est en train de marcher.; The former is simple présent tense. The latter is présent progressif.

question: I am learning. + I am not learning.; Use présent progressif.
answer: Je suis EN TRAIN D'apprendre. + Je ne suis pas en train d'apprendre.; When using PAS as an adverb to negate a phrase... PAS is placed directly after the auxiliary or conjugated portion of a verb.

question: the learning
answer: l'apprendisage (masculine); e.g. learning french = l'apprendisage du langue français

question: I am dressing/getting dressed.
answer: Je suis en train de ME habiller.; When using présent progressif tense with a reflexive verb... the reflexive pronoun stays with the infinitive. But it must adapt to the subject (e.g. me instead of se).

question: He was jumping/leaping.
answer: Il était en train de sauter.; Jumping is an english présent participe (an ongoing activity) which means that we need to use a progressive tense in french (être + en train de + infinitive). But this is happening in the past so we conjugate être in imparfait (was doing something): était.; This is an alternative (to imparfait) for expressing context in the past.

question: She will be jumping/leaping.
answer: Elle sera en train de sauter.; Jumping is an english présent participe (an ongoing activity) which means that we need to use a progressive tense in french (être + en train de + infinitive). But this is happening in the future (not present) so we conjugate être in futur simple (will be doing something): sera.

question: What is the 'passé recent' verb tense?
answer: This verb tense expresses that something was 'just happening' before the current state or before some other action. e.g. I just read that book. = Je viens de lire ce livre.; NB: This structure aligns with how we generally connect two verbs: conjugated verb + DE + infinitive verb.

question: How do you construct the 'passé recent' verb tense?
answer: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE; You must adapt reflexive pronouns to the subject.; You can add 'juste' for emphasis after the conjugated form of VENIR but it is not a requirement.

question: I just arrived.
answer: Je viens (juste) D'arriver.; Use passé recent: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE; You can optionally add 'juste' for emphasis.

question: We just woke up.
answer: On vient (juste) DE SE réveiller.; Use passé recent: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE; If the verb is reflexive then you must adapt the pronoun to the subject (even though you are using an infinitive). The pronoun is placed directly before the infinitive verb.

question: I just got married.
answer: Je viens (juste) DE ME marier.; Use passé recent: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE; If the verb is reflexive then you must adapt the pronoun to the subject (even though you are using an infinitive). The pronoun is placed directly before the infinitive verb.

question: They just found a new apartment.
answer: Ils viennent (juste) DE trouver un nouvel appartement (OR un appart which is short for appartement).; Use passé recent: VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE; NB: The adjective nouveau (masc sing) changes to nouvel when the noun starts with a vowel. This avoids two vowels against eachother. This behavior only happens to some adjectives that are placed before a noun.

question: She had just eaten.
answer: Elle venait (juste) de manger.; Use passé recent (VENIR conjugated + DE + INFINITIVE) but conjugate venir in impafait (instead of present) to indicate that everything happened in the past.

question: He moves to Brazil in 1929.
answer: Il déménage au Brésil en 1929.; You can use present tense to describe something in the past - just like in english.

question: He returns tomorrow.
answer: Il revient (présent) demain (futur).; You can use present tense to describe something in the future - just like in english.

question: I leave tonight.
answer: Je pars (présent) ce soir (futur).; You can use present tense to describe something in the future - just like in english.

question: What is the 'impératif' verb mood?
answer: Impératif mood expresses a command - something that you want someone to do.; It has two verb tenses: impératif présent (Do something right now.) and impératif passé (Have something done by midnight.)

question: How do you construct the 'impératif présent' for group 1 (-ER) verbs?
answer: There are only 3 possibilities: tu + nous + vous. Omit the subject because it is assumed. Then use the indicatif présent conjugation of the verb. For regular -ER verbs: remove the S from the tu form.; e.g. Eat the food.: (tu) Mange / (nous) Mangeons / (vous) Mangez la nourriture.

question: (you informal) Cut the bread.
answer: Coupe le pain.; COUPER is a regular -er verb so we use the present tense conjugation for tu (coupes) and then remove the S.

question: (we / let's) Change the sheets.
answer: Changeons les draps.; CHANGER is the verb. The present tense conjugation for nous is changeons.

question: (you formal) Listen.
answer: écoutez.; ÉCOUTER is the verb. The present tense conjugation for vous is écoutez.

question: How do you construct the 'impératif présent' for group 2 (-IR) verbs?
answer: Keep the final S in the tu form.; e.g. Finish the food.: (tu) Finis / (nous) Finissons / (vous) Finissez la nourriture.; NB: Sortir is not a regular -IR verb.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Go to the store.
answer: (tu) Va / (nous) Allons / (vous) Allez au magasin.; Aller is treated as a regular -ER verb in this case so we remove the S from the conjugated tu form.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Cook the meat.
answer: (tu) Fais cuire / (nous) Faisons / (vous) Faites le viande.; Faire is an irregular verb so we do not delete the S at the end of the tu verb form!

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Be nice.
answer: (tu) Sois / (nous) Soyons / (vous) Soyez sympa.; être is a fully irregular verb in the impératif mood so you have to memorize all three conjugations.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Get a cat.
answer: Use the verb avoir (to have): (tu) Aie / (nous) Ayons / (vous) Ayez un chat.; avoir is a completely irregular verb in the impératif mood so you have to memorize all three conjugations.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Put on the coat.
answer: Use the verb mettre (to put): (tu) Mets / (nous) Mettons / (vous) Mettez le manteau.; Keep the S on the tu form because mettre is irregular in the impératif mood.

question: (you informal / let's / you formal) Do something.
answer: Use the verb faire: (tu) Fais / (nous) Faisons / (vous) Faites quelque chose.; Keep the S on the tu form because faire is irregular in the impératif mood.

question: How do you construct the 'impératif présent' for reflexive verbs?
answer: The pronoun gets attached to the end of the verb.; e.g. (you informal) Go for a walk! = Promène-toi!; SE PROMENER is an -er verb so the S is omitted in the you informal form.

question: Let's go for a walk!
answer: (nous) Promenons-nous!; Use the impératif command form. SE PROMENER is the verb. To make the impératif for a reflexive verb attach the pronoun after the verb.

question: (you informal) Hurry up!
answer: Dépêche-toi!; SE DÉPÊCHER = to hurry up (oneself). It is generally used reflexively.

question: (you formal) Register! / Sign up!
answer: (vous) Inscrivez-vous!; Use the impératif command form. S'INSCRIRE is the verb. To make the impératif for a reflexive verb attach the pronoun after the verb.; the registration = l'inscription (from S'INSCRIRE)

question: (you formal) Do not eat that!
answer: (vous) Ne mangez pas ça!; Use the impératif command form. Mangez ça! would be the positive command. To negate it: NE is placed directly after where the (omitted) subject would be. PAS is placed directly following the verb.

question: (formal / informal) Drink lots of water.
answer: Bois / Buvez plus de l'eau.; NB: When plus is followed by DE then the S is pronounced 'plooews'.

question: (formal / informal) Always sleep for 8 hours.
answer: Dors / Dormez depuis huit heures pour toutes les nuits.

question: (formal / informal) Stop using your laptop.
answer: Arrête / Arrêtez d'utliser ton / votre ordinateur.

question: (formal / informal) Take some medicine.
answer: Prends / Prenez des médicaments.

question: (formal / informal) Put a wet towel on your forehead.
answer: Mets / Mettez une serviette de toillette humide sur ton / votre front.

question: How do you construct the 'futur proche' verb tense?
answer: ALLER conjugated + INFINITIVE of the action verb; The direct translation is 'X is going to do something'. NB: All object pronouns are placed between the two verbs!

question: When do you use the futur proche tense in writing?
answer: The usage is different when speaking and when writing!; When writing: Use futur proche for 1) something that will happen imminently - not years from now 2) something that will happen as a natural consequence of some action e.g. warning a child... Tu vas tomber! 3) an action that is lightly planned - not a major commitment/project/vision - that may or may not change in the future (lower certainty than futur simple) 4) a change to the status quo; If something is more intentionally planned (like a project/goal) or will occur further into the future or has higher certainty (with the exception of projections)... then use futur simple (instead of futur proche) in writing.

question: When do you use the future proche tense in speaking?
answer: The usage is different when speaking and when writing!; When speaking: It is very common for people to use futur proche for anything in the future because it's easy to formulate and it's very dynamic (it indicates action that is lightly planned - not a manifesto on what you will undertake over the next year or 5 years).; It is especially correct to use futur proche to discuss the weather or to say something like: Le année prochaine je vais aller... because you made the time frame clear.

question: They are going to eat. Use futur proche.
answer: Ils vont manger.

question: After we go to the cinema we will drink some wine. Use futur proche.
answer: après on va au cinema on va boire DU vin.; Remember that BOIRE is always followed by DE. de + le = du

question: You are going to eat it (masculine). Use futur proche.
answer: Tu va le manger.; Note how the object pronoun is placed in between the two verbs in futur proche.

question: I am going to help you. Use futur proche.
answer: Je vais t'aider.; Note how the object pronoun is placed in between the two verbs in futur proche.; The pronoun te ends in a vowel and the infinitive starts with a vowel so we condense them using apostrophe.

question: How do you construct the 'indicatif futur simple' verb tense?
answer: ENTIRE INFINITIVE* + ending that agrees with subject (je –AI + tu -AS + il/elle/on -A + nous -ONS + vous -EZ + ils/elles -ONT); *except for 3rd group and irregular verbs which typically transform into something that ends in an R; NB: The endings for the nous form and ils form sound exactly the same and they are NOT silent! (not like -ENT au présent).; NB: Most of the endings are the same as AVOIR conjugated au présent.

question: What are the two non-intuitive things regarding pronunciation in indicatif futur simple?
answer: 1) ils/elles -ONT ending in futur simple is pronounced (not silent like -ENT au présent) 2) We often drop a syllable in futur simple. e.g. PRÉSENTER: il présentera ('pray-suhn-TRA'). Drop the penultimate syllable like médicin. This often results in a heavy R sound at the end of the verb - the characteristic sound of futur simple.; NB: There are times when the R is skipped. e.g. Ils diffuseront ('di-fuh-sont').

question: What is the radical used for indicatif futur simple for -ER verbs (group 1) and -IR verbs (group 2)?
answer: the entire infinitive for both group 1 and group 2 verbs; e.g. parler and choisir; NB: This is the same base used for conditionnel présent.; NB: There are some verbs that end in -IR but that are not regular. e.g. sortir + partir + venir + tenir

question: What is the radical used for indicatif futur simple for group 3 verbs ending in -RE (e.g. prendre + dire + croire + descendre)?
answer: Simply drop the final E. So the R remains lending to the heavy R sound of futur simple.; prendre:prendr + dire:dir + croire:croir + descendre:descendr; NB: This is the same base used for the conditionnel présent.

question: What are the radicals used for indicatif futur simple for these irregular verbs: être + aller + faire + venir + pouvoir + devoir?
answer: Even the irregular verbs use a radical that ends in R - contributing to the heavy R sound of futur simple.;être:ser + aller:ir + faire:fer + venir:viendr + pouvoir:pourr + devoir:devr; Make sure that you are pronouncing SER and FER bases like a classic french E (rounded mouth; mix between 'uh' and 'oh').; NB: These are the same bases used for the conditionnel présent.

question: What is the difference between these two: serai + serrai?
answer: It's really important to pronounce these differently. 1) serai ('suh-ray') is the verb être in futur simple. The E in future forms of être (base: ser) sound like the classic french E (a mix of 'uh' and 'oh' because the mouth is rounded). 2) serrais ('say-ray') is the verb serrer (to tighten) in imparfait. The RR changes the sound of the E.; If you pronounce the future forms of être (like serai) with an 'ay' sound then it sounds like a different verb.

question: What are the future bases for these irregular verbs: avoir + savoir + voir?
answer: avoir:aur + savoir:saur (savoir is conjugated the same as avoir but with an S at the beginning) + voir:verr (voir is totally different than avoir and savoir); NB: These are the same bases used for the conditionnel tense.

question: What are the future bases for these irregular verbs: pouvoir + vouloir + devoir + falloir?
answer: pouvoir:pourr + vouloir:voudr + devoir:devr + falloir:faudr; NB: These are the same bases used for the conditionnel présent.

question: What are the future bases for these irregular verbs: venir + tenir?
answer: venir: viendr + tenir: tiendr

question: When should you use futur simple? (instead of futur proche)
answer: The general rule (with some exceptions) is to use futur simple for higher certainty (highly planned) events. Use futur proche for lower stakes events that have slightly less certainty or for natural consequences of some action. Use futur simple: 1) To make a promise. Using futur simple indicates higher certainty so it will mean more if you promise in this tense. 2) To describe significant plans for the future (e.g. large projects). Use futur proche (instead) for minor plans like meeting a friend for coffee. 3) To discuss something that is not imminent - happening in the coming months and years. 4) To express a projection (e.g. how some metric will grow or what the weather will be like). This is an exception to the general rule because projections are not high certainty. 5) To discuss the result/consequence of a change OR an ongoing change. 6) For politeness or formality when making a request. e.g. Vous appellerez Madame Dupont?

question: When should you never use futur simple?
answer: Never use futur simple directly following SI (if) but you can use futur simple for the consquence. e.g. Si on mange trop (use présant because 'if' makes this part of the sentence a hypothetical)` alors on grossit (use futur simple because this part of the sentence is the consequence).

question: How do you pronounce these? je voudrais (conditionnel présent) + je voudrai (indicatif futur simple)
answer: Technically they are pronounced exactly the same: 'juh-voo-dray'. But french people tend to drag out the ending when they mean to use the conditionnel présent: 'juh-voo-draaaay'. When they intend futur simple then they keep the ending short: 'juh-voo-dray'.

question: What verb tense will generally follow these setups: Quand ... + Pendent que ... + J'espére que ...?
answer: Assuming you are describing an event in the future then use futur simple in these phrases.

question: When should you use alors vs puis?
answer: Alors is a good transition word when you are revealing a consequence of the earlier sentence (e.g. if i eat too much then i will gain weight).; Puis should only be used to describe sequential steps. e.g. We went to dinner. Then we went to a movie.

question: then (at that time in the future)
answer: cependant; This is not a commonly used word but it is the appropriate word when you want to express that you will do something at a time in the future (cependant) instead of doing something because of a cause (alors) or doing something after something else (puis).

question: I will finish. Use futur simple.
answer: Je finirai. (finir is the infinitive + ai to agree with je)

question: I will finish it (masculine). Use futur simple.
answer: Je le ('zszszszluh') finirai.; All pronouns representing objects of the verb are placed before the verb in futur simple.; When JE is followed by an L it does not sound like 'shhhh'. Instead it sounds closer to an English J 'zszszszs'. But it is still a long slow sound without forming a separate syllable.

question: You will go out. Use futur simple.
answer: Tu sortiras. (sortir is the infinitive + as to agree with tu)

question: You (plural/formal) will sing. Use futur simple.
answer: Vous chanterez. (chanter is the infinitive + ez to agree with vous)

question: They will arrive tonight. Use futur simple.
answer: Ils arriveront ce soir.

question: I will take. Use futur simple.
answer: Je prendrai.; For verbs that end in -e (like PRENDRE) we remove the -e from the infinitive before applying the same futur simple endings to agree with the subject.; PRENDR + AI

question: They will put. Use futur simple.
answer: Ils mettront.; Follows the same pattern as PRENDRE.; 'muh-tron' because -ont is still pronounced in this form.

question: We will wait. Use futur simple.
answer: On attendra.; Attendre is the infinitive. It ends in -e so subtract the -e. Then add the -a ending for il/elle/on.; ATTENDR + A

question: I will come tomorrow. Use futur simple.
answer: Je viendrai demain.; This is an example of a verb that is irregular in futur simple. The infinitive for 'to come' is VENIR. But we change it to VIENDR and then add the futur simple endings.

question: You will go. Use futur simple.
answer: Tu iras.; Aller is irregular in futur simple. The infinitive for 'to go' is ALLER. But we change it to IR and then add the futur simple endings.

question: We will go. + They will go. Use futur simple.
answer: On ira (or nous irons). + Ils iront.

question: I will go. He would go.
answer: J'irai (indicatif futur simple). Il irait (conditionnel présent).; NB: The conditionnel présent conjugated forms sounds like the first person (je) conjugated in indicatif futur simple.

question: We will run errands (not shopping for luxury goods).
answer: Nous ferons des courses.; Faire is irregular in futur simple. Instead of 'fair' we use the radical 'fer' and then add the endings.

question: You (formal/plural) will be in Paris.
answer: Vous serez à Paris.; être is irregular in futur simple. We use 'ser' as the radical and then add the endings.

question: She will have a cat.
answer: Elle aura un chat.; Avoir is irregular in futur simple. We use 'aur' as the radical and then add the endings.

question: What will you eat? (use futur simple)
answer: Que mangeras-tu?

question: What will you (informal) do? / What will you (formal) do?
answer: Que feras-tu? / Que ferez-vous?; Faire is irregular in past participle using 'fer' as base.

question: I will see you (informal). Use futur simple.
answer: Je te verrai.

question: I will do it.
answer: Je le ('zszszszluh') ferai.; When JE is followed by an L it does not sound like 'shhhh'. Instead it sounds closer to an English J 'zszszszs'. But it is still a long slow sound without forming a separate syllable.

question: We shall see. / We will see.
answer: On verra. (use futur simple); NB: On verra ce que ça donne. = We will see. (the same meaning but more idiomatic)

question: If I save money then I will travel to Italy.
answer: Si j'economise d'argent puis j'irai à l'Italie.; The first phrase is in indicatif présent because it is a hypothesis. The second phrase is in indicatif futur simple because it is something that will certainly happen if the hypothesis is met.

question: I will work more if I travel less.
answer: Je traveillerai plus si je voyage moins.; The first phrase is indicatif futur simple because it happens in the future if the hypothesis (the second phrase in indicatif présent) is met.

question: Is it possible for the futur simple to follow the word SI (if) directly?
answer: It is possible if the SI indicates 'whether or not something will happen' instead of indicating a hypothesis ('if something happens').;e.g. Je ne sais pas SI je partirai. = I do not know IF (yes/no) I will leave (futur simpl directly follows the SI). Si je pars... = IF I leave... (hypothesis so présent directly follows the SI)

question: I will not eat butter any more. (use futur simple)
answer: Je NE mangerai PLUS de beurre.; 'no more' is a defined quantity so use generic DE (instead of partitive articles).; This is one way to express that you will stop doing something in the future.

question: I will not eat butter or bread. (use futur simple)
answer: Je NE mangerai PAS de beurre NI de pain.; A lack or negative quantity is still a defined quantity. So use generic DE (instead of partitive articles).; Use NI instead of ET when you are are negating multiple items.; This is another way to express that you will stop doing something in the future.

question: I will never eat butter. (use futur simple)
answer: Je NE mangerai JAMAIS de beurre.; 'none ever' is a defined quantity so use generic DE (instead of partitive articles).; This is one way to express that you will stop doing something in the future. JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: I will stop eating butter. (use futur simple)
answer: J'arrêterai manger de beurre.; This is another way to express that you will stop doing something in the future.

question: I will stop. (use futur simple)
answer: Je m'arrêterai.; When you use arrêter and you do not specify what you are stopping then you must use the reflexive form of the verb (S'ARRÊTER) to explain that you are stopping yourself ...from doing something. You cannot just say: J'arrête.

question: The water stopped.
answer: L'eau s'est arrêté.; We use the reflexive form of the verb (S'ARRÊTER) because some subject has to stop the water - it can't be ambiguous. In this case the water is stopping itself. But if we were more explicit about what stopped the water (or turned it off) then we could use the non-reflexive form of ARRÊTER. e.g. Elle a arrêté l'eau. = She stopped the water.

question: He stopped the car.
