answer: Il a arreté DE la voiture.;Subject + ARRÊTER + DE + Object (with article). You must use preposition DE.; In this case the object (the thing that is stopped) is explicit. So we do not need to use the reflexive form of the verb (S'ARRÊTER).

question: How do you construct the 'indicatif passé composé' verb tense?
answer: AUXILIARY VERB (être or avoir conjugated au présent) + PARTICIPE PASSÉ of the main verb; If être is the auxiliary (helper) verb then the participe passé must also agree with the subject in number and gender. Generally if the auxiliary is avoir then the participe passé does not agree in gender/number. There are some exceptions.

question: When should you use indicatif passé composé (instead of indicatif imparfait)?
answer: Use it for actions that occurred in the past. It should be used for anything that can be placed in a chronology - anything that advances a story. It should definitely be used to conclude a story. It should be used for an action that interupts the setting/background (e.g. the phone rang).

question: How does the treatment of objects change when you are using indicatif passé composé (compared to indicatif imparfait)?
answer: Phrases in passé composé must always be able to stand alone. So you cannot omit an object (or a pronoun that represents an object) of the phrase.; But when you are using imparfait to describe the context of a story then you are allowed to be a little vague (to build suspense) because you will eventually need to conclude with a complete phrase in passé composé.

question: Generally how is the participe passé formed for 1) regular -ER verbs 2) irregular -RE verbs?
answer: 1) -ER verbs: radical + É (e.g. parler becomes parlé). This group sounds exactly the same as the 2nd person plural (vous) au présent.; 2) -RE verbs: radical + IS (e.g. prendre becomes pris. mettre become mis. comprendre becomes compris.)

question: Generally how is the participe passé formed for 1) regular -IR verbs 2) irregular verbs ending -RIR  3) irregular verbs ending -IRE?
answer: 1) regular -IR verbs: radical + i (e.g. partir becomes parti); 2) irregular -RIR verbs: radical + ert (e.g. ouvrir becomes ouvert. souffrir becomes souffert.); 3) irregular -IRE verbs: radical + IT (e.g. conduire becomes conduit. écrire becomes écrit. dire becomes dit.)

question: Generally how is the participe passé formed for -OIR verbs?
answer: radical + U (e.g. pouvoir becomes pu. vouloir becomes voulu. courir becomes couru.)

question: I ate. We drank.
answer: J'ai mangé. On a bu.; boire is the infinitive for 'to drink' - bu is the past participle and it uses AVOIR in passé composé.

question: You (informal and formal) bought.
answer: Tu as acheté. Vous avez acheté.

question: They studied.
answer: Ils ont étudié.; étudier is a regular -ER verb. The radical is 'étudi' - not 'étud'.

question: They did not study.; Specify common pronunciation.
answer: When writing: Ils n'ont pas étudié.; When speaking the NE portion of negation is optional: Ils‿ont pas étudié. There is now an obligatory liaison between Ils and ont - even though gramatically there should be an NE there.

question: I did not study.
answer: Je n'ai pas étudié.; You do not need to add DE after PAS when what follows is a verb. This is different from nouns. e.g. Je n'ai pas DE pommes.; In passé composé PAS is placed between the auxiliary and the past participle. It is the only word that comes between those two parts of the verb.

question: All in passé composé: I read. / I read it. / I did not read it.
answer: J'ai lu. / Je l'ai lu. / Je ne l'ai pas lu.; Lire changes to Lu for past participle.

question: I learn. / I learned.
answer: J'apprends. ('juh-prawn') / J'ai appris. ('jay ah-pree')

question: What is the past participle for to take + to learn + to understand?
answer: prendre: pris + apprendre: appris + comprendre: compris; Every S is silent at the end.; être compris = to be understood

question: at school / in school
answer: à l'école

question: He lived alone. (passé composé + imparfait)
answer: Il a vécu seul. + Il vivait seul.

question: We saw something.
answer: On a vu quelque chose.; Voir is the infinitive. It uses avoir in passé composé and the participle is vu.; NB: The general rule for making a past participle for a verb ending in -OIR is to replace -OIR with -U.

question: They wanted something. (use passé composé)
answer: Ils/Elles ont voulu quelque chose.;Voulour is the infinitive. It uses avoir in passé composé and the participle is voulu.; NB: The general rule for making a past participle for a verb ending in -OIR is to replace -OIR with -U.

question: They were wanting me to... (use imparfait which is the likely idiomatic way to say this in french - unless you are stating the conclusion of a story)
answer: Ils voulaient que je...; Voulour is the infinitive

question: You were able (to pay).
answer: Tu a pu (payer).; Pouvoir is the infinitive (to be able to). Pouvoir uses avoir in passé composé and the participle for all subjects is pu.; NB: pouVOIR is the infinitive so it should be conjugated exactly the same as VOIR (to see).

question: Which 5 verbs have a completely irregular past particle?
answer: avoir (eu) + être (été) + faire (fait) + offrir (offert) + ouvrir (ouvert); NB: All of these use AVOIR as the auxiliary in passé composé and plus que parfait.

question: He had. / He was. / He did (something).
answer: Il a eu. / Il a été. / Il a fait.; All the 5 verbs with an irregular past participle use AVOIR as the auxiliary verb in passé composé.

question: How do you express: There is... (present) + There was/were... (past)
answer: There are... =  Il y a...; There was/were... = Il y avais...  Generally imparfait is the better choice for this phrase in the past because you are describing the scene. But there are examples where passé composé is better (Il y a eu...).

question: How do you express: There will be... (future)
answer: Two options depending on context. 1) Futur simple: Il y aura... = There will be....  2) Futur proche: Il y va avoir = There's gonna be...

question: There may be a thunderstorm.
answer: Il peut y avoir un orage.; Take the present tense (Il y a...) and change to use the helper verb pouvoir: Il peut y avoir...

question: He spoke rapidly.
answer: Il a RAPIDEMENT parlé.; In passé composé: Adverbs (like rapidement) are placed between the auxiliary and the past participle.

question: She often wore makeup.
answer: Elle s'est SOUVENT maquilée.; In passé composé: Adverbs (like souvent) are placed between the auxiliary and the past participle.

question: I grew a lot as a person (during some formative time of life)
answer: J'ai BEAUCOUP grandi en tant que personne.; In passé composé: Adverbs (like beaucoup) are placed between the auxiliary and past participle.

question: How do you negate a phrase in passé composé?
answer: NE comes directly after the subject. PAS is placed between the auxiliary and the past participle (like all adverbs).; e.g. We did not do X. = Nous n'avons pas fait X.; Nothing else (except adverbs) are ever placed between the auxiliary and the past participle.

question: He did not read. + They did not run.
answer: Il N'a PAS lu. + Ils N'ont PAS couru.; In passé compose: NE is placed directly after the subject (before any pronouns). PAS is placed between the auxiliary and past participle.

question: I did not travel a lot.
answer: Je N'ai PAS BEAUCOUP voyagé.; In passé composé: Adverbs (like beaucoup) are placed between the auxiliary and past participle - with PAS.

question: I have not yet finished.
answer: Je n'ai pas ENCORE fini.; Encore can mean 'yet' or 'even'.; Adverbs (like encore) are placed between the auxiliary and the past participle - with PAS.

question: idiomatic way to express: I was running all week.
answer: J'enchaine. = I'm really busy doing one thing after another; enchainer = to do one thing after another (like chain smoking); You could also say: J'ai couru toute la semaine. = I ran all week long (literally).

question: She pinched her finger.
answer: Elle s'est pincé (not pincée) le doight.; If a reflexive verb is followed by an object then the participe passé does not agree in gender/number with the subject.

question: She injured herself while riding a bike.
answer: Elle s'est blessée (agreement) en faisant du vélo.; The reflexive verb is not followed directly by an object so the participe passé still must agree in gender/number with the subject.

question: What the three characteristics that lead to a verb using être in passé composé?
answer: 1) a verb that describes movement of an animate object (e.g. la maison de être = verbs that describe a person's movement in/around a home) 2) a verb that describes a change of state (e.g. naître + mourir + devenir = to become something) 3) Any verbs that is being used in a reflexive way (e.g. SE PROMENER); NB: An acronym to remember the 15 base verbs is MRS VANDERTRAMPP.; Remember that when être is the auxiliary verb then the past participle must agree with the subject in gender and number.

question: What are the 15 verbs that use être in passé composé (a past tense)?
answer: Monter Retourner Sortir Venir (e.g. includes devenir + revenir + etc.) Arriver Naître Descendre Entrer Rentrer Tomber Rester Aller Mourir Partir Passer; Remember that when être is the auxiliary verb then the past participle must agree with the subject in gender and number.; Some verbs can use both être and avoir as auxiliaries but the choice changes the meaning.

question: When do we use avoir (instead of être) as auxiliary in passé composé for the 15 verbs that typically use être?
answer: If the COD of the verb is a location then we are using the verb in the positional sense which dictates être as auxiliary. e.g. Je suis passé devant le magasin. = I passed in front of the store.; If the COD of the verb is an object then we are using the verb in a non-positional sense which dictates avoir as auxiliary. e.g. J'ai passé un bon moment. = I had a good time.

question: Conjugate 'to arrive' in passé composé.
answer: ARRIVER is the infinitive; Je suis arrivé(e) (m/f) + Tu es arrivé(e) (m/f) + Il/Elle/On est arrivé(e) (m/f) + Nous sommes arrivés + Vous êtes arrivés + Ils/Elles sont arrivé(e)s; explanation: arriver uses être in passé composé. So we conjugate être for the auxiliary. Then the past participle must agree with the subject.

question: I leave. + I left (a place).
answer: Je pars. + Je suis parti(e).; PARTIR is not a regular -IR verb. Nous partONS. - not Nous partissons.; PARTIR uses être in passé composé so the past participle must agree with the subject.; Think of partir as 'parting' from something.

question: I go out of the apartment. + I went out.
answer: Je sors du appartement. + Je SUIS sorti(e) du appartment.; SORTIR is not a regular -IR verb in the present tense.; SORTIR uses être in passé composé (when it is being used to describe the position of the subject) so the past participle must agree with the subject.; la sortie = the exit. SORTIR + DE = to go out from OR to take out from.

question: I take my gloves out of the box. + I took my gloves out of the box.
answer: Je sors mes gants de la boîte. + J'AI sorti mes gants de la boîte.; SORTIR generally uses être as auxiliary but in this case we are using SORTIR to describe an action (not the position of the subject) so we use avoir as auxiliary.; SORTIR + DE = to go out from OR to take out from.

question: They (all feminine) went online to learn.
answer: Elles sont allées en ligne.; Aller uses être in passé composé and so it must agree with the subject (Ils sont allés. vs Elles sont allées.)

question: You come from the country. + You came from the country.
answer: Tu viens de la campagne. + Tu es venu(e) de la campagne.; VENIR (to come) uses être in passé composé so the participe passé must agree with the subject (venu if masculine + venue if feminine).

question: We came home to our place. + We brought the table into our place.
answer: On EST rentrés chez nous. + On A rentré la table chez nous.; RENTRER (to come back) generally uses être as auxiliary (the first phrase). But if we use RENTRER to describe something other than the position of the subject then we use avoir as auxiliary and that means that the participe passé no longer agrees with subject (second phrase).

question: I entered the bedroom. + I inserted the key into the lock.
answer: Je SUIS entré(e) dans la chambre. + J'AI entré la clé dans la serrure.; ENTRER (to enter) generally uses être as auxiliary (the first phrase). But if we use ENTRER to describe something other than the position of the subject then we use avoir as auxiliary and that means that the participe passé no longer agrees with subject (second phrase).

question: I climbed the stairs. + I put up the suitcases.
answer: Je SUIS monté(e) les escaliers. +  J'AI monté les valises.; Monter with auxiliare être (participe passé agrees) = to go up / to take oneself up. Monter with auxiliare avoir (participe passé does not agree) = to take upstairs (or assemble) some object (COD).

question: I got off the bus. + I took down the bottle from the shelf.
answer: Je SUIS descendu(e) du bus. + J'AI descendu la bouteille de l'étagère.; DESCENDRE (to go down / to descend) generally uses être as auxiliary (the first phrase). But if we use DESCENDRE to describe something other than the position of the subject then we use avoir as auxiliary and that means that the participe passé no longer agrees with subject (second phrase).

question: The mosque was turned towards the museum. + He turned the page of the book.
answer: La mosquée EST tournée vers la musée. + Il A tourné la page du livre.; TOURNER generally uses avoir in passé composé (which is the case in the second phrase). But when we use TOURNER to describe the position of the subject (as in the first phrase) then we must use être as auxiliary. That means that the participe passé must agree in gender/number with the subject.

question: What are the only two verbs that use être in passé composé AND are irregular in passé composé?
answer: naître (to be born) and mourir (to die) - e.g. Je suis né(e) + Il/Elle est mort(e).; NB: Any verb can be made into a reflexive verb. So if a verb (that normally uses avoir in passé composé) is used reflexively in passé composé then it might be an additional case of an irregular être verb in passé composé.

question: They (all men / all women) died.
answer: Ils sont morts. / Elles sont mortes.;Mourir (to die) uses être in passé composé which means that the participle must agree with the subject.

question: She/he was born on XX/XX/XXX. He was born.
answer: Elle/il est né(e) le XX/XX/XXXX.; Naître (to be born) uses être in passé composé so the past participle must agree with the subject.; Place LE before any date because all dates are masculine nouns.

question: You (formal and informal) were born in XXXX
answer: Vous êtes / Tu es né(e) à/en/au/aux XXXX.; à for a city; en/au/aux for a country following aller + rester + partir.

question: What are 3 alternative ways to say I was born in Paris (without using the verb naître)?
answer: Je suis natif de Paris. + Je suis parisienne de naissance. + Je suis paname.; Paname is a slang word for Paris.

question: the city where I was born
answer: la ville OÙ je suis né(e); Use the relative pronoun OÙ to represent a time or place (where or when). This is different than when you start a phrase with 'when'. e.g. when i was 10 years old = QUAND j'avais 10 ans

question: France is a good place to live.
answer: La France est un bon endroit OÙ vivre.; Use pronom où (where) in this case - instead of DE.

question: the season when it is hottest
answer: la saison OÙ il fait plus chaud; Use the relative pronoun OÙ to represent a time or place (where or when).

question: the moment when I saw it
answer: le moment ('momo') OÙ je l'ai vu; Use the relative pronoun OÙ to represent a time or place (where or when).

question: My cousin had a son.
answer: Use AVOIR in passé composé: Mon cousin a eu un fils.

question: How do you construct the 'indicatif passé composé' verb tense for reflexive verbs?
answer: All reflexive verbs use être as a helper verb (regardless of whether or not they use être in the non-reflexive form). SUBJECT + PRONOUN (me/te/...) + ÊTRE CONJUGATED + PAST PARTICIPLE OF THE VERB; NB: We are using être as the auxiliary verb in these reflexive cases so the past participle must agree with the subject.

question: Yesterday I got up at 8am.
answer: Hier je me suis levé(e) à 8h.

question: You (masc / fem) went to sleep late last night.
answer: Tu t'es couché / couchée tard hier soir (or la nuit dernière).; Se coucher is reflexive so we use être as auxiliary and then the past participle agrees with the subject.; NB: In this case t'es is a required contraction of the pronoun TE and the verb EST. But in conversation it is not uncommon for the french to contract the subject TU and the verb EST. e.g. T'es gentil(e). = You are nice. Do not use this in formal communication but you will hear it in informal communication.

question: I help you.
answer: Je t'aide.; pronouns that are direct objects come BEFORE the verb in French

question: I helped you.
answer: Je t'ai aidé.; In the past tense the direct object pronoun comes BEFORE BOTH the helper verb and the action verb.

question: He helped us. / I helped them.
answer: Il nous a aidé. / Je les ai aidé.

question: Can you (formal) help me? + Would you help me?
answer: Pouvez-vous m'aider? (indicatif présent) + Pourriez-vous m'aider? (conditionnel présent); The latter is more polite because it uses the conditionnel mood.

question: Can you (informal) hear me?
answer: Peux tu m'entendre?

question: Can I ...? + May I ...?
answer: Pourrais-je ('poo-rayj')...? Use POUVOIR in the conditionnel mood to be polite in formal and informal settings.; Rarely used alternative: Puis-je ('poo-eej') ...? This is the present tense (je peux) inverted. We cannot say peux-je because of vowels so we revert to an ancient form of the word (je puis). This is not common. It sounds weird in everyday settings. Do not use it.

question: May I help you?
answer: Pourrais-je vous aider? Use POUVOIR in the conditionnel mood to be polite in formal and informal settings.; Alternative you may hear: Comment puis-je ('poo-eej') vous aider? = How can I help you? using inversion of the ancient form je puis. A vendor in a store may use this to be overly polite but it sounds weird in everyday conversation.

question: He gives to me. + He gave to me. + He will give to me.
answer: Il me donne. + Il m'a donné. + Il va me donner.; In futur proche (conjugated ALLER + infinitive) pronouns that are objects of the verb - direct and indirect - are placed in between the conjugated ALLER and the infinitive.

question: You told me multiple times.
answer: Tu me l'as dit plusieurs fois.; Tu (You) me (to me) le (it) as (auxiliary AVOIR because NOT reflexive and uses 'to tell' uses avoir) dit (past participle of dire); NB: In French you cannot just say 'You told me.' You must refer to what it is that was told (You told IT to me.) ...even if you use a pronoun and even if you already described it in a previous sentence.; Both the direct and indirect object pronouns come before the verb.

question: I remembered it. + I did not remember it.
answer: Je m'en suis souvenu(e). + Je ne m'en suis pas souvenu(e).; To form the past tense look at the infinitive (se souvenir). It is a variation of the verb VENIR. So it has the same ending in past participle: souvenu.; Remember in this case we use 'en' instead of 'le' to represent 'it' because SE SOUVENIR triggers DE before the object.

question: I thought about something. + I remembered something.
answer: Je pensais (imparfait) à quelque chose. + J'ai pensé à quelque chose.; You can choose between imparfait (something in the past that has changed or is no longer happening) and passé composé (something distinct that happened in the past) to change the meaning of a phrase. There is lots of nuance - it's not black/white.; We almost always use the imparfait to describe something we were thinking in the past because (implicitly) we no longer think the same now.

question: I dreamed of a cat. + I dreamed of becoming a doctor (but I did not).
answer: J'ai rêvé (passé composé) d'un chat. + Je revais de devenir médecin.; You can choose between imparfait (something in the past that has changed or is no longer happening) and passé composé (something distinct that happened in the past) to change the meaning of a phrase. There is lots of nuance - it's not black/white.

question: I became an engineer. + I almost became a doctor (but I did not).
answer: Je suis devenu(e) (passé composé) ingénieur. + Je devenais (imparfait) médecin.; You can choose between imparfait (something in the past that has changed or is no longer happening) and passé composé (something distinct that happened in the past) to change the meaning of a phrase. There is lots of nuance - it's not black/white.

question: When using passé composé (or any other composed verb tense) with AVOIR as the auxiliary` under what circumstances does the participe passé agree in gender/number?
answer: When the direct object of the phrase (or its pronoun) is placed before the verb. In these cases the participe passé must agree in gender/number with the OBJECT (not the subject).; For example: J'ai VU la femme. (No agreement in participe passé because avoir is the auxiliary and a direct object is placed after the verb.) C'est la famme que j'ai VUE. (Participe passé is feminine singular to agree with the object - la femme - because avoir is the auxiliary and the object is placed before the verb.

question: He ate them.
answer: Il les (masc pl) a mangéS (masc pl).; This is the special case of passé composé (or any composed tense) where avoir is the auxiliary and a direct object (or its pronoun) is placed before the verb. In those cases the participe passé must agree with the object (not the subject). This often changes the pronunciation of the participe passé.

question: It's the apartment that she bought. + It's the house that she bought.
answer: C'est l'appartement qu'elle a acheté (masc sing to agree with appartement). + C'est la maison qu'elle a achetée (fem sing to agree with maison).; The participe passé must agree in gender/number with a DIRECT OBJECT (not the subject) when avoir is the auxiliary and the object is placed before the verb.; This often changes the pronunciation of the participe passé.

question: the apartment that my father constructed + the house that my father constructed; Specify pronunciation.
answer: l'appartement (masc sing) que mon père a construit ('kohn-stwee') + la maison (fem sing) que mon père a construitE ('kohn-stweeT'); This is the special case of passé composé (or any composed tense) where avoir is the auxiliary and a direct object (or its pronoun) is placed before the verb. In those cases the participe passé must agree with the object (not the subject). This often changes the pronunciation of the participe passé.

question: the box that I opened; Specify pronunciation.
answer: la boîte que j'ai ouvertE ('oo-verT'); This is the special case of passé composé (or any composed tense) where avoir is the auxiliary and a direct object (or its pronoun) is placed before the verb. In those cases the participe passé must agree with the object (not the subject). This often changes the pronunciation of the participe passé.

question: the flowers that you offered to Simone; Specify pronunciation.
answer: les fleurs (fem pl) que tu as offertES ('oh-fehrT') à Simone; This is the special case of passé composé (or any composed tense) where avoir is the auxiliary and a direct object (or its pronoun) is placed before the verb. In those cases the participe passé must agree with the object (not the subject). This often changes the pronunciation of the participe passé.

question: the flowers that you gave + the flowers of which you spoke; Specify spelling of the participe passé.
answer: les fleurs (fem pl) que tu as donnéES (fem pl) + les fleurs DONT tu as parlé (masc sing).; The first phrase is the case of composed tenses where a direct object (the flowers) is placed before the verb AND avoir is the auxiliary. So the participe passé must agree in gender/number with the direct object.; The second phrase resembles that case butthe object is not a direct object. So the participe passé does NOT agree in gender/number with the object. The object (the flowers) is the object of a prepositional phrase: Tu as parle DE les fleurs. The use of DONT is the hint here.

question: What is the 'indicatif imparfait' verb tense?
answer: Imparfait tense is used for happenings in the past (not the present) that do not advance the story (do not fit strictly into a chronology): a situation + scene + state of being + habit + feelings + thoughts. 1) Something in the past with a continuing/ambigous time frame. e.g. telling a story / sharing a memory  2) Adding context/setting/details (not actions) to a story in the past  3) Something that happened habitually in the past (habits)  4) Something that was true in the past but is no longer true in the present (e.g. When you thought something in the past but now you think differently.)

question: How do you construct the 'indicatif imparfait' verb tense?
answer: For -ER and -IR verbs: RADICAL of the infinitive in the NOUS form + imparfait endings (je -ais + tu -ais + il -ait + nous -ions + vous -iez + ils -aient); There is no auxiliary/helper verb (as in passé composé).; NB: For all -ER verbs 'imparfait' sounds exactly the same as the infinitive for ALL subjects (except nous and vous forms)!!; NB: The endings (not the base) for the indicatif imparfait and conditionnel présent tenses are exactly the same.

question: What are the two english phrases that - when translated - almost always use 'imparfait' tense?
answer: I was (doing something) + I used to (do something) ...for any subject; Note how these indicate something in the past without a defined beginning and end / was or used to be but is no longer / was habitual.

question: I bought it at the store. + I was buying it... (when something else happened).
answer: Je l'ai acheté (indicatif passé composé) au magasin. + Je l'achetais (indicatif imparfait)...; The second phrase is in l'imparfait because it describes context instead of an action that advances the story.

question: I walked on the beach. + I used to walk on the beach.
answer: J'ai marché (indicatif passé composé) sur la plage. + Je marchais (indicatif imparfait) sur la plage.; The second phrase is in l'imparfait because it describes an habitual action in the past.

question: How do you determine whether to conjugate in indicatif passé composé vs imparfait?
answer: Use passé composé for ACTION (or reaction) that advances a story. These phrases could be placed in a timeline/chronology. Often these are punctuated actions with clear start/end.; Use imparfait for DESCRIPTION to enrich the context or provide detail (e.g. weather). Use imparfait for habitual/repetitive activities in the past and activities in the past without a clear start/finish.; If the phrase doesn't fit into the chronology of the story then it probably should be conjugated in imparfait.

question: Conjugate marcher (to walk) in the 'imparfait' tense (I was walking + You were walking + etc).
answer: First determine présent nous form: nous MARCHons. Then subtract the ending so radical = MARCH; Now add the endings to the radical: Je marchais + Tu marchais + Il/Elle/On marchait + Nous marchions + Vous marchiez + Ils/Elles marchaient; NB: Marcher is a regular -ER verb so all the imparfait forms (except nous and vous) sound exactly the same as the infinitive - though they are spelled differently.

question: I ate. / I was eating.
answer: J'ai mangé. / Je mangeais.; Both are pronounced exactly the same as the infinitive.; Manger is a regular -ER verb all the 'imparfait' conjugations (except nous and vous) sound exactly the same as the infinitive - though they are spelled differently.

question: You (informal) ate. / You (informal) were eating.
answer: Tu a mangé. / Tu mangeais.; Both are pronounced exactly the same as the infinitive.; Manger is a regular -ER verb all 'imparfait' conjugations (except nous and vous) sound exactly the same as the infinitive - though they are spelled differently.

question: You (formal) ate. / You (formal) ate.
answer: Vous avez mangé. ('mon-jay') / Vous mangiez. ('mon-jee-ay'); Only passé composé is pronounced the same as the infinitive because the subject is vous.; Manger is a regular -ER verb all 'imparfait' conjugations (except nous and vous) sound exactly the same as the infinitive - though they are spelled differently.

question: She was waiting for me. + She was waiting for me to finish.
answer: Elle m'attendait. (no preposition between the verb 'to wait' and the person/thing you are waiting for) + Elle attendais que je finisse. (Use subjonctif in this case.)

question: Conjugate être (to be) in the 'imparfait' tense (I was + You were + He was + We were + You guys were + They were)
answer: J'étais ('jeh-tay') + Tu étais ('tu-eh-tay' OR 'teh-tay' but always spelled as two words) + Il/Elle était ('eh-tay') + Nous étions ('eh-teeon')+ Vous étiez ('eh-teeay')+ Ils/Elles étaient ('eh-tay')

question: I was happy.
answer: J'étais heureux/heureuse.; You automatically use the imparfait (instead of passé composé) because you are describing a state of being in the past.

question: Conjugate avoir (to have) in the imparfait tense (I was having + You were having + He was having + We were having + You guys were having + They were having)
answer: j'avais + tu avais + il avait + nous avions + vous aviez + ils avaient

question: Conjugate savoir (to know) in the imparfait.
answer: the same as AVOIR - just add an S in front of them all

question: Conjugate voir (to see) in the imparfait.
answer: Different than AVOIR. je voyais + tu voyais + il voyait + nous voyions + vous voyiez + ils voyaient

question: to recognize/acknowledge
answer: reconnaître; It is CONNAÎTRE (to be familiar with) with the prefix RE-.

question: to get to know (someone)
answer: apprendre à connaître (quelqu'un); This phrase only works with getting to know someone. If you mean 'to get to know some thing' then you must use S'HABITUER (to get used to)

question: I got to know him at work.
answer: J'ai appris à le connaitre au travail.; le = him because it is a direct object in this case.

question: to be used to something
answer: AVOIR l'habitude À quelque chose; This is different from describing the action of getting used to something (S'HABITUER).

question: to get used to something
answer: Many options: 1) S'HABITUER À quelque chose  2) PRENDRE l'habitude  3) AVOIR l'habitude = to be used to something already  4) DEVOIR habituer = to be required to get used to something

question: I adapt (to a new situation).
answer: Je me suis adapter.; Must use the reflexive form of the verb.

question: The hairdressers must get used to (or 'get to know') my hair.
answer: Il faut que les coiffeurs s'habituent à mes cheveux.; S'HABITUER = to get used to some thing; USE apprendre à connaître if instead you mean to get to know someone.

question: They are used to reading content online. + They got used to reading content online.
answer: Ils ont (AVOIR) l'habitude à lire du contenu en ligne. + Ils se sont habitués (S'HABITUER)...; These two sentiments are different enough that they require different verbs.

question: I am getting used to walking to work.
answer: Je m'habitue (S'HABITUER) à marcher (infinitive) pour aller au travail.; In english when we want to use a verb as a noun (walking in this case) then we add -ING (e.g. I like dancing.) But in french we cannot use a verb as a noun. If we need a noun then we use the infinitive. (e.g. J'aime danser. = I like to dance.)

question: to blend in
answer: se fondre dans la masse

question: Before... I went out every night.
answer: Avant... je sortais tous les soirs.; 'i went' is the flag to use the 'imparfait'. But also when 'avant' is used in this way then you can expect 'imparfait' to follow it.

question: In the mornings I ate eggs. + Frequently I ate eggs.
answer: Le matin je mangeais des œufs. +  Souvent je mangeais des œufs.; Both of these phrases suggested something that was habitually done in the past (not just once). Therefore we use imparfait in both cases.

question: I used to play tetris.
answer: Je jouais ('zshoo-ay') au tetris.; Use imparfait because in this case 'used to' means an activity in the past that was done repeatedly that is no longer happening - not to become accustomed to something.

question: I used to make coffee.
answer: Je faisais ('fez-ay') du café.; Use imparfait because in this case 'used to' means an activity in the past that was done repeatedly that is no longer happening - not to become accustomed to something.

question: I am used to sleeping a long time.
answer: Je suis habitué(e) (SE HABITUER) À dormir longtemps. OR J'ai l'habitude DE dormir longtemps.; Être habitué(e) requires preposition À. Avoir l'habitude requires preposition DE.; In this case 'used to' means that you got accustomed to something (in the past). So use passé composé. It is not an activity that was done repeatedly.

question: I am used to swimming.
answer: Je suis habitué(e) (SE HABITUER) À nager. OR J'ai l'habitude DE nager.; Être habitué(e) requires preposition À. Avoir l'habitude requires preposition DE.; In this case 'used to' means that you got accustomed to something (in the past). So use passé composé. It is not an activity that was done repeatedly.

question: Which verbs almost always use the imparfait tense (instead of passé composé) when used in the past tense? Why?
answer: penser + savoir + connaitre + vouloir + pouvoir + devoir; When you use these verbs in the past you almost mean that you thought/knew/wanted/etc something but that you no longer think/knew/want it now - the scenario has changed. That is why we almost always use imparfait for these verbs in the past tense. But be careful. Choosing imparfait vs passé composé depends on how the phrase is being used.

question: My mother wanted to see the horse.
answer: Ma mère voulait voir le cheval.; The infinitive is VOULOIR (to want). Conjugate vouloir in the imparfait because you are implying that she wanted something in the past but may not want the same thing in the present. For this reason... VOULOIR is almost always conjugated in imparfait (instead of passé composé) in the past.

question: It was 3:00pm. I saw an elephant.
answer: Il était 15 heures. J'ai vu un éléphant.; The first sentence describes the setting so use imparfait. The second sentence describes a discrete action so use passé composé.

question: What is the 'conditionnel' verb mood? Which tenses does it contain?
answer: Conditionnel verb mood expresses a hypothetical action that depends on something else being true. Contionnel mood has two verb tenses: conditionnel présent (could/should/would) and conditionnel passé (could have / should have / would have)

question: What is the 'conditionnel présent' verb tense?
answer: e.g. I would / could / should (do something). It expresses a hypothetical situation. There is uncertainty with a condition - you would do something IF something else were true. The accompanying IF statement may be implied.; The word IF cannot be used in the same phrase as you use the conditionnel mood because that would duplicate the hypothetical. e.g. I would do it... if I have time. = Je le ferrais (conditionnel présent)... si j'ai (indicatif présent) le temps.

question: When should you use the conditionnel présent verb tense?
answer: 1) to be polite (e.g. je voudrais) 2) to express a wish 3) to give advice (tu devrais) 4) to share information that is not confirmed (e.g. news article); NB: You can also use the imparfait to be polite in the present: Je voulais un cafe. = I would like a coffee. (in a very polite way)

question: How do you construct the 'conditionnel présent' verb tense?
answer: Use the same radical as the futur simple (the entire infinitive or modified infinitive - typically with R). Then add the imparfait endings to agree with subject: je -ais + tu -ais + il/elle/on -ait + nous -ions + vous -iez + ils/elles -aient; NB: Almost all of the conditionnel présent conjugations (je/tu/il/ils) sound exactly the same as the first person singular (je) form for indicatif futur simple (though spelled differently).; But the nous and vous forms are pronounced differently.

question: I would like some milk.
answer: Je voudrais DU lait.; Vouloir (to want) is conjugated in the conditionnel mood for politeness.

question: I would like to find...
answer: Je voudrais trouver...; Vouloir (to want) is conjugated in the conditionnel mood for politeness.

question: How do you express: I could / may / might (do something).
answer: Je POURRais faire quelque chose.; POUVOIR (to be able to) in the conditionnel présent + infinitive of the action verb

question: How do you express: I should (do something).
answer: Je DEVRais ('shduh-vray'; Je can contract in front of any verb) faire quelque chose.; DEVOIR (to must) in the conditionnel présent + infinitive of the action verb

question: How do you express: I must (do something).
answer: Je DOIS ('shdwah'; Je can contract in front of any verb) faire quelque chose.; Use DEVOIR (to must) in the présent tense!! ... not the condtionnel tense

question: How do you express: I had (to do something).
answer: Je DEVais ('shduh-vray'; Je can contract in front of any verb) faire quelque chose.; DEVOIR (to must) in the imparfait + infinitive of the action verb. Use imparfait because telling a story.; If you really needed to use passé composé (e.g. if you were stating a conclusion to past activity) then it would be: J'ai du (past participle of devoir) faire quelque chose.

question: How do you express: I didn't need (something).
answer: Je n'AVAIS pas besoin quelque chose.; Use AVOIR BESOIN in the imparfait tense because telling a story.; There is no second infinitive verb when you use avoir besoin.

question: How do you express: I want you (to do something). + I wanted you (to do something).
answer: This triggers subjonctif because it expresses a desire that may or may not reflect reality: Je veux QUE tu fasses quelque chose. + Je voulais QUE tu fasses quelque chose.; Remember that VOUDRAIS is the same verb. Any time you say: Je voudrais que... followed by a phrase - then that phrase must be in subjonctif.

question: idiomatic way to express: I have to do it.; Specify pronunciation.
answer: Il faut que je fasse ça. It is pronounced very quickly and squished together: 'foh-tkuh-shfahs'

question: idiomatic way to express: I don't have to do it.
answer: Je n'ai pas À faire ça.; Less idiomatic option: Je ne dois faire pas ça.

question: I will be able to. (indicatif futur simple) / I could. (conditionnel présent)
answer: Je pourrai. / Je pourrais.; Pronounced exactly the same ('pour-ray') because je/tu/il/elle/on/ils/elles in conditionnel présent sound exactly the same as je in futur simple - though spelled differently.; Remember 'ai' sounds like 'ay' in french - like j'ai.

question: I will eat. (indicatif futur simple) / They would eat. (conditionnel présent)
answer: Je mangerai. / Ils mangeraient.; Pronounced exactly the same ('man-jer-ray') because je/tu/il/elle/on/ils/elles in conditionnel présent sound exactly the same as je in futur simple - though spelled differently.; -ent is always silent on verbs

question: I will have more time. (indicatif futur simple) / I will know how to do it. (indicatif futur simple)
answer: J'aurai plus DE temps. / Je saurai comment faire.; NB: AVOIR and SAVOIR are usually conjugated in the same way - just add an S to the front for the SAVOIR version.

question: Elle has been working longer than me.
answer: Elle travaille depuis plus longtemps que moi.

question: We didn't have enough time.
answer: On n'a pas eu assez DE temps.; Even though temps is an exception when negated... (e.g. Je n'ai pas LE temps. = I do not have time.)... There is no exception when expressing equivalence.

question: It took too long.
answer: Ça a pris trop DE temps.; Use DE (instead of LE temps). The only time that le temps over-rides the generic DE is when it is negated with PAS (pas le temps).

question: It took 30 minutes.
answer: Ça a pris 30 minutes.

question: I quit. / I will quit. / I would quit.
answer: J'ai quitté. / Je quitterai. / Je quitterais.; QUITTER is the infinitive. It also means 'to leave'.

question: Using the verb ÉCOUTER... You would listen. / He would listen. (both conditionnel présent)
answer: Tu écouterais. / Il écouterait.; ('ay-coo-tuh-ray') Both sound exactly the same as Je version in futur simple (j'écouterai) - though they are spelled differently.

question: Using the verb CHANTER... They would sing. / You (formal/plural) would sing. (both conditionnel présent)
answer: Ils chanteraient. ('shon-tu-ray') / Vous chanteriez. ('shon-tu-ree-ay'); The ils version sounds exactly the same as the je version in futur simple (je chanterai) BUT the vous version sounds different because nous and vous versions do not follow the rule that je/tu/il/elle/on/ils/elles follow.

question: Using the verb VOIR... She would watch. / We (nous) would watch. (both conditionnel présent)
answer: Elle verrait. / Nous verrions.; VOIR is irregular in futur simple - we use the radical 'verr'.; Note that the pronunciation rule still holds: Elle verrait (She would watch) sounds the same as Je verrai (I will watch). BUT Nous verrions (We would watch) does not sound the same as Je verrai (I will watch) because nous and vous never follow the pronunciation rule.

question: You (familiar) would go. / You (formal/plural) would go. (both futur conditionnel présent)
answer: Tu irais. / Vous iriez.; ALLER is irregular in futur simple - we use the radical 'ir'.; The pronunciation similarities still hold. Tu irais (You would go) sounds the same as J'irai (I will go). Vous form sounds different - always does.

question: What is the 'conditionnel passé' verb tense?
answer: The conditionnel mood (a hypothesis) in the past tense. It is used to express: a regret/remorse + a rapproche (scolding someone) + uncertainty (journalists use it to report unconfirmed information).; To compare: conditionnel présent (a hypothetical action) is should do/ could do / would do. Conditionnel passé is the same but in the past: should have done / could have done / would have done.; For example: I would have returned the book (IF I had had time). The first phrase is conditionnel passé. The second phrase could be said or omitted.

question: How do you construct the 'conditionnel passé' verb tense?
answer: AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel présent + past participle; e.g. I would have done something. = J'AURAIS FAIT quelque chose.; The past participle is the same as passé composé. The pairing with avoir/être is the same as passé composé.

question: I would receive. + I would have received.
answer: Je reçevrais (conditionnel présent). + J'aurais reçu (conditionnel passé).

question: I would have written a letter.
answer: J'aurais écrit une lettre.; This is hypothetical in the past so use conditionnel passé (AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel présent + past participle).

question: They would have gone to the movies.
answer: Ils seraient allés au cinéma.; This is hypothetical in the past so use conditionnel passé.

question: I would have liked to discuss it with the saleswoman.
answer: J'aurais voulu/aimée (conditionnel passé) en discuter avec la vendeuse.

question: He would have become a doctor. + He would have liked to become a doctor.
answer: Il serait devenu (conditionnel passé) un médecin. + Il aurait aimée (conditionnel passé) devenir (2nd verb) médecin.; Both sentences are conditionnel passé. In the first sentence the conjugated verb is devenir. In the second sentence the conjugated verb is aimer (so devenir remains as infinitive).

question: I could have seen the coral reef.
answer: J'aurais pu voir le récif de corail.; Use conditionnel passé (AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel présent + past participle) to describe what should or could or would have happened.

question: She could have gone to the movies.
answer: Elle aurait pu (conditionnel passé) aller (infinitive) au cinéma.; This is special variation of conditionnel passé (could have): AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel présent (aurait) + PAST PARTICIPLE (pu from pouvoir) + INFINITIVE

question: I should have taken care of my body.
answer: J'aurais dû prendre soins de mon corps.; Use conditionnel passé (AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel présent + past participle) to describe what should or could or would have happened.

question: I should have known it.
answer: J'aurais dû (conditionnel passé) le savoir (infinitive).; This is special variation of conditionnel passé (should have): AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel présent (aurait) + PAST PARTICIPLE (dû from devoir) + INFINITIVE

question: You should have listened to me.
answer: Tu aurais dû m'écouter.; Use conditionnel passé (AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel présent + past participle) to describe what should or could or would have happened.; When speaking tu + aurais contracts to t'aurais. But never contract it in writing.

question: We should have sang a song.
answer: On aurait dû (conditionnel passé) chanter (infinitive) une chanson.; This is special variation of conditionnel passé (should have): AVOIR/ÊTRE conjugated in conditionnel présent (aurait) + PAST PARTICIPLE (dû from devoir) + INFINITIVE

question: She arrived yesterday (I think) but I'm not certain.
answer: Unconfirmed information triggers conditionnel passé: Elle serait arrivée hier mais je ne suis pas sûr.

question: It could be worse. + It could have been worse.
answer: Ça pourrait être pire. (conditionnel présent) + Ça aurait pu être pire. (conditionnel passé)

question: idiomatic way to express: It can't get any worse.
answer: On ne peut pas descendre plus bas.

question: What are the three combinations of tenses that one can use in dependent (If...) / independent phrases?
answer: There are 3 possibilities: 1) imparfait + conditionnel présent 2) plus que parfait + conditionnel passé 3) présent + futur simple; Remember to NEVER EVER use conditionnel mood in the same phrase as SI - it's redundant and very bad form. e.g. Si j'AVais (subordinate clause)... j'AURais (independant clause)... When educated speakers here SI j'AURais... (Si + conditionnel mood) it is like nails on a chalkboard.

question: If I had more time... I would dance every day.
answer: Si j'avais (indicatif imparfait) plus de temps... je dancerais (conditionnel présent) tous les jours.; SI and conditionnel mood verbs are never in the same phrase. That would be redundant because conditionnel mood implies the existence of an if-clause.; This example illustrates 1 of 3 possible pairings in French when using independent and dependent clauses: 1) imparfait + conditionnel présent 2) plus que parfait + conditionnel passé 3) présent + futur simple

question: If she had been saving money... she would go to the market.
answer: Si elle économisait (indicatif imparfait)... elle irait (conditionnel présent) au marché.; This example illustrates 1 of 3 possible pairings in French when using independent and dependent clauses: 1) imparfait + conditionnel présent 2) plus que parfait + conditionnel passé 3) présent + futur simple; Never use SI + conditionnel (it's redundant and very bad form). And never use futur proche in the subordinate clause.

question: If I had woken up earlier... I could have done the chores.
answer: Si je m'étais réveilée (plus que parfait)... j'aurais pu (conditionnel passé) faire le ménage.

question: If I had saved money... I would have gone to the market.
answer: Si j'avais économisé (plus que parfait)... je serais allé (conditionnel passé) au marché.; This example illustrates 1 of 3 possible pairings in French when using independent and dependent clauses: 1) imparfait + conditionnel présent 2) plus que parfait + conditionnel passé 3) présent + futur simple; Never use SI + conditionnel (it's redundant and very bad form). And never use futur proche in the subordinate clause.

question: If he saves money... he will go to the market.
answer: Si il économise (indicatif présent)... il ira (indicatif futur simple) au marché.; This example illustrates 1 of 3 possible pairings in French when using independent and dependent clauses: 1) imparfait + conditionnel présent 2) plus que parfait + conditionnel passé 3) présent + futur simple; Never use SI + conditionnel (it's redundant and very bad form). And never use futur proche in the subordinate clause.

question: If I had known the things that I know now... I would have gottena bachelors in finance.
answer: Si j'avais su (plus que parfait) les choses que je sais maintenant... j'aurais etudié (conditionnel passé) pour obtenir une licence en finance.

question: Unless she has her computer... she cannot work.
answer: Sauf si elle a (indicatif présent) son ordinateur... elle ne peut (indicatif présent) pas travailler.; Generally the consequence (she cannot work) is negated when using an unless (sauf si) phrase (unless she has her computer).; This example illustrates 1 of 3 possible pairings in French when using sauf si: 1) Sauf si + indicatif présent... + indicatif présent 2) Sauf si + indicatif présent... + indicatif futur 3) Sauf si + indicatif imparfait... + conditionnel présent

question: Unless I am near a cat... I will not sneeze.
answer: Sauf si je suis (indicatif présent) près d'un chat... je n'éternuerai pas (indicatif futur).; Generally the consequence (she cannot work) is negated when using an unless (sauf si) phrase (unless she has her computer).; This example illustrates 1 of 3 possible pairings in French when using sauf si: 1) Sauf si + indicatif présent... + indicatif présent 2) Sauf si + indicatif présent... + indicatif futur 3) Sauf si + indicatif imparfait... + conditionnel présent

question: I would not share my photos... unless I trusted the person.
answer: Je ne partegerais pas (conditionnel présent) mes photos... sauf si je faisais (indicatif imparfait) confiance À la personne.; Generally the consequence (she cannot work) is negated when using an unless (sauf si) phrase (unless she has her computer).; This example illustrates 1 of 3 possible pairings in French when using sauf si: 1) Sauf si + indicatif présent... + indicatif présent 2) Sauf si + indicatif présent... + indicatif futur 3) Sauf si + indicatif imparfait... + conditionnel présent

question: I will walk... unless is rains. Use both SAUF SI and À MOINS QUE.
answer: Je vais marcher... sauf s’il pleut (indicatif). + Je vais marcher... à moins qu’il pleuve (subjonctif).; Sauf si does not trigger subjonctif mood. À moins que does trigger subjonctif mood.

question: polite + politely
answer: poli(e) + poliment; Transform an adjective that ends in a vowel by adding -MENT. This ensures a vowel is present before -MENT ending.

question: for politeness / in order to be polite
answer: par politesse

question: impolite; Specify pronunciation.
answer: impoli(e); The first syllable is pronounced like ingénieur because there is only one M: 'uhm-poh-lee'.

question: You come with us? (formal and informal)
answer: Vous venez / Tu viens AVEC nous?

question: How do you ask politely: Should I (do something)?
answer: Devrais-je... (insert any infinitive verb)?; should = DEVOIR in conditionnel présent; Alternative: Dois-je ('dwaj')...? = Must I ...?

question: How do you ask politely: Do you have eggs (formal and informal)?
answer: Auriez-vous / Aurais-tu des œufs?; Verb is AVOIR. Use conditionnel mood to be polite.

question: How do you ask politely: May I / Can I... (do something)?
answer: Pourrais-je...? Use POUVOIR in the conditionnel présent to ask if you may do something. This is the best way to ask the question in formal and informal situations.; Rarely used ultra-formal alternative: Puis-je ('pweej')...? Je puis is a formal alternative to Je peux. It is literally just a different way to express 'I can'. But if you use inversion to ask a question then peux-je is impossible/forbidden. So one would have to use puis-je. But this is a very rare phrasing. Do not use this as a foreigner.

question: How do you ask politely: May I keep this? (e.g. a menu)
answer: Pourrais-je garder ça?; Use POUVOIR in the conditionnel présent tense to ask if you may do something.

question: How do you ask politely: Could you please open the door?
answer: Pourriez-vous / Pourrais-tu ouvrir la porte?; Verb is POUVOIR. Use conditionnel mood to be polite.

question: How do you ask politely: Would you like some water?
answer: Voudriez-vous / Voudrais-tu de l'eau?; Verb is VOULOIR. Use conditionnel mood to be polite.

question: What is the 'indicatif plus que parfait' (pluperfect) verb tense?
answer: 'Perfect' means 'completed' when talking about verb tenses. So use this tense to describe an event in the past that 'had taken' place and 'had been' completed BEFORE some other past event. Often the words AVANT or DÉJÀ are in the phrase. Generally another phrase using passé composé or imparfait must be present. The phrase in plus que parfait happens before.; Do not use this for something that happened independently or in the recent past (when you would use passè composé or imparfait instead).; In English we call this the 'past perfect' tense (e.g. I had been doing something).; In English we often use a simple past tense (e.g. passé composé or imparfait) for both events in the past. But in french you MUST use plus que parfait whenever you are describing an event that occurred before some other event (or context) in the past.

question: How do you construct the 'indicatif plus que parfait' verb tense?
answer: Same as passé composé but AVOIR and ÊTRE auxiliaries are conjugated au imparfait. Use the same past participle as passé composé.; e.g. I had been eating BEFORE you saw me. = J'avais mangé (plus que parfait) AVANT tu me voyais (imparfait).

question: She returned to Portugal because her visa had expired.
answer: Elle est rentrée (passé composé) au Portugal parce que son visa avait expiré (plus que parfait).; Use plus que parfait for a past event that occurred before some other past event.; Literally: Her visa had expired.

question: I read the book because I heard it was good.
answer: J'ai lu le livre parce que j'aVais entendu (plus que parfait) que c'était bon.; The second phrase (j'avais entendu) is conjugated in the plus que parfait (literally: I had heard...) because it is a past event that occurs before some other past event.

question: Yesterday I was sick because I had eaten oysters.
answer: Hier j'était (imparfait) malade parce que j'aVais mangé (plus que parfait) des huîtres.; Plus que parfait can be paired with passé composé or imparfait... as long as the plus que parfait phrase occured before the other phrase.

question: I had a horrible trip because I had forgotten my suitcases and I had gotten a headache.
answer: J'ai passé (passé composé) un séjour horrible parce que j'avais oublié (plus que parfait) mes valises et j'avais eu (plus que parfait) mal à la tête.; The phrase conjugated in plus que parfait can describe a discrete action or the context - as long as that phrase occurred before another action/context in the past.

question: I missed my interview because my train was cancelled.
answer: J'ai raté (passé composé) mon entretien d'embauche parce que mon train avait été (plus que parfait) annulé.; In this case there are two events in the past and they are sequential. Therefore the first event should use plus que parfait.

question: The train was cancelled. + The book was taken.
answer: Le train a été annulé. + Le livre a été pris.; In a vacuum passé composé is appropriate for both of these.

question: I was late to class because I woke up too late.
answer: J'étais en retard (imparfait) en classe parce que je m'étais réveillée (plus que parfait) trop tard.; The first event must be conjugated in plus que parfait (even if it is contextual instead of a discrete action). The second event can be imparfait or passé composé.

question: If I had found ten euros (then) I would have bought a coffee.
answer: Si j’aVais trouvé (plus que parfait) dix euros... j'auRais acheté (conditionnel passé) un café.; If a conditional phrase (if..) is in the past (e.g. If we had arrived earlier...) - instead of in the present tense (e.g. If we arrive early...) - then that phrase should use the plus que parfait tense. And that means that the resultant/hypothetical phrase (what would have happened if the if-statement was true) should use the conditionnel passé tense (would have/could have/should have).

question: If they had found ten euros (then) they would have bought a coffee.
answer: S'ils aVaient trouvé (plus que parfait) dix euros... ils auRaient acheté (conditionnel passé) un café.; Si contracts with any word that starts with a vowel.; NB: Never use IF in the same phrase as the conditionnel mood. That would be duplication because the conditionnel mood assumes a hypothetical.

question: We would have finished early if we had worked together.
answer: On auRait fini (conditionnel passé) si on aVait travaillé (plus que parfait) ensemble.; If a conditional phrase is in the past (if we had worked together) then that phrase should use the plus que parfait tense. That means that the resultant/hypothetical phrase (we would have finished earlier) should use the conditionnel passé tense (would have/could have/should have).

question: What is the 'indicatif futur antérieur' verb tense?
answer: It indicates an event in the future that happens before some other event. It's like the future version of plus que parfait. e.g. The box will have been delivered (futur antérieur) before the guests will arrive (futur simple).

question: How do you construct the 'indicatif futur antérieur' verb tense?
answer: auxiliary être/avoir au futur simple + participe passé; e.g. Tu seras sorti. = You will have gone out (before some other action).

question: I will leave when they (all female) have finished.
answer: Je sortirai quand‿elles‿auront fini ('kohn-Tehl-Zau-rohn-fih-nee').; auront fini is futur antérieur tense because it is an event that happens in the future but it happens before some other event in the future.; Remember that the D in quand sounds like a T when you make a liaison.

question: When robotics have penetrated all homes... we will not live in the same way.
answer: Quand la robotique aura pénétré (futur antérior) dans toutes les maisons... nous ne vivrons (futur simple) plus de la même manière.; There are two events in the future and one comes before the other (or one depends on the other). So use futur antérior (for the first) and futur simple (for the second).

question: I will have finished when you arrive.
answer: J'aurai fini (futur antérior) quand tu arrivera (futur simple).; There are two events in the future and one comes before the other (or one depends on the other). So use futur antérior (for the first) and futur simple (for the second).

question: If you come home late... I will have already crashed (gone to bed).
answer: Si tu rentres (indicatif présent) tard... je serai déja couché (futur antérior).; This is an example of pairing indicatif présent with futur antérior. We can only do this when the phrase using indicatif présent actually occurs in the future - because we need two events that happen in sequence (or with causality) in the future.

question: The world will be better when all children have received an education.
answer: Le monde ira (futur simple) mieux quand tous les enfants aura récévu un bonne education.; This is a typical construct for using futur antérior verb tense. One depends on the other so there is a squence of two events in the future. Use futur antérior (for the first) and futur simple (for the second).

question: It will be better when I find a job.
answer: Ça ira (futur simple) mieux quand j'aurai trouvé (futur antérior) un emploi.; This is a typical construct for using futur antérior verb tense. One depends on the other so there is a sequence of two events in the future. Use futur antérior (for the first) and futur simple (for the second).

question: It will be better when I speak french more fluently.
answer: Ça ira (futur simple) mieux quand j'aurai parlé plus couramment.; This is a typical construct for using futur antérior verb tense. One depends on the other so there is a sequence of two events in the future. Use futur antérior (for the first) and futur simple (for the second).

question: What are the three cases where it is required to use 'indicatif futur antérior' verb tense in French - where other languages (including English) do not use this or any perfect (completed) tense?
answer: 1) After conjonctives / conjonctive phrases. e.g. As soon as you HEAR it you must tell me. Conjugate HEAR in futur antérior (like 'have heard'). 2) When making an assumption about what happened in the past. e.g. I must have FORGOTTEN it. Conjugate FORGOTTEN in futur antérior (like 'have forgotten'). 3) Historical narratives. e.g. She PUBLISHED her first novel in 1962. Conjugate PUBLISHED in futur antérior (like 'have published').

question: As soon as you eat it... you must leave.
answer: Dès que tu l'aurais mangé (futur antérior)... tu dois partir.; Following a conjonctives / conjonctives phrase is 1 of 3 cases (in French) where we are required to use futur antérior - even though it is likely not required in other languages.; A short list of conjonctives / conjonctive phrases: après que + dès que / aussitôt que + quand / lorsque + une fois que

question: I cannot find my bag... I must have left it in the car.
answer: Je ne peux pas trouver mon sac... Je l'aurais laissé dans la voiture.; Assumptions about the past are 1 of 3 cases (in French) where we are required to use futur antérior - even though it is likely not required in other languages.

question: What are les temps composés?
answer: Verb tenses that use an auxiliary. e.g. passé composé + plus que parfait + futur antérieur. If a verb tense is composed (has an auxiliary) in one mood then it will also be composed in another mood.

question: What is a verb mood in the french language?
answer: 'des modes des verbes' are the 7 large subgroups of verb conjugations. Within each mode there may be multiple tenses.; For example: Conditionnel is a mood that contains 2 tenses: conditionnel présent and conditionnel passé. Participe is a verb mood that contains 2 tenses: participe présent and participe passé.; 4 of the moods are 'personnel'. 3 of the moods are 'impersonnel'.

question: List the 4 'modes personnel' (personal verb moods). Explain when they are used.
answer: 1) Indicatif: expresses reality and certainty; 2) Conditionnel: expresses a hypothesis that is (implicitly or explicitly) dependent on something else happening; 3) Subjonctif: expresses a 'sub-reality' - something that the speaker knows may not necessarily reflect reality; 4) Impératif: expresses a command

question: List the 3 'modes impersonnel' (impersonal verb moods). Explain when they are used.
answer: 1) Infinitif: the nominal form of a verb - it can even be the subject of a phrase  2) Participe: used to form the second half of all composed tenses 3) Gérondif: modifies a verb by expressing simultaneous actions of the how/why of how something happened; These verb modes do not agree in gender/number with a subject because they are impersonnel.

question: What is the 'subjonctif' verb mood?
answer: Transforming a verb into the subjonctif mood expresses that a phase does not necessarily reflect reality: doubt or impossibility or subjectivity (that it is subjective from the point of view of the speaker).; For example: I wish that you do not smoke. When saying this in French the verb(s) in the second half of the phrase (you do not smoke) would be conjugated in the subjonctif mood (not indicatif or conditionnel) because not smoking does not exist in reality - it is a wish in the thoughts of the speaker (subjectivity).; Sometimes the structure of a phrase makes conjugation in the subjonctif mood obligatory (previous example). Sometimes the use of the subjonctif is a choice of the speaker based on context (e.g. when the speaker wants to make it clear that the opinion they are expressing is subjective - not necessarily based in reality.)

question: When is the 'subjonctif' verb mood used?
answer: The more uncertainty that exists the more likely that the subjonctif is required - though it is not an exact science and sometimes a choice made by the speaker.; Some major categories (not exhaustive) obligate the subjonctif: 1) an obligation (or lack of obligation e.g. il ne faut pas que...) 2) a feeling / sentiment (Je suis heureuse que... + Je suis surpris(e)/choqué(e) que...) 3) judgement /appreciation (C'est bien que...) 4) a wish (Je veux/voudrais que...) 5) a possibility or doubt (C'est possible que... + J'ai doute que...) 6) when the speaker wants to insinuate that something may not be as it appears

question: What is the English equivalent of the 'subjonctif' verb mode?
answer: This mode does not exist (with direct translation) in English which is very important to keep in mind. In french the subjonctif mood is used to show that a statement is subjective - perhaps not fully based in reality.; If this subtlety is not taken into account in a translation (e.g. if one does not pick up on whether the indicatif or subjonctif was used) then the intention will be misunderstood.

question: Translate the following to use a) indicatif mood and b) subjonctif mood. Explain how the meaning changes. I am happy that you are happy.
answer: Indicatif: Je suis content(e) que tu es content(e). = I'm happy that you are a happy and I really believe that you are happy.; Subjonctif: Je suis content(e) que tu sois content(e). = I am happy that you are happy - but are you really happy?...I think that you might not be.; This is an example of a non-obligatory use of the subjonctif mood. The speaker chooses the subjonctif mood to throw doubt on the statement in the 2nd case.

question: How do you construct the 'subjonctif présent' verb tense?
answer: For the nous/vous forms: Use the radical from nous/vous au présent. Add imparfait endings. (e.g. venir -&gt venions + veniez); For je/tu/il/ils forms: 1) Use the radical from the ILS form au présent. Add the présent endings (e.g. venir -&gt ils viennent -&gt vienn).; So for most verbs the subjonctif sounds like the ils/elles forms in indicatif présent.

question: How do you construct the 'subjonctif passé' verb tense?
answer: For passé composé: Conjugate the auxiliary (avoir or être) in subjonctif mood. Then add the participe passé as you would in passé composé.; For imparfait: Use the subjonctif base and add the subjonctif imparfait endings: je: asse + tu: asses + il: ât + nous: assions + vous: assiez + ils: assent

question: How do you construct the 'subjonctif futur' verb tense?
answer: This does not exist. When you use the subjonctif you are acknowledging that the statement is virtual (may not reflect reality) and that means for right now or any time in the future. So if you have a phrase in a future tense and you need to use the subjonctif mood... then simply use subjonctif présent.; This is how it works in English too. e.g. I wish that you did not smoke (now or in the future - this part is implicit).

question: What are the requirements of using the subjonctif mood?
answer: Three requirements: 1) A subjonctive phrase is dependent on another phrase triggering the subjonctive tense. e.g. I wish that you have a good life. 'I wish' is indicatif présent but the verb 'to wish' triggers the subjonctive mood in the subsequent dependent phrase: that you have a good life.; 2) A subjonctive phrase always starts with the word 'que' or 'qui'. e.g. Je souhaite... QUE vous ayez (avoir in subjonctive) une belle vie.; 3) The independent phrase (that triggers the subsequent subjonctif) must have a subject that is different from the subject in the subjonctif phrase. e.g. I wish that I have a good life. You can't use the subjonctif in this case because the subject of both phrases is the same.

question: How do you differentiate between verbs that trigger the subjonctif vs those that do not?
answer: The level of certainty (or proximity to reality) and emotion determines whether or not to use the subjonctif. Statements without emotion and expressing a high level of certainty (e.g. I am sure that... + It is evident that... + It is very probably that...) do NOT trigger the subjonctif. Simple opinions and observations do NOT trigger subjonctif because they are not emotional and the statements are fairly certain - what a person thinks is actually what they think. The following do NOT trigger the subjonctif: Je pense que... + Je crois que... + Je trouve que... + J'espère que... + J'ai l'impression que... ; However when you negate these statements then they indicate uncertainty/doubts. So then they DO trigger subjonctif: Je NE pense PAS que... + Je NE crois PAS que... + Je NE trouve PAS que... + Je N'espère PAS que... + J'ai doute que...; The presence of emotions makes the subordinate clause more uncertain/subjective (potentially further from reality). So the following trigger the subjonctif: J'ai peur que... + Je suis outré(e) que...

question: Which of these trigger the subjonctif: J'aimerais que... vs J'espère que...
answer: J'aimerais que... (I would like that...) triggers the subjonctif because it is a wish and the dependent phrase probably differs a lot from the current reality. J'espère que... (I hope that...) is somewhat of an exception. It does not trigger the subjonctif unless it is negated.

question: Which of these trigger the subjonctif: C'est bien que... vs Il semble que...
answer: C'est bien que... (It's good that...) triggers the subjonctif because it is a personal judgement. Il semble que... (It seems that...) does not trigger the subjonctif. It is a straightforward remark/observation.; NB: C'est evident que... does not trigger subjonctif because it is also a remark/observation and it indicates certainty.

question: Which of these trigger the subjonctif: C'est possible que... vs C'est probable que... vs C'est peu probable que...
answer: C'est possible que... triggers subjonctif because there is lack of certainty.; C'est probable que... does NOT trigger subjonctif because there is enough certainty in the phrase that follows - it is probable.; C'est peu probable que... does trigger the subjonctif because there is a fair amount of uncertainty in the statement that follows - it's not probable.

question: Which of these trigger the subjonctif: Je suis desolé(e) que... vs Je demande que...
answer: Both trigger the subjonctif. Je suis désolé(e) que (I'm sorry that) is a sentiment. Je demande que (I order that) is an order/demand.

question: Conjugate parler (regular in indicatif) in the subjonctif présent.
answer: que je parle ('shhhhhparl') + que tu parles + qu'il/elle/on parle + que nous parlions + que vous parliez + qu'ils/elles parlent (-ent is silent for all verbs); PARLER is regular in indicatif présent AND au présent subjonctif.

question: Conjugate finir (regular in indicatif) in the subjonctif présent.
answer: que je finisse + que tu finisses + qu'il/elle/on finisse + que nous finissions + que vous finissiez + qu'ils/elles finissent (-ent is silent for all verbs); FINIR is regular in indicatif présent AND au présent subjonctif.

question: Conjugate venir (irregular in indicatif) in the subjonctif présent.
answer: que je vienne + que tu viennes + qu'il/elle/on vienne + que nous venions + que vous veniez + qu'ils/elles viennent (-ent is silent for all verbs); VENIR is irregular in indicatif présent but it is completely regular in subjonctif présent.

question: Conjugate prendre (irregular in indicatif) in the subjonctif présent.
answer: que je prenne + que tu prennes + qu'il/elle/on prenne + que nous prenions + que vous preniez + qu'ils/elles prennent (-ent is silent for all verbs); PRENDRE is irregular in indicatif présent but it is completely regular in subjonctif présent.

question: Conjugate être in subjonctif présent. It is completely irregular in subjonctif.
answer: Pronounced 'SWA': que je sois ('swa') + que tu sois + qu'il/elle/on soit + que nous soyons + que vous soyez + qu'ils/elles soient (-ent is silent for all verbs)

question: Conjugate avoir in subjonctif présent. It is completely irregular in subjonctif.
answer: nous/vous forms are the only times we hear the 'Y'. Otherwise just pronounce the hard A ('ay'): que j'aie + que tu aies + qu'il/elle/on ait + que nous ayons (add Y sound) + que vous ayez (add Y sound) + qu'ils/elles aient (-ent is silent for all verbs)

question: Conjugate aller in subjonctif présent. It is completely irregular in subjonctif.
answer: nous/vous forms are the only times we hear the 'L'. Otherwise just pronounce the hard I ('eye'): que j'aille + que tu ailles + qu'il/elle/on aille + que nous allions (add L sound) + que vous alliez (add L sound) + qu'ils/elles aillent (-ent is silent for all verbs)

question: Conjugate faire in subjonctif présent. It is completely irregular in subjonctif.
answer: que je fasse + que tu fasses + qu'il/elle/on fasse + que nous fassions + que vous fassiez + qu'ils/elles fassent (-ent is silent for all verbs)

question: Conjugate pouvoir in subjonctif présent. It is completely irregular in subjonctif.
answer: que je puisse + que tu puisses + qu'il/elle/on puisse + que nous puissions + que vous puissiez + qu'ils/elles puissent (-ent is silent for all verbs)

question: It is possible that you will never return.
answer: C'est possible que tu ne reviennes jamais.; C'est possible que triggers the subjonctif because there is enough uncertainty in the dependent phrase. But if you had said 'It is probable that...' then there is too much certainty to use the subjonctif.; REVENIR is the infinitive.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: I'm not certain that he remembers it.
answer: Je ne suis pas certaine qu'il s'en souvienne.; The expression of uncertainty triggers the subjonctif in the second phrase. SOUVENIR is conjugated exactly like VENIR - but remember that it is reflexive.

question: I am convinced that...
answer: Je suis convaincue que...; This does not trigger the subjonctif because it indicates a high level of certainty in whatever phrase follows.

question: It is required that the president listen to the citizens.
answer: Il faut que le président ecoute les citoyens.

question: It is not required that we do the homework.
answer: Il ne faut pas qu'on fasse les devoirs.; Obligations - even when negated - (e.g. It's necessary/essential/required that...) trigger the subjonctif.

question: It is necessary that police do not violate the law.
answer: Il est nécessaire que la police ne viole pas le loi.; Obligations (e.g. It's necessary/essential/required that...) trigger the subjonctif.

question: It is not essential that students ask questions.
answer: Il n'est pas indispensable que les étudiants posent des questions.; Obligations - even when negated - (e.g. It's necessary/essential/required that...) trigger the subjonctif.

question: It is fundamental that we test our code.
answer: Il est fondamental qu'on teste notre code.; Obligations (e.g. It's necessary/essential/required that...) trigger the subjonctif.

question: I like that you swim. + I like that I swim.
answer: J'aime que tu nages (subjonctif). + J'aime nager (infinitive).; In the second phrase we replace the subjonctif phrase with an infinitive because the subjects of the two phrases are the same. In order to use the subjonctif the subjects of the two phrases must be different.

question: I prefer (indicatif présent) that you go to the park (présent subjonctif).
answer: Je préfère que tu ailles (subjonctif) au parc.; NB: préférer has a slight variation (change accent aigu to accent grave) au présent in all but the nous and vous forms.; The expression of a preference (I prefer) triggers the subjonctif in the phrase (that you go to the park).; ALLER is irregular in subjonctif.

question: I would prefer (conditionnel présent) that you go to the park (présent subjonctif).
answer: Je préférerais que tu ailles (subjonctif) au parc.; NB: The change of accent in conjugation of préférer is only applicable in indicatif présent so no change to the accent in this case (conditionnel présent).; Statements in both the indicatif and conditionnel moods can trigger the subjonctif in the second phrase.; ALLER is irregular in subjonctif.

question: My preference is X.
answer: Ma préférence est X.

question: She wants the meal to be ready by 8 o'clock.
answer: Elle veut que la repa soit (ÊTRE au subjonctif) prête pour huit heures.; VOULOIR triggers the subjonctive. And we can use the subjonctive because the subjects of the two phrases (she and the meal) are different.

question: She wants to please everyone.
answer: Elle veut faire plaisir à tout le monde.; 'She wants...' would trigger the subjonctive. But we can't use that because the subject of the two phrases (she and she) are the same. So just use the inifinitive to express the desire.

question: How do you use the subjonctif for something in the past (e.g. I wished that you told me.)?
answer: Use passé composé. Conjugate the auxiliary in the subjonctif. The past participle stays the same.; When you use the subjonctif mood in the past tense you must use passé composé. You cannot use imparfait.

question: How do you use the subjonctif for something in the future (e.g. It's necessary that you take the bus tomorrow.)?
answer: There is no subjonctif futur tense. So use subjonctif présent.; Il faut que tu prennes (subjonctif present) le bus demain.

question: I must cry.
answer: Il fait que je pleure (subjonctif).; This is by far the most common way of expressing that you must do something (not with devoir and not with avoir besoin).; The literal translation of 'il fait' is 'it is required'. Obligations trigger the subjonctif in the subsequent phrase (e.g. Il fait que + SUBJONCTIF phrase).

question: I hope that the sky is blue.
answer: J'espère que le ciel est (indicatif présent) bleu.; ESPÉRER (to hope) does NOT trigger the subjonctif mood. It is an exception to the subjonctif rules. So we use indicatif présent instead here.

question: They hope that you will eat well.
answer: Ils/Elles espèrent que tu mangeras (indicatif futur simple) bien.; ESPÉRER  (to hope) does NOT trigger the subjonctif mood. It is an exception to the subjonctif rules. So we use indicatif futur simple instead here.

question: I think that we have a cat.
answer: Je pense qu'on a un chat (AVOIR in indicatif présent).; PENSER does not trigger the subjonctif mood when it is used in the positive sense.; NB: PENSER does trigger the subjonctif mood when it is negated.

question: I do not think that the president is close to the people.
answer: Je ne pense pas que le président soit (ÊTRE in subjonctif présent) proche de gens.; PENSER does not trigger subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense. But PENSER does trigger the subjonctif mood when it is negated.

question: I believe that education is a human right.
answer: Je crois que l'éducation est (ÊTRE in indicatif présent) un droit humain.; CROIRE does NOT trigger the subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense.; NB: CROIRE does triggers the subjonctif mood when it is negated.

question: I do not believe that you have a dog.
