answer: Je ne crois pas que tu aies (AVOIR au présent subjonctif) un chien.; CROIRE does not trigger the subjonctif when it is used in the positive sense. But it does trigger the subjonctif mood when it is negated.

question: I have doubt about a word.
answer: J'ai doubt SUR un mot.

question: I doubt that it is raining.
answer: Je doute qu'il pleuve (présent subjonctif).; PLEUVOIR is conjugated in the subjonctif mood because the first phrase expresses doubt/uncertainty.

question: I suspect that it is raining.
answer: Je ME doute qu'il pleut (indicatif présent).; Je me doute que; SE DOUTER = to suspect. It does NOT trigger the subjonctif mood even though DOUTER (non-reflexive form) does trigger the subjonctif mood.

question: It's better that you come.
answer: Il vaut mieux que tu viennes (subjontif présent) avec nous.; The first phrase expresses a wish (not a certainty) so it triggers the subjonctif mood.

question: I would like that you come with us.
answer: Je voudrais que tu viennes (subjonctif présent) avec nous.; The first phrase expresses a which (not a certainty) so it triggers the subjonctif mood.

question: What do you want me to say?
answer: Que veux tu que je dise (subjonctif présent )?; The subjonctif mood is triggered because the affirmative version would be: You want that I (do something).

question: What do you want me to do?
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous voulez que ça me fasses (subjonctif présent)?; The subjonctif mood is triggered because the affirmative version would be: You want that I (do something).

question: What is the common way to express: X is required. / X is necessary.; What is the infinitive of the verb?
answer: Il faut...; FALLOIR is the infinitive. The meaning is similar to DEVOIR but FALLOIR is only ever conjugated for 3rd person singular (il/elle/on). FALLOIR communicates that some ambiguous 'it' or 'one' must be or do something.

question: idiomatic way to express: It is a must-have.
answer: C'est incontournable.; incontournable = unavoidable

question: One must be determined to work here.
answer: Il faut être déterminé(e) pour travailler ici.; IL FAUT + ÊTRE + any adjective is a good way to express: One must be X...; This is using the pattern: Il faut + INFINITIVE which avoids the subjonctif.

question: It is important that the muscles are warm before stretching.
answer: C'est IMPORTANT QUE les muscles soient (subjonctif) chauds avant les étirements.; Any kind of opinion like this (e.g. It is critical that...) triggers the subjonctif.

question: What are four progressively direct/confrontational ways to say: You must go to the doctor.
answer: Using FALLOIR is always the least confrontational. 1) The softest possible is IL FAUT + INFINITIV: Il faut aller chez médecin.; 2) The next stronger option is IL FAUT QUE + SUBJONCTIF PHRASE: Il faut QUE tu ailles (subjonctif) chez le médecin.; 3) Phrases stronger than the previous two do not us FALLOIR: e.g. Il est nécessaire que...; 4) The most confrontational phrases use DEVOIR: Tu doit aller chez le médecin.

question: What are two generalized / non-aggressive ways to say: You/One must take the medicine.
answer: Using FALLOIR is always the least confrontational. 1) least direct: Il faut prendre le médicament. 2) more direct: Il faut QUE vous preniez (subjonctif) le médicament.; The latter is slightly more targeted/personal and with a higher sense of urgency.; Both are much less harsh than using DEVOIR: Vous devez prendre le médicament.

question: What are two generalized / non-aggressive ways to say: We must win this match.
answer: Using FALLOIR is always the least confrontational. 1) least direct: Il faut gagner ce match. 2) more direct: Il faut QU'on gagne (subjonctif) ce match.; The latter is slightly more targeted/personal and with a higher sense of urgency.; Both are much less harsh than using DEVOIR: On doit gagner ce match.

question: What is a very direct / confrontational way to say: You must eat healthily.
answer: Using DEVOIR is always the most confrontational: Vous devez manger sainement.; This is much more direct than: Il faut manager sainement. or Il faut que vous manger sainement.

question: Using FALLOIR what are two ways to say: You/One must rest.
answer: 1) Il faut SE reposer. (more generalized / less aggressive); 2) Il faut TE/VOUS reposer. (still generalized but slightly more personalized / confrontational and with higher sense of urgency); SE REPOSER is reflexive. This means that there is an additional layer of subtlety that can be used simply by changing whether or not the reflexive pronoun is conjugated.; Both options are less confrontational than using Il faut que...

question: I must wait.
answer: Il faut que j'attende.; It is more common to express this using FALLOIR (instead of using DEVOIR).; Il faut que triggers the subjonctif so j'attende is in the subjonctif form.

question: You had to do your homework before going out.
answer: More targeted with high sense of urgency: Il fallait (FALLOIR in imparfait) que tu fasses (subjonctif) tes devoirs avant de sortir.; More generalized alternative: Il fallait faire tes devoirs avant de sortir. This translates more to 'it was required to do our/your homework...'; FALLOIR alone signifies a general requirement. FALLOIR + QUE is a very targeted and personal statement.

question: Using falloir in imparfait: It was required to sleep. + I (emphasis on I) really needed to sleep.
answer: Il fallait dormir. + Il fallait que je dorme (subjonctif).; FALLOIR alone signifies a general requirement. FALLOIR + QUE + SUBJONCTIF is still polite but more targeted and with a higher sense of urgency.

question: Using falloir in conditionnel présent: We should sleep. + I should sleep.
answer: Il faudrait dormir. + Il faudrait que je dors (subjonctif).; FALLOIR alone signifies a general requirement. FALLOIR + QUE + SUBJONCTIF is still polite but more targeted and with a higher sense of urgency.

question: It was required that I come home before midnight.
answer: Il fallait que je revienne (subjonctif) avant minuit.

question: He left even though I told him to stay.
answer: Il est parti BIEN QUE je lui aie (subjonctif) dit de rester.; BIEN QUE = though / although / even though / altogether. It always triggers the subjonctif.; When you use the subjonctif in the past tense you must use passé composé. You cannot use imparfait.

question: I dance tango. + I dance ballet.
answer: Je danse LE tango. + Je danse LA danse classique.; DANSER does not use a preposition. So the object only requires it's article (le/la/l') - not du/de la.

question: Two ways to express: I learn tango so that we may dance together.
answer: J'apprendrai le tango AFIN QUE (or POUR QUE) nous dansions (subjonctif) ensemble.; To express 'so that / in order to...' use either AFIN QUE or POUR QUE. Both are followed by complete phrases in the subjonctif mood (because it is something that is imagined); Alternatives that also trigger the subjonctif: en sorte que (so that) + vu que (given that).

question: Two ways to express: We will leave now so that you are on time.
answer: Nous partirons maintenant AFIN QUE (or POUR QUE) tu sois (subjonctif) à l’heure.; To express 'so that / in order to...' use either AFIN QUE or POUR QUE. Both are followed by complete phrases in the subjonctif mood (because it is something that is imagined); Alternatives that also trigger the subjonctif: en sorte que (so that) + vu que (given that).

question: Two ways to express: I will do it so that we can leave.
answer: Je le ferai AFIN QUE (or POUR QUE) nous puissions (subjonctif) partir.; To express 'so that / in order to...' use either AFIN QUE or POUR QUE. Both are followed by complete phrases in the subjonctif mood (because it is something that is imagined); Alternatives that also trigger the subjonctif: en sorte que (so that) + vu que (given that).

question: to strive to do something
answer: se donner faire quelque chose; e.g. Il se donne améliorer ses compétences. = He strives to improve his skills.; se donner = to strive; s'adonner = to give oneself over completely to a person or thing

question: to make it one's aim/goal/objective to do something
answer: se donner pour mission/but/objectif DE faire quelque chose; e.g. Elle se donne pour but DE réussir l'examen. = She makes it her goal to pass the exam.

question: to give/bring meaning to something
answer: donner du sens à quelque chose

question: to give oneself completely over to a person or thing
answer: s'adonner; se donner = to strive; s'adonner = to give oneself over completely to a person or thing

question: What are the grammatical terms used to refer to 1) phrases that reference a time before 2) phrases that reference a time after?
answer: Anteriority: phrases that reference a time before (e.g. Before the test... Before going to school... Before he turns...); Posteriority: phrases that reference a time after (e.g. After the test... After going to school... After he turns...); In English the grammatical structures of phrases in anteriority and posteriority are the same. In French they are different.

question: Before the thing... + After the thing...
answer: Avant la chose... + Après la chose...; When there is only a noun (no verb at all) following before/after then there is no preposition required. There is no difference between avant and après in this situation.

question: Before covid... + After covid...
answer: Avant le covid... + Après le covid...; avant/après + noun: no preposition required

question: Before doing the thing...
answer: Two possibilities when avant is followed by a verb: 1) The verb (doing) occurs in past: Avant D'avoir fait la chose...  2) The verb (doing) occurs in the present or future: Avant DE faire la chose...; If the event occurred in the past: AVANT + DE + PAST INFINITIVE (auxiliary infinitive + participe passé). If the event occured in present/future: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE.; NB: This structure can only be used when the subject of both phrases is the same: Before sleeping I brush my teeth. If the subjects are different (e.g. Before the cat sleeps I pet it.) then you must use AVANT QUE + subjonctif.

question: After doing the thing...
answer: One possibility when après is followed by a verb: Après avoir fait la chose... (no DE); Regardless of when the event occurred: APRÈS + PAST INFINITIVE (auxiliary infinitive + participe passé) because we almost always assume that this event occurred in the past.; If we used avant (instead of après) then there are two different possibilities depending on when the event occurred.;  NB: This structure can only be used when the subject of both phrases is the same: After sleeping I feel better. If the subjects are different (e.g. After the cat sleeps I feed it.) then you must use APRÈS QUE + indicatif.

question: Before having covid...
answer: Two possibilities when avant is followed by a verb: 1) The verb (having) occurs in past: Avant D'avoir eu le covid...  2) The verb (having) occurs in present or future: Avant D'avoir le covid...; If the event occurred in the past: AVANT + DE + PAST INFINITIVE (auxiliary infinitive + participe passé). If the event occured in present/future: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE.; NB: Avant uses DE. Après does not.

question: After having covid...
answer: One possibility when après is followed by a verb: Après avoir eu le covid... (no DE); Regardless of when the event occurred: APRÈS + PAST INFINITIVE (auxiliary infinitive + participe passé) because we almost always assume that this event occured in the past.; If we used avant (instead of après) then there are two different possibilities depending on when the event occurred.; NB: Avant uses DE. Après does not.

question: Before going to the beach...
answer: Two possibilities when avant is followed by a verb: 1) The verb (going) occurs in the past: Avant D'être allé(e) à la plage... 2) The verb (going) occurs in the present or future: Avant D'aller à la plage...; If the event occurred in the past: AVANT + DE + PAST INFINITIVE (auxiliary infinitive + participe passé). If the event occured in present/future: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE.; NB: Avant uses DE. Après does not.

question: Before visiting my parents...
answer: Two possibilities when avant is followed by a verb: 1) The verb (visiting) occurs in the past: Avant D'avoir rendu visite À mes parents...  2) The verb (visiting) occurs in the present or future: Avant DE rendre visite À mes parents...; If the event occurred in the past: AVANT + DE + PAST INFINITIVE (auxiliary infinitive + participe passé). If the event occured in present/future: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE.; NB: Avant uses DE. Après does not.

question: Before making a decision...
answer: Two possibilities when avant is followed by a verb: 1) The verb (taking) occurs in the past: Avant D'avoir pris une décision...  2) The verb (taking) occurs in the present or future: Avant DE prendre une décision...

question: Before getting up...
answer: Two possibilities when avant is followed by a verb: 1) The verb (getting up) occurs in the past: Avant DE s'être levé(e)...  2) The verb (getting up) occurs in the present or future: Avant DE se lever...; If the event occurred in the past: AVANT + DE + PAST INFINITIVE (auxiliary infinitive + participe passé). If the event occured in present/future: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE.; NB: Avant uses DE. Après does not.; If the verb is reflexive then the reflexive pronoun must adapt to agree with the subject in the linked phrase.

question: Before moving (to a new city)...
answer: Two possibilities when avant is followed by a verb: 1) The verb (moving) occurs in the past: Avant DE s'être installé(e)... 2) The verb (moving) occurs in the present or future: Avant DE s'installer...; When using reflexive verbs with avant or aprés... the reflexive pronoun must agree with the subject of the linked phrase. e.g. Avant de t' (to agree with tu in the linked phrase) installer à Berlin tu acheteras une maison. = Before moving to Berlin you will buy a house.

question: After drinking wine...
answer: One possibility when après is followed by a verb: Après avoir bu du vin...; Regardless of when the event occurred: APRÈS + PAST INFINITIVE (auxiliary infinitive + participe passé); If we used avant (instead of après) then there are two different possibilities.; NB: Avant uses DE. Après does not.

question: After passing the B1 exam...
answer: One possibility when après is followed by a verb: Après avoir réussi l'examen B1...; Regardless of when the event occurred: APRÈS + PAST INFINITIVE (auxiliary infinitive + participe passé); If we used avant (instead of après) then there are two different possibilities.; NB: Avant uses DE. Après does not.

question: After studying French...
answer: One possibility when après is followed by a verb: Aprés avoir étudié français...; Alternative: Après mes études de français... (This simplifies the phrase by using après + noun format.)

question: After entering the room...
answer: One possibility when après is followed by a verb: Après être entré(e)...; Regardless of when the event occurred: APRÈS + PAST INFINITIVE (auxiliary infinitive + participe passé); If we used avant (instead of après) then there are two different possibilities.; NB: Avant uses DE. Après does not.

question: After moving to Paris...
answer: One possibility when après is followed by a verb: Après s'être installé(e)...; When using reflexive verbs with avant or aprés... the reflexive pronoun must agree with the subject of the linked phrase. e.g. Après t' (to agree with tu in the linked phrase) être installés à Berlin tu acheteras une maison. = After moving to Berlin you will buy a house.

question: before we met
answer: AVANT QU'on se soit rencontrés (subjonctif passé with a reflexive verb); Avant que triggers subjonctif. Après que does not.

question: Before my uncle died... + After my uncle died...
answer: Avant QUE mon oncle soit décédé (subjonctif passé)... + Après que mon oncle est décédé (indicatif)...; Avant que triggers subjonctif. Après que does not.

question: Before Julien does the thing... + After Julien does the thing...
answer: Avant QUE Julien fasse (subjonctif) la chose... + Après QUE Julien fait (indicatif) la chose...; When avant/après are followed by a phrase (subject + verb) then we no longer use infinitives and we treat them differently: 1) AVANT QUE + subjonctif (because it will not have happened yet so there is less certainty)  2) APRÈS QUE + indicatif (because it will have happened so there is more certainty); NB: Many people do not know that après que does not trigger subjonctif mood so you will hear après que + subjonctif in spoken french (but it is incorrect).

question: We must go to the store before he makes the bread.
answer: On doit aller au magasin AVANT QU'il fasse (subjonctif) le pain.; When avant is followed by a phrase (subject + verb) then the formula is: AVANT QUE + subjonctif (because it will not have happened yet so there is less certainty); Remember that the subjonctif requires that the subjects of the two phrases are different. If the subjects are the same then reformat the phrase to use AVANT DE etc.

question: We call her before she can leave.
answer: On l'appele AVANT QU'elle puisse (subjonctif) partir.; When avant is followed by a phrase (subject + verb) then the formula is: AVANT QUE + subjonctif (because it will not have happened yet so there is less certainty); Remember that the subjonctif requires that the subjects of the two phrases are different. If the subjects are the same then reformat the phrase to use AVANT DE etc.

question: Before I make a decision it's necessary to visit Marseille.
answer: AVANT QUE je prenne (subjonctif) une décision il faut ('ee-foh' omit the L) visiter Marseille.; When avant is followed by a phrase (subject + verb) then the formula is: AVANT QUE + subjonctif (because it will not have happened yet so there is less certainty); Remember that the subjonctif requires that the subjects of the two phrases are different. If the subjects are the same then reformat the phrase to use AVANT DE etc.

question: I call him after the dog yells.
answer: Je l'appelle APRÈS QUE le chien crie (indicatif).; When après is followed by a phrase (subject + verb) then the formula is: APRÈS QUE + indicatif (because it will have happened so there is more certainty); NB: Many people do not know that après que does not trigger subjonctif mood so you will hear après que + subjonctif in spoken french (but it is incorrect).

question: After I take a coffee the training can begin.
answer: APRÈS QUE je prends (indicatif) l'entraînement peut commencer.; When après is followed by a phrase (subject + verb) then the formula is: APRÈS QUE + indicatif (because it will have happened so there is certainty); NB: Many people do not know that après que does not trigger subjonctif mood so you will hear après que + subjonctif in spoken french (but it is incorrect).

question: We began to eat lunch after Paul arrived.
answer: On a commencé à déjeuner APRÈS QUE Paul était arrivé (indicatif plus que parfait because two actions in the past).; When après is followed by a phrase (subject + verb) then the formula is: APRÈS QUE + indicatif (because it will have happened so there is more certainty); NB: Many people do not know that après que does not trigger subjonctif mood so you will hear après que + subjonctif in spoken french (but it is incorrect).

question: We took the train before he ate lunch. + We took the train before eating lunch.
answer: Nous avons pris le train AVANT QU'il ne déjeune (subjonctif). + Nous avons pris le train AVANT DE déjeuner (DE + infinitive).; The first phrase triggers subjonctif because of the use of AVANT QUE and because the two subjects are different. In the second phrase the subjects of the phrases are the same. So we replace subjonctif with DE + INFINITIVE.

question: Idiomatic way to express: It may be that she is late.
answer: Il se peut qu'elle soit (subjonctif) en retard.; Il se peut que (or Il se pourrait que) is the very idiomatic way to express possibility or uncertainty. It triggers subjonctif. Usually this phrase is used to contradict something you said previously.

question: Idiomatic way to express: It may be that I can come now! (after refusing an invitation earlier)
answer: Il se pourrait que je puisse venir.; Il se peut que (or Il se pourrait que) is the very idiomatic way to express possibility or uncertainty. It triggers subjonctif. Usually this phrase is used to contradict something you said previously.

question: What is the difference between a gerund and a present participle in English?
answer: They are spelled exactly the same: verb base + ING (e.g. giving + waiting + swimming). In english gerunds act as nouns (e.g. I enjoy swimming.) Swimming is the direct object in this sentence. In english present participles act as adjectives (e.g. the waiting person + an interesting film) or verb tenses (e.g. I was waiting.).

question: What is the difference between 'gérondif' and 'participe' in French?
answer: Gérondif and Participe are both verb moods. They each contain two tenses: présent + passé.; The participe présent is the base of nous-form (indicatif présent) + ANT (e.g. vivre -&gt vivons -&gt vivant).; In french... When used alone (without 'en') the participe présent modifies a noun by explaining what the noun is doing or the reason why something is happening. e.g. We saw Jean eating. = On a vu Jean mangeant. Here eating modifies the nearest noun (Jean).; The gérondif présent is formed by EN + participe présent (e.g. en mangeant). Gérondif présent modifies a verb. e.g. We saw him while eating. = On l'a vu EN mangeant. Here eating is an additional action taken by we.; Generally the gérondif is used when speaking and the participe présent is only used in writing (often for literary effect) - it sounds odd when spoken. e.g. Regardant la lune... = Looking at the moon...

question: What is the difference between gerunds in English and gérondif in French?
answer: In english the definition of a gerund is a verb acting as a noun. e.g. I like swimming. Swimming is an english gerund acting as a noun. It is the direct object (a noun) of the verb.; But in french neither 'gérondif présent' nor 'participe présent' can act as a noun. e.g. I like swimming. = J'aime nager. In french we use the infinitive mood (instead of gérondif or participe moods) to talk about a verb as a noun.

question: What are the participes présents for these verbs: choisir + sortir?
answer: choisir: choisissant + sortir: sortant; Choisir is a regular -IR verb. Indicatif présent: nous choisissons. So the base is: choisiss. choisiss + ant = choisissant.; Sortir is not a regular -IR verb. Indicatif présent: nous sortons. So the base is: sort. sort + ant = sortant

question: What are the participes présents for these verbs: prendre + faire + aller?
answer: prendre: prenant + faire: faisant + aller: allant

question: What are the participes présents for these verbs: être + avoir + savoir?
answer: These are the only irregular participes présents: être: étant + avoir: ayant + savoir: sachant

question: The woman who speaks... + The woman speaking...
answer: La femme qui parle... + La femme parlant...; You can think of participe mood verbs as replacing QUI (when they describe what a thing is doing) or COMME/CAR/PARCE QUE (when they describe the cause of something).

question: The man living in Canada... he has a strong accent.
answer: L'homme venant au Canada... il a un accent fort.; You can think of participe mood verbs as replacing QUI (when they describe what a thing is doing) or COMME/CAR/PARCE QUE (when they describe the cause of something).

question: The sleeping dogs are quiet.
answer: Les chiens dormant (no EN before dormant) sont tranquilles.; Use only the participe présent (without EN) because DORMANT modifies a noun (les chien) - not another verb.

question: The travelers coming from Europe are tired.
answer: Les voyageurs venant (no EN before venant) de l’Europe sont fatigués.; Use only the participe présent (without EN) because VENANT modifies a noun (les voyageurs) - not another verb.

question: Living in the city... we pay expensive rent.
answer: Vivant en ville... nous payons un loyer élevé.; You can think of participe mood verbs as replacing QUI (when they describe what a thing is doing) or COMME/CAR/PARCE QUE (when they describe the cause of something). In this case it replaces PARCE QUE (parce que nous vivons en ville)

question: Having the need for money... I look for a job.
answer: Ayant (partipe présent) besoin d'argent... Je cherche un emploi. OR Nécissant d'argent... ; You can think of participe mood verbs as replacing QUI (when they describe what a thing is doing) or COMME/CAR/PARCE QUE (when they describe the cause of something). In this case it replaces PARCE QUE (parce que j'ai besoin d'argent)

question: The post being interesting... I read it completely.
answer: Le poste étant (participe présent) intéressant... je l'ai lu complètement.; You can think of participe mood verbs as replacing QUI (when they describe what a thing is doing) or COMME/CAR/PARCE QUE (when they describe the cause of something). In this case it replaces QUI (le poste qui est intéressant).

question: He walks while choosing.
answer: Il marche EN choisissant.; Use a gérondif présent (en + participe présent) because CHOISISSANT modifies a verb - it reveals a concurrent activity with the main verb (walks).

question: She talks while selling.
answer: Elle parle EN vendant.; Use a gérondif présent (en + participe présent) because VENDANT modifies a verb - it reveals a concurrent activity with the main verb (talks).

question: He dances while showering.
answer: Il danse EN SE douchant.; The gérondif of a reflexive verb includes the pronoun. Use a gérondif présent (en + participe présent) because DOUCHANT modifies a verb - it reveals a concurrent activity with the main verb (dances).

question: I convinced him by explaining the details.
answer: Je l'ai convaincu EN EXPLIQUANT les détails.; Use a gérondif présent (en + participe présent) because EXPLIQUANT modifies the main verb (CONVAINCRE) - revealing why or how the main verb happens.

question: By listening to french radio I learned french.
answer: EN ÉCOUTANT la radio française j'ai appris le français.; Use gérondif présent (en + participe présent) because ÉCOUTER modifes the main verb (APPRENDRE) - revealing why or how the main verb happens.

question: I finished on time by waking up at 6h.
answer: J'ai fini à temps EN ME réveillant à 6h.; Use a gérondif présent (en + participe présent) because SE RÉVEILLANT modifies the main verb (FINIR) - revealing why or how the main verb happens.; If using a reflexive verb as gérondif then the reflexive pronoun must agree with the subject (je).

question: While finishing... + While thinking deeply / reflecting...
answer: En finissant... + En réfléchissant...; Use gérondif (en + participe présent) to describe concurrent activities.; FINIR and RÉFLÉCHIR are regular group 2 -IR verbs. These verbs have SS in the base of their participes présent - same as their conjugations in indicatif présent.

question: While going out... + While leaving...
answer: En sortant... + En partant...; Use gérondif (en + participe présent) to describe concurrent activities.; SORTIR and PARTIR are not group 2 -IR verbs (despite ending in -ir). So these verbs do not have SS in the base of their participes présent - same as their conjugations in indicatif présent.

question: What is the 'la voix passive' (passive voice)?
answer: This is not a verb tense. It is a way to indicate that something is being done to a subject (le sujet passif) by an agent (le sujet actif) - to emphasize the object instead of the subject. e.g. The chicken is followed by her chicks. It emphasizes a direct object (the chicken) over the real subject/agent (the chicks). If we used active voice instead: The chicks follow the chicken.; In passive voice the agent can always be omitted: The chicken is followed.; Passive voice can only be used with verbs that have a direct object.

question: How do you construct a phrase in 'la voix passive' (passive voice)?
answer: subject/object + ÊTRE conjugated + participe passé + PAR + the agent; The participe passé must agree in gender and number with the subject of the passive sentence (le sujet passif).; The agent can be completely omitted. e.g. La vaisselle est faitE (par Henri). = The dishes are done by Henry. The participe passé must be feminine (faite instead of fait) to agree with la vaisselle.; NB: If the verb describes a feeling or opinion then use DE (instead of PAR) before the agent.

question: How do you adapt 'la voix passive' (passive voice) to the past and the future?
answer: Change the conjugation of être to the desired tense. Any tense is possible. e.g. The pie is made by Derrek. = La tarte est (indicatif présent) faite par Derrek.  The pie was made. = La tarte a été faite (passé composé). The pie was being made. = La tarte était (indicatif imparfait) faite.; The participe passé must be feminine (faite instead of fait) to agree with la tarte.

question: Transform this phrase into la voix passive: On connait (indicatif présent) le danger du soleil.
answer: Le danger du soleil est connu (indicatif présent + participe passé).; The agent (on) is omitted completely. In la voix passive a generalized subject is generally omitted completely.

question: Transform this phrase into la voix passive: La police a interrogé (passé composé) les suspects.
answer: Les suspects one été interrogés (passé composé + participe passé) par la police.; Participe passé (interrogés agrees with passive subject - les suspects).

question: Transform this phrase into la voix passive: Le professeur va interroger (futur proche) les étudiants.
answer: Les étudiants vont être interrogés (futur proche + participe passé) par le professeur.; Participe passé (interrogés agrees with passive subject - les suspects).

question: Transform this phrase into la voix passive: Les enterprises avaient signé (plus que parfait) un accord.
answer: Un accord avait été signé (plus que parfait + participe passé) par les enterprises.; Participe passé (interrogés agrees with passive subject - les suspects).

question: Which verbs cannot be used in 'la voix passive'?
answer: AVOIR plus verbs that do not have a direct object (because la voix passive requires that the sujet passiv be a direct object of the verb).; This means that the following verbs cannot be used in la voix passive: AVOIR + Intransitive Verbs (verbs that do not have objects)

question: Which verbs use 'la voix passive' even though there is no direct object?
answer: décéder and mourir (both mean to die)

question: The book is written by the team.
answer: Le livre est écrit par l'équipe.; This is the indicatif présent tense in the passive voice. écrit (participe passé) can stay masculine singular because the subject (le livre) is masculine singular.; Use PAR before the agent (l'équipe) because the verb is not expressing opinion/feeling.

question: The comic strip is written by the team.
answer: La bande dessinée est écritE par l'équipe.; This is the indicatif présent tense in the passive voice. écritE (participe passé) must be made feminine because the subject (la bande) is feminine singular.; Use PAR before the agent (l'équipe) because the verb is not expressing opinion/feeling.

question: The professor is hated by his colleagues.
answer: Le professeur est détesté DE ses collègues.; This is the indicatif présent tense in the passive voice. détesté (participe passé) can stay masculine singular because the subject (le professeur) is masculine singular.; Use DE (instead of PAR) before the agent because the verb is expressing opinion/feeling.

question: The decision is appreciated by everyone.
answer: La décision est très appréciéE DE tout le monde.; This is the indicatif présent tense in the passive voice. appréciéE (participe passé) must be made feminine because the subject (la décision) is feminine singular.; Use DE (instead of PAR) before the agent because the verb is expressing opinion/feeling.

question: My mother woke me up. + I was woken up by my mother.
answer: Ma mère m'a révaillé. + J'ai été réveillé(e) par ma mère.; When a reflexive verb is placed in la voix passive... it is no longer reflexive.

question: The subject is talked about by all the newspapers.
answer: This phrase (as is - using talked about in the passive voice) cannot be translated to French because we can only use la voix passive with direct objects in French. The active voice version of this phrase has an indirect object: Tous les journaux parlent DU sujet. (parler de X = to talk about X).; If we want to la voix passive then we have to change the phrase so that the object is a direct object: Le sujet est évoqué dans tous les journaux. = The subject is mentioned in all of the newspapers.

question: She was defended by the lawyer.
answer: Elle a éte défendue par l'avocat(e).; This is passive voice in passé composé. So we use the voix passive pattern and conjugate être in passé composé.; The participe passé (défendue(e)) must agree with the sujet passif (elle).

question: She was being defended by the lawyer.
answer: Elle était défendue par l'avocat(e).; This is passive voice in imparfait. So we use the voix passive pattern and conjugate être in imparfait.; The participe passé (défendue(e)) must agree with the sujet passif (elle).

question: She will be defended by the lawyer.
answer: Elle sera défendue par l'avocat(e).; This is passive voice in futur simple. So we use the voix passive pattern and conjugate être in futur simple.; The participe passé (défendue(e)) must agree with the sujet passif (elle).

question: I wish that she is defended by the lawyer.
answer: Je souhaite qu'elle soit défendue par l'avocat(e).; This passive voice in subjonctif. So we use the voix passive pattern and conjugate être in subjontif.; The participe passé (défendu(e)) must agree with the sujet passif (elle).

question: Transform this phrase into la voix passive: Je suis sorti au cinema.
answer: This phrase cannot be transformed into passive voice because the verb does not have a direct object. A direct object is required to form le sujet passif.; The clue is that SORTIR is using être as an auxiliary in this case. That means that the verb describes state of being (instead of action). We cannot use passive voice with verbs that use être as auxiliary.

question: Transform this phrase into la voix passive: J'ai sorti le chien au parc.
answer: Le chien a été sorti par moi.; This phrase can be tranformed into passive voice because the verb does have a direct object (le chien). A direct object is required to form le sujet passif.; The clue is that SORTIR is using avoir as an auxiliary in this case. That means that the verb describes action (often with a direct object to receive the action).

question: Transform these phrases into la voix passive: I write to my father. + I write the letter.
answer: The first phrase cannot be transformed to la voix passive because there is no direct object. The second phrase does have a direct object so we can transform it: Le lettre est écrit par moi.

question: Bothered by the noise` she decided to move.
answer: DérangéE (agrees with elle) par le bruit` elle a décidé de se déplacer.; The first clause is passive voice with a participe passé that is completely lacking an auxiliary. This is one exception where the participe passé agrees with the subject it describes (elle).; The second phrase is regular passé composé using avoir where the participe passé does not adapt in gender/number because there is no object placed before the verb.

question: to become a citizen
answer: nationaliser; This verb can also mean 'to nationalize': the act of a government taking over companies or industries

question: She became French.
answer: Elle est naturalisée française.; NATIONALISER = to become a citizen

question: What is 'passé simple' verb tense?
answer: This is completely interchangeable with passé composé (same use cases). Passé simple (now) is only used in written texts of fiction or history - often the history of famous people and events with an especially grand character.; In old French passé composé was only used for verbal communication - never written. The language has evolved to use passé composé in both writing and speaking.

question: How do you construct 'passé simple' verb tense?
answer: RADICAL + endings: je -ai + tu -as + il/elle/on -a + nous -âmes + vous -âtes + ils/elles -èrent

question: What is indirect speech and how does it impact verb conjugation?
answer: Indirect/reported speech happens when we do not use direct quotes to reference something that was said. Direct speech: She said 'The car is (présent) blue'. Indirect speech: She said that the car was (imparfait) blue.; Notice that the tense of the verb of the spoken portion changed.; This change occurs in English and French. Whether a change is required depends on the verb tense of the introducteur (she said...). If - for example - the introducteur was au présent (she says...) then there would be no transformation of the spoken portion.

question: What is the most common case of reported speech that triggers a transformation of a verb?
answer: In indirect/reported speech... when the introducteur is in passé composé then we must transform the verb in the dependent clause. e.g. direct speech: He told me 'The cat is (présent) black'. indirect speech: He told me that the cat was (imparfait) black.; The introducteur (he told me) is in passé composé. This means that we always have to transform the verb in the spoken portion. The tense to which we transform depends on the original tense of the spoken portion. In this case the original verb is au présent so it transforms to imparfait.

question: Which tenses do not get transformed when moving from direct speech to indirect speech?
answer: conditionnel mood + subjonctif mood + indicatif imparfait + plus que parfait; If the introductuer is au présent or au futur then you are not obligated to change the tense when reported indirectly.; Generally the imparfait does not need to be transformed but there are some cases where it changes to plus que parfait.

question: If information is originally in passé composé and then reported indirectly... which tense is used?
answer: passé composé transforms into plus que parfait; Original: She said 'He ate it.' = Elle a dit 'Il l'a mangé (passé composé). Indirect: She said that he had eaten it. = Elle a dit QU'il l'avait mangé (plus que parfait).

question: If information is originally in futur simple and then reported indirectly... which tense is used?
answer: futur simple transforms into conditionnel présent; Original: She said 'He will eat it.' Indirect: She said that he would eat it.

question: If information is originally in futur antérior and then reported indirectly... which tense is used?
answer: futur antérior transforms into conditionnel passé; Original: She said 'He will have eaten it.' Indirect: She said that he would have eaten it.

question: If information is originally in impératif and then reported indirectly... which tense is used?
answer: impératif transforms into DE + INFINITIVE; Original: She ordered 'Eat the apple.' = Elle a ordonné 'Mangez la pomme (impératif).' Indirect: She ordered that the apple be eaten. = Elle a ordonné DE manger (infinitive) la pomme.

question: If information is originally in indicatif présent and then reported indirectly... which tense is used?
answer: It depends. 1) If introductuer is also in présent: Keep the verb in présent.  2) If introducteur is in a past tense: transform into imparfait.  3) If the subject of both clauses is the same: Use DE + INFINITIVE (though this is optional - not required).

question: If information is originally in futur proche and then reported indirectly... which tense is used?
answer: This depends only on the tense of the verb ALLER. e.g. She said 'He is going to eat.' = Elle a dit 'Il va manger'. The conjugation of aller in this case is au présent (indicatif). So follow the rules of indicatif présent. In this case the introducteur (said) is in the past. So tranform the ALLER portion of the verb to imparfait: Elle a dit qu'il allait manger.

question: The man repeated 'I needed a pear.' + The man repeated that he had needed a pear.
answer: L'homme a répété 'J'ai eu (passé composé) besoin d'une poire.' + L'homme a répété qu'il avait eu (plus que parfait) besoin d'une poire.; When using indirect speech: passé composé transforms into plus que parfait.; NB: Pronouns and temporal indications often change as well.

question: The woman explained 'I will return.' + The woman explained that she would return.
answer: La femme a expliqué 'Je reviendrai (futur simple).' + La femme a expliqué qu'elle reviendrait (conditionnel présent).; When using indirect speech: futur simple transforms into conditionnel présent..; NB: Pronouns and temporal indictions often change as well.

question: He whispered 'My homework will have been finished.' + He whispered that his homework would have been finished.
answer: Il a chuchoté 'Mes devoirs auront été (futur antérior) finis.' + Il a chuchoté que ses devoirs auraient été (conditionnel passé) finis.; When using indirect speech: futur antérior transforms into conditionnel passé.; NB: Pronouns and temporal indictions often change as well.

question: She ordered 'Bring the wine.' + She ordered to bring the wine.
answer: Elle a ordonné 'Apportez (impératif) le vin.' + Elle a ordonné de apporter (de + infinitive) le vin.; When using indirect speech: impératif transforms into DE + INFINITIVE.; NB: Pronouns and temporal indications often change as well.

question: The doctor says 'Everything is fine.' + The doctor says that everything is fine.
answer: Le médecin dit 'Tout va (présent) bien.' + Le médecin dit que tout va (présent) bien.; When using indirect speech: indicatif présent does not transform IF the introductuer (says) is also indicative présent.; If instead the introducteur is au passé (e.g. said) then indicatif présent transforms to imparfait.

question: The doctor said 'Everything is fine.' + The doctor said that everything was fine.
answer: Le médecin dit 'Tout va (présent) bien.' + Le médecin a dit que tout allait (imparfait) bien.; When using indirect speech: indicatif présent transforms to imparfait IF the introductuer (said) is au passé.; If instead the instroducteur is au présent (e.g. says) then the indicatif présent does not transform.

question: The artist recounted 'The supplies are going to arrive.' + The artist recounted that the supplies were going to arrive.
answer: L'artiste a raconté 'Les peintures vont arriver (futur proche).' + L'artiste a raconté que les peintures allaient (imparfait) arriver.; When using indirect speech on futur proche: Use the conjugation of ALLER to guide the transformation. If ALLER is conjugated in indicatif présent then follow the rules of indicatif présent and only transform ALLER. The infinitive portion of the verb remains unchanged.

question: The author affirmed 'I would sign the contract.' + The author affirmed that he would sign the contract.
answer: L'actrice a affirmé 'Je signerais le contrat.' + L'actrice a affirmé qu'elle signerait le contrat.; When using indirect speech: conditional moods do not transform. Neither do subjonctif moods.

question: She asked him 'You come from which country?' + She asked him from which country he came.
answer: Elle lui a demandé 'Tu viens (présent) DE QUEL pays?' + Elle lui a demandé DE QUEL pays il venait (imparfait).; The interrogattive phrase (de quel) is maintained when moving from direct to indirect speech.

question: 'Do not smoke in the hallways!' + He forbids smoking in the hallways.
answer: 'Ne fumez pas (impératif) dans les couloirs !' + Il est interdit de fumer (de + infinitive) dans les couloirs.; Impératif (or any kind of order/advice) transforms to DE + INFINITIVE when reported indirectly.

question: 'Give me the book.' + She demands that he give the book.
answer: 'Apporte-moi (impératif) le livre'. + Elle exige de lui apporter (de + infinitive) le livre.; Impératif (or any kind of order/advice) transforms to DE + INFINITIVE when reported indirectly. Pronouns maintain tonique form.

question: I order you to rest at my place. + He ordered me to rest at his place.
answer: Je t'ordonne (présent) que tu restes chez moi. + Il m'a ordonné de rester (de + infinitive) chez lui.; Any kind of order or advice transforms to DE + INFINITIVE (like impératif) when reported indirectly.

question: Transform the following into indirect speech: He said 'The concert is today.'
answer: Direct: Il a dit 'Le concert est (présent) aujourd'hui'. Indirect: Il a dit que le concert était (imparfait) CE JOUR-LÀ.; When speech is transformed (from direct to indirect) the temporal and spacial phrases (e.g. ici + hier) must also transform (e.g. là-bas + la veille).

question: What is the 'infinitif passé' verb tense?
answer: Infinitif passé is used to express that an action happened earlier. It's similar to plus-que-parfait. Both are 'perfect' tenses meaning that the action was already completed.; e.g. Je suis heureuse d’avoir fini le travail. = She is happy to have finished the work.; In English we use verb + ing for this tense (e.g. swimming + having). English verbs ending in -ing often translate to infinitif passé in French.

question: How do you construct the 'infinitif passé' verb tense?
answer: AVOIR/ÊTRE (inifinitive) + PARTICIPE PASSÉ (adapts to gender/number of subject IF auxiliary is être); Often the verb is preceded by DE but not in every case.; e.g. Elle est soulagée d'être montéE (feminine because auxiliare is être) des escaliers. = She is relieved to have gone up the stairs.

question: Before having seen the film... + After having seen the film...
answer: Avant D'avoir vu le film... + Après‿avoir vu le film...; Use DE between avant and inifinitif passé. No preposition between aprèe and infinitive passé (but there is a Z liaison).

question: I hope to have found a job before June.
answer: J’espère t’avoir trouvé (infinitive passé) un emploi avant juin.

question: She regrets having gone out without a coat.
answer: Elle regrette d’être sortie (infinitive passé) sans manteau.; Expressing regrets in this way is a common use case for infinitive passé.

question: What a shame to have ate too much!
answer: Quel dommage d'avoir mangé (infinitive passé) trop!; Expressing regrets in this way is a common use case for infinitive passé.

question: I feel bad for ignoring the task.
answer: Je m'en veux d’avoir ignoré (infinitive passé) la tâche.; S'EN VOULOIR is a way to express regrette about something. It is used with infinitive passé to express regret.

question: She likes neither red nor orange nor yellow.
answer: Elle n'aime NI le rouge NI l'orange NI le jaune.; When dealing with a list of negatives use multiple NI instead of PAS. The NIs replace PAS completely.; If it is a negated list of nouns: Use only NI in front of each noun. Never add NE in addition to the NI with nouns.

question: He does not speak write nor walk.
answer: Il NE parle NI (n') écrit NI (ne) marche.; When dealing with a list of negatives use multiple NI instead of PAS. The NIs replace PAS completely.; If it is a negated list of verbs: It is obligatory to use NI in front of each verb. It is optional to add NE in addition to the NI.

question: neither you nor I
answer: ni toi ni moi; Negation triggers the pronom tonique which disambiguates between gender in the 3rd person.; Alternative: aucun des deux = neither of the two

question: It is not X Y or Z.
answer: Three options when making a negated list. 1) Use ou: Ça n'est pas X Y ou Z. 2) Use et: Ça n'est pas X Y et Z. This is possible in french. 3) Use ni (stronger tone): Ça n'est pas X ni Y ni Z.

question: either... or...
answer: soit... soit...; Use the same word twice. It looks like the subjonctif form of être but it is not.

question: whether or not... (e.g. I don't know whether or not I succeeded.)
answer: Je ne sais pas SI j'ai réussi ou non.; There is no equivalent for 'whether'. Generally one states the first option and then adds 'ou non' (literally: or not).

question: in order to speak and take
answer: POUR parler et POUR prendre; When you list items connected by ET then articles and prepositions must be listed on both sides - not just once.

question: the cat and dog
answer: LE chat et LE chien; When you list items connected by ET then articles and prepositions must be listed on both sides - not just once.

question: the people
answer: Multiple options: les gens + le peuple + les personnes + le public (people out and about)

question: a character + the main character + a caricature
answer: un personnage + le personnage principal + une caricature; Do NOT use 'un caractère' to describe a character in a story. un caractère = a trait of personality / an attribute / a characteristic

question: an aquaintance + a contact (a person you know)
answer: une connaissance + un contact; a confident = un(e) confident(e)

question: a colleague + a peer
answer: un(e) collègue + un(e) pair; un(e) homologue = a person that has your job in a different company or organization

question: the associates (the people that someone hangs out with)
answer: les fréquentations

question: a friendship
answer: une amitié

question: a friend
answer: un(e) ami(e) (m/f; pronounced same); Alternative: le copain / la copine (If you add petit(e) then it means boyfriend/girlfriend.); NB: Avoid using mon ami(e) / mes amis when talking about platonic friends because it sounds like boyfriend/girlfriend in french. Instead use un(e) ami(e) or des amis.

question: my friend
answer: un(e) ami(e) à moi; Take care: mon ami(e) means a romantic partner.

question: my sister's friend
answer: l'ami(e) de ma souer; Do not use the relation as a possessive. e.g. l'ami(e) de mon mari = the friend of my husband

question: an old friend (known for a long time)
answer: un(e) vieil(le) ami(e); Like english use the word for 'old' to describe both someone who is old and someone who you have known for a long time.

question: a good/close friend (m/f)
answer: Many options: 1) un(e) bon(ne) ami(e)    2) très grand(e) ami(e)    3) ami(e) très proche; Do not use the adjective vieux (old) for this case.; Remember proche triggers DE (not À) so you could say: une amie très proche DE moi.

question: my closest friend (m/f)
answer: l'ami(e) la plus proche; Do not say: plus proche ami(e)... the order is incorrect.

question: my best friend (m/f)
answer: mon meilleur ami / ma meilleure amie; best friends = des meilleurs amis; Alternative: un(e) vrai(e) ami(e) = a true friend

question: 2 to 3 friends
answer: des amis; It's not idiomatic to say deux ou trois amis.

question: a gay friend (m/f)
answer: un(e) pote homo; un(e) pote = buddy/pal

question: a new friend / acquaintance (someone you just met)
answer: une connaissance; This word is always feminine (like personne).

question: idiomatic way to refer to a classmate - a person that you went to school with and were friendly with but who is not necessarily as close to you as a friend
answer: two options: 1) un copain/une copine (m/f) is more modern 2)un/une camarade (literally: comrade) is less modern but still used

question: idiomatic way to refer to someone you work with but who is not necessarily a friend
answer: un/une collègue

question: 2 steps to the train
answer: à deux pas du train; NB: pas is spelled the same regardless of singular/plural. e.g. un pas = a step  deux pas = two steps

question: a street + a pedestrian street
answer: + une rue + une rue piétonne

question: a sidewalk + a pedestrian
answer: un trottoir + un(e) piéton(ne); NB: piéton(ne) can also be used as an adjective

question: a road + an alley
answer: une route + la ruelle; La route is a bit of a 'false friend'. It means the pavement itself - not the route.

question: an avenue + a boulevard
answer: une avenue + un boulevard

question: on the avenue + on the boulevard
answer: DANS l'avenue + SUR le boulevard; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: on the road + on the street
answer: SUR la route + DANS la rue; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: in the plaza + in the street + in the photo
answer: SUR la place + DANS la rue + SUR la photo; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: I live at XX Bond Street. + I live at XX Park Boulevard.
answer: J'habite` XX Rue Bond. + J'habite` XX Boulvard Park.; This is how you give your address. Use the same structure regardless of whether you live on a rue (feminine) or a boulevard (masculine).

question: I live on Bond Street. + I live on Park Boulevard.
answer: J'habite DANS la Rue Bond. + J'habite AU Boulevard Park.; Use dans for a street. Use au for a boulevard.

question: I live on that street. + I live on that boulevard.
answer: J'habite DANS cette rue. + J'habite AU ce boulevard.Use dans for a street. Use au for a boulevard.

question: a pathway + a bike path
answer: un chemin + une piste cyclable

question: a path (for your career)
answer: parcours; This can also mean path (un chemin) or journey (un voyage) but it can additionally be used to describe a path in life or work.

question: a journey + a chase
answer: un voyage + une chasse (also means a hunt); voyage de noces = honeymoon

question: the traffic
answer: le trafic is the general term. Without further context this means the trafficing of forbidden goods (e.g. le trafic de drogues / d'armes). But if you add an adjective then it can mean the movement of vehicles (e.g. le traffic aérien = the air traffic). But if you mean car traffic then you must use a different word: la circulation.

question: a traffic jam
answer: un embouteillage ('uh-bow-tay-ahj'); Alternative and very familiar option: un bouchon (like bottleneck)

question: honking (of horns on a car)
answer: klaxonner

question: The horns (of the cars) annoy me.
answer: Les klaxons m'énerve.

question: rush hour + the rush (busy time) at a restaurant or party
answer: les heures de pointe + un coup ('koo') de feu

question: a parking lot + a parking meter
answer: un parking + un parcomètre; un parking can also mean parking spaces

question: to park (a car)
answer: garer OR stationner OR garanter

question: to row (a boat)
answer: ramer; NB: Je rame. = I row a boat. Do not add the object - it is understood. The following does not make sense: Je rame le bateau.

question: to drive (a car); Conjugate it.
answer: ROULER is commonly used. CONDUIRE is more formal.; Conduire is conjugated similar to dire: je conduis + tu conduis + il conduit + nous conduisons + vous conduisez + ils conduisent; past participle: conduit; CONDUIRE can also mean to travel by car. e.g. On a conduit de X à Y. = We drove from X to Y.

question: We drove. + We were driving.
answer: On a conduit. + On conduisait.; NB: You can use the verb 'to drive' in french the same as you do in english. e.g. On a conduit (we drove) means that we were all on a roadtrip.

question: The car operates without a driver.
answer: La voiture roule sans conducteur.; ROULER is the verb used to describe the action of a car. It is independant of a driver. It means something like: to roll from the power of an engine

question: The computer program works.
answer: Le programme informatique fonctionne. Do not use ROULER or MARCHER in this case.

question: a driver of a car (whoever happens to be driving) + a professional/hired driver
answer: un(e) conducteur/conductrice + un chauffeur; These are two different words in French.

question: to operate (or turn) an engine/machine
answer: diriger; This can also mean to drive in the sense of leading.

question: a leader (m/f)
answer: un(e) dirigeant(e); This comes from the verb DIRIGER (to operate or turn an engine).

question: to lead
answer: There are two major options: 1) DIRIGER: to direct someone or something to accomplish a goal. 2) MENER: This can mean to bring someone along to accomplish a goal. It is also used to talk about causation (MENER + À). e.g. Le problème mène à une solution. = The problem leads to a solution.

question: to result in... + to lead to...
answer: entraîner à... + mener à...; If you use MENER without the preposition Á then is just means to lead someone or something.

question: to perpetuate
answer: pérenniser (like perennial)

question: to cause
answer: causer OR provoquer; Alternatives: poser + produire (to produce)

question: The leak caused a problem.
answer: La fuite a posé un problème.; POSER is a common way to suggest causation - as opposed to CAUSER.

question: The disease caused the symptoms.
answer: La maladie a provoqué les symptômes.; PROVOQUER is a common way to suggest causation - as opposed to CAUSER.

question: provoking
answer: provocateur / provocatrice; This can mean thought-provoking or someone who incites violence

question: a bicycle + a motorcycle
answer: un vélo + une moto

question: a car + a taxi
answer: une voiture + un taxi

question: a flat tire; Specify pronunciation.
answer: un pneu ('PNOW') crevé; Both consonants of PN are pronounced in French. e.g. la pneumonie ('PNOW-moh-nee') = the pneumonia

question: a truck + a van
answer: un camion + un van; NB: un van is a van used for travelling.

question: a police van + a firetruck + a garbage truck
answer: une camionnette + un camion de pompier + un camion poubelle

question: a bus
answer: un bus ('boos'); The S in 'bus' is pronounced even though it is a final consonant - likely because the origin of the word is foreign.

question: a subway + a subway station
answer: le métro + la station de métro; You can use 'un métro' to mean a subway stop.

question: Where do you go if you lose something on the métro?
answer: le bureau d'objects trouvés (15e arrondissement)

question: in the middle of the subway platform
answer: au milieu ('mee-lYoo') de quai; le quai = the dock/waterfront and the subway platform

question: at the front of the train + at the rear of the train
answer: en tête du train + à l'arrière du train / en queue du train

question: a train + a train station
answer: un train ('tron') + la gare ('gahr' rhymes with car); NB: gare à toi (or anyone) = a warning to someone like you are watching them and there might be consequences if they do something

question: a boat + the boats
answer: un bateau + les bateaux; Endings -eau and -eaux are pronounced like a really strong 'oh'.; Words that end in -eau are made plural by adding X.

question: a ferry
answer: un bateau navette

question: a sailboat + a submarine
answer: un bateau à voile + un sous-marin

question: a cruiseship + a container/cargo ship
answer: un paquebot + un cargo

question: an airplane + an airport
answer: un avion + un aéroport (4 syllables! 'ah-yah-ro-por')

question: How do you pronounce Charles de Gaulle airport?
answer: aéroport (4 syllables! 'ah-ay-ro-pohr') Charles ('shahrl') de Gaulle ('gohl'; hard O like bateau and chateau)

question: to fly + to take off
answer: voler (also means 'to steal') + s'envoler; VOLER works for describing a bird or a person in an airplane.

question: a flight
answer: un vol OR un envol

question: an engine
answer: un moteur

question: by sea + on the sea
answer: par la mer + sur le large; Preposition PAR (= by way of) explains causation in terms of the manner or the place.

question: by foot + by bike + by horse
answer: À pied + À velo + À cheval

question: by car + by train + by subway + by plane
answer: EN voiture + EN train + EN métro + EN avion; EN can be a pronoun or a preposition (as in en voiture). EN (as a preposition) indicates the interior of something or a state of mind. e.g. en métro + en ville + en colère

question: public transport
answer: les transports en commun

question: The public transport system in my city is really developed.
answer: Les transports en commun sont bien développés (or bien desservi) dans ma ville.; Desservir = to serve / to service (like an institution or system)

question: The buses run frequently.
answer: Les bus passent fréquemment.; PASSER and TRAVERSER are good verbs for describing public transport.

question: She opened her studio to the public.
answer: Elle a ouvert son studio au public.

question: one-way + roundtrip
answer: aller simple + aller-retour

question: a trip
answer: un trajet

question: the luggage + a suitcase
answer: les bagages (plural masculine) + une valise

question: an identity card
answer: une pièce d'identité

question: a driver's licence
answer: un permis de conduire; Do not use 'un licence' to mean a physical permit. un licence = an undergraduate diploma or an authorization (e.g. license to kill)

question: a license plate (on a car)
answer: la plaque d'immatriculation

question: a forest + into the great outdoors
answer: une forêt + au grand air

question: the vineyard + the orchard
answer: le vignoble ('veen-yo') + le verger; the vines = les vignes. Many people have grapevines in their yard. They may even make their own wine. But the word le vignoble is only used to indicate a very large and professional operation.

question: the nature
answer: la nature

question: the tropics
answer: les tropiques; alternative: un climat tropical (a tropical climate)

question: the mountain(s) + the hill
answer: la montagne / les montagnes + la colline

question: the cliff + the volcano
answer: la falaise + le volcan

question: a rock + a pebble
answer: un rocher + un caillou

question: a stone + made of stone
answer: une pierre + en pierre

question: the ocean + the sea
answer: un océan + une mer

question: The Mediterranean Sea + on the Mediterranean Sea
answer: la mer Méditerranée + en Méditerranée / dans la mer (Méditerranée)

question: a lake + on the western side of the lake
answer: un lac + à l'ouest du lac

question: a pond
answer: un étang OR une mare ('mahr' not 'mehr' which means sea)

question: a river
answer: Two words: 1) un fleuve: a wide/large river - technically it should empty into the ocean or sea 2) une rivière: a smaller river - technically it should flow into another larger river (not the ocean or sea)

question: a dam (on a river)
answer: un barrage; faire barrage can mean to physically build a dam but it is also commonly used as an expression meaning to build up a defense (to protect) against something that is very large and growing.

question: a fjord
answer: un fjord

question: the aurora borealis
answer: les aurores boréales

question: the north pole + the south pole
answer: le pôle Nord + le pôle Sud; le pôle can also be used to describe the poles of a magnet and a public development center

question: What are the 5 major rivers in France?
answer: La Seine (NW: goes through Paris) + La Loire (W: south of Paris; many chateuax along this river) + Le Rhin (NE: at border of France with Germany) + Le Rhône (E: goes through Lyon and Avignon) + La Garonnel (SW; goes through Bordeaux and Toulouse)

question: the right bank + the left bank (of a river)
answer: la rive droite + la rive gauche; NB: sur berge = on the banks of river

question: the canal + the canals
answer: le canal ('kah-naL') + les canaux ('ka-noh'); The L in the singular form is pronounced.

question: the bridge + the port
answer: le poNt + le poRt

question: a waterfall + a coral reef
answer: une cascade + un récif de corail; la grande Barriere de Corail = the Great Barrier Reef

question: a dock / a place on the waterfront
answer: un quai; NB: This is also the name for a subway platform.; If you are explaining to someone that you want to meet at the dock or that something is located at the dock use: SUR le quai. Do not use au or dans.

question: on the waterfront + the docks of the Seine
answer: sur les quais ('kay') + les quais de Seine

question: a park on the Seine
answer: un parc SUR LA Seine; Use sur instead of dans. La Seine is feminine.

question: an amusement park
answer: un parc d'attraction

question: the beach(s)
answer: la plage / les plages

question: a beach cabana
answer: une cabine de plage

question: the sand
answer: le sable

question: a current (of water or air)
answer: un courant

question: the sky + the atmosphere
answer: le ciel + l'atmosphère (feminine)

question: a star + a planet
answer: une étoile + une planète; en orbite = orbiting; une bonne étoile = a lucky star (use this describe a close friend that brings luck and good things to your life)

question: the Moon + the Earth
answer: la Lune + la Terre; These words are capitalized in french.; le globe = the globe

question: a universe + a solar system
answer: un univers + un système solaire

question: a telescope + a microscope
answer: un télescope + un microscope

question: a wave
answer: Depends on context. 1) une vague = a wave of water 2) une onde = a ripple of energy / light / sound   3) un signe = a greeting wave with the hand

question: vaguely
answer: vaguement; This comes from the word for a wave of water: une vague

question: The waves crash on the wall.
answer: Les vagues éclatent sur le mur.; ÉCLATENT = to burst. This is a better fit than ÉCRASER (to crash).

question: to burst + to shake
answer: éclater + secouer; Use éclater to describe a storm breaking or a large burst of thunder or waves crashing on a shore. e.g. l'orage éclate = the thunder bursts but it also translates to: the storm breaks

question: to shake hands (as a greeting)
answer: serrer la main

question: to nod (as a greeting)
answer: saluer de la tête

question: a heat wave
answer: une canicule

question: a drought + a forest fire
answer: une sécheresse + un incendie

question: an earthquake + a volcanic eruption
answer: un tremblent de terre + une éruption volcanique

question: to break + broken
answer: casser + cassé(e); CASSER is not the best verb when you mean 'to break a law'. In that case use VIOLER (to violate).

question: She broke the window. + She broke her arm.
answer: Elle a cassé la fenêtre. + Elle s'est casséE le bras.; You must use CASSER reflexively to mean the breaking of a bone. If you don't use it reflexively then it sounds like the person intentionally broke their own bone. And use an article - not an adjective - in front the part of the body (not son bras).

question: to fall apart
answer: tomber en panne; This is used to describe an electrical or mechanical malfunction that could likely be fixed.; en panne = broken down; casser = completely broken and likely irreparable

question: to damage
answer: abîmer OR endommager

question: the damage(s)
answer: les dégâts (masculine) OR la panne OR un préjudice; This is a faux ami. un préjugé = a bias BUT un préjudice = an injury/harm.

question: damaged
answer: abîmé(e) OR endommagé(e)

question: delapidated
answer: délabré(e)

question: stained + torn
answer: taché(e) + déchiré(e)

question: unsanitary
answer: insalubre

question: to shelter + a shelter
answer: s'abriter + un abri; abrîmer = to damage

question: to succumb to X
answer: succomber À X

question: the climate
answer: le climat

question: global warming
answer: le réchauffement climatique; NB: Suffix -ment (on a noun) usually indicates some kind of process.

question: a greenhouse effect
answer: un effet de serre; un serre = a greenhouse

question: a domino effect
answer: un effet domino; same meaning as in english

question: the melting of the glaciers
answer: la fonte des glaciers; la banquise = the arctic ice

question: rising water levels
answer: la montée du niveau des eaux

question: the destruction of the ozone layer
answer: la destruction de la couche d'ozone; une couche = a layer

question: the disappearance of endangered species
answer: la disparition d'espèces menacées

question: the spice + the species
answer: une épice + une espèce

question: the noise pollution + the light pollution
answer: la pollution sonore + la pollution lumineuse

question: the air pollution + the ocean pollution + the ground pollution
answer: la pollution atmosphérique + ...marine + ...des sols

question: polluting + polluted
answer: polluant(e) + pollué(e)

question: The air is polluted by the factory.
answer: L'air est pollué PAR l'usine.

question: to carpool
answer: faire du covoiturage; le covoiturage = the carpooling

question: glass/plastic/paper recycling
answer: le recyclage du verre/plastique/papier

question: to sort / to separate (e.g. trash for recycling)
answer: trier

question: to reuse a plastic bag
answer: réutiliser un sac plastique

question: to conserve (a resource)
answer: conserver

question: a natural resource
answer: une ressource ('z') naturelle; There really are two SS.

question: a fossil fuel + a green/renewable energy
answer: une énergie fossile + une énergie verte

question: solar energy + wind energy
answer: l'énergie solaire + l'énergie éolienne

question: the gas + the gasoline
answer: the gas (state of matter + natural gas): le gaz + the gasoline (for a consumer car): l'essence

question: the diesel gas (for a truck) + the diesel oil
answer: le gasoil + le pétrole

question: the coal
answer: le charbon

question: the fire + the fireworks
answer: le feu + le feu d'artifice; Fireworks is singular in french though plural in english.; NB: un incendie = an incidence (specifically of a fire)

question: a flame
answer: une flamme; la flamme des J.O. = the olympic flame

question: the gift
answer: le cadeau OR le don

question: to offer as a gift + to give a gift
answer: offrir en cadeau + offrir/donner un cadeau; Offrir is more idiomatic than donner.

question: on sale
answer: en promotion OR en solde OR soldé

question: sold out
answer: épuisé OR plein

question: an auction
answer: une enchère

question: a possibility of promotion (in a job)
answer: une possibilité de promotion

question: to promote
answer: mettre en avant; This is the most common way to express 'to promote' to promote a product/idea or to encourage a person.; PROMOUVOIR exists but it is not commonly used. You can use it for advertising or to promote a person to a better job.

question: a package/bundle of services
answer: forfait; This is different than the words for food packaging: les emballages.

question: I exceeded my phone plan this month.
answer: J'ai dépassé mon forfait téléphonique ce mois.

question: to close a sale
answer: clore l'échange; CLORE may be short for CONCLURE which is a more formal verb to use for closing a transaction.

question: the checkout
answer: le caisses ('kes')

question: He goes to the checkout.
answer: Il va aux caisses.; à + les = aux ('oh')

question: paid for
answer: payant(e)

question: shopping
answer: le shopping (remember 'le' is pronounced 'luh')

question: I wear all black.
answer: Je porte tout en noir.

question: the color
answer: une couleur; The noun for color is feminine. But when you use a color as a noun (e.g. the blue) then it is always masculine (e.g. le bleu).; The second part of the word -leur is pronounced the same as time/hour (l'heure).; NB: couler = to sink

question: the (color) white + white (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le blanc + blanc ('blon') / blanche ('blonch') / blancs (masculine plural; pronounced same as masculine singular) / blanches (feminine plural; pronounced same as feminine singular)

question: the (color) black + black (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le noir + noir / noire / noirs (masc pl) / noires (fem pl); all four are pronounced exactly the same way

question: the (color) gray + gray (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le gris + gris / grise / gris / grises; The adjective already ends in 's' so the masculine plural is same as masculine singular (gris).

question: the (color) red + red (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le rouge + rouge / rouge / rouges / rouges; when an adjective ends in 'e' it has the same spelling for masculine and feminine

question: the (color) pink + pink (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le rose + rose ('roos') / rose / roses / roses; Adjectives that end in 'e' are the same for masculine and feminine.; Even though 'rose' is based on a noun it is an exception in that it agrees in number with the noun.

question: the (color) orange + orange (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le orange + orange ('or-onj'); The adjective 'orange' is invariable (does not agree in gender/number) because it is based on a noun.

question: the (color) yellow + yellow (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le jaune + jaune ('jown') / jaune / jaunes / jaunes; 'au' makes a strong 'oh' sound; if you say 'joon' that is a different word meaning young

question: the (color) green + green (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le vert + vert ('ver') / verte ('vert') / verts (masc plural) / vertes (fem plural)

question: the (color) blue + blue (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le bleu + bleu ('blu') / bleue / bleus / bleues

question: the (color) purple + purple (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le violet + violet ('vee-oh-lay') / violette / violets / violettes; Even though 'violet' is based on a noun it is an exception in that it agrees in gender/number with the noun.

question: the (color) brown + brown (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le marron + marron ('meh-ron'); The adjective 'marron' is invariable (does not agree in gender/number) because it is based on a noun.

question: the (color) burgundy + burgundy (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le bordeaux + bordeaux; The adjective 'bordeaux' is invariable (does not agree in gender/number) because it is based on a noun.

question: the (color) auburn + auburn (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le auburn + auburn; Though auburn is not based on a noun it is invariable (does not agree in gender/number).

question: the (color) chestnut + chestnut (m/f/m pl/f pl)
answer: le châtain + châtain / châtain / châtains / châtains; Châtain as a color agrees in number (but not gender) with its noun. It is an exception to the general rules.

question: a gray area (where the rules are not certain)
answer: une zone grise

question: without color
answer: incolore

question: of silver + silver-colored
answer: d'argent OR en argent + argenté(e)

question: sterling silver + a silver bar
answer: argent sterling + un lingot d'argent

question: of gold + golden
answer: d'or + doré(e); a gold bar = un lingot d'or

question: a shadow
answer: une ombre

question: It's night / dark (outside).
answer: Il fait sombre. OR Il fait nuit.; The latter is very idiomatic and translates to something like: It is nigh.; Do not use soir/soirée or foncé(e) in this case.

question: The sun is bright.
answer: Le soleil est brillant.

question: bright (with light) + dark (without light)
answer: lumineux / lumineuse (m/f) + sombre; the bright colors = les couleurs vives

question: the luminosity / brightness
answer: la luminosité

question: light (in color) + dark (in color)

question: Do you have it in white?

question: When does a color adjective not agree in gender/number with its noun?
answer: 1) When the color is derived from a noun. e.g. les chaussures ivoire = the ivory shoes. There are some exceptions that do adapt in gender/number (e.g. rose and violet).; 2) Compound colors (using more than one adjective related to the color) are invariable - they never agree in gender/number with their noun. e.g. la robe vert jaune	= the yellow-green dress; 3) More than one color in play: It depends. Agreement happens when there is group of items and some of them are red and some of them are yellow (e.g. des fleurs rouges et jaunes = the red and yellow flowers). Agreement does not happen if you have a group of items that are multi-colored (e.g. des fleurs rouge et jaune = the red-yellow flowers).

question: a blue-grey house + the green-blue crayons
answer: une maison bleu gris + des crayons vert blue; When you make a compound color (more than one adjective related to the color) the adjectives become invariable - they no longer agree with the noun in gender/number.

question: a light green car + the dark red hats
answer: la voiture vert clair + des chapeaux rouge foncé; When you make a compound color (more than one adjective related to the color) the adjectives become invariable - they no longer agree with the noun in gender/number.

question: the medium-blue paint
answer: la peinture bleu intermédiaire;When you make a compound color (more than one adjective related to the color) the adjectives become invariable - they no longer agree with the noun in gender/number.

question: the moss-green planet + the lemon-yellow birds
answer: la planète vert mousse + des oiseaux jaune citron; When you make a compound color (more than one adjective related to the color) the adjectives become invariable - they no longer agree with the noun in gender/number.

question: the white and green houses (some are white; some are green)

question: the white and green houses (all houses are white with green trim)

question: to hide

question: We go to the bakery.

question: at your place

question: We go to our place. (using nous) + We go to our place. (using on)

question: the butcher shop + the butcher (m/f)

question: the post office + the posting (like a position or job)

question: a wrinkle (on the face)

question: What are the two ways to talk about pain/injury?
answer: 1) To talk about acute pain/discomfort or to talk about health status in general: person injured + AVOIR MAL À + body part. 2) To talk about an event where someone was injured: person injured + SE FAIRE + MAL À + body part ...the reflexive pronoun is conjugated for the person that was injured (not the part of the body).

question: He injured his hand.
answer: Il s'est fait (passé composé of SE FAIRE) À la main.; Use SE FAIRE + MAL À + body part because we are talking about an event where someone injured (themselves).

question: My knees hurt.
answer: Two possibilities: 1) J'ai mal AUX genoux. (à + les = aux); 2) Mes genoux me font (SE FAIRE) mal.; The second option is a different wasy to use SE FAIRE where the subject is the body part instead of the person injured.

answer: J'ai mal À la tête.;To talk about pain/discomfort: AVOIR MAL + À + body part

question: I have a soar throat.
answer: J'ai mal À la gorge. / Ma gorge me fait mal.; To say that you hurt somewhere it is AVOIR + MAL + à + le/la/les + X.; To say that something hurts you... X + ME + FAIRE + MAL

question: Take care of yourself. (when someone is ill)

question: the symptom

question: the essentials

question: How do you talk about character-driven drama? e.g. The story is not built around the actions.
