question: We went to see the swimming / football.
answer: On est allé VOIR la natation / le foot.; ALLER + VOIR (without preposition) is the way to express this. Just list the sport. Do not use événement for sports.; Pronom ON is always conjugated as singular masculine even if it represents two women. So the participe passé in passé composé should be singular masculine.

question: We went to see the volleyball competition.
answer: On est allé VOIR les épreuves du volleyball.; ALLER + VOIR (without preposition) is the way to express this.; If you need to specify that it was a competition then une épreuve is the most idiomatic choice.; Pronom ON is always conjugated as singular masculine even if it represents two women. So the participe passé in passé composé should be singular masculine.

question: Which sporting events are on today?
answer: Two options: 1) Quelles sont les épreuves aujourd'hui ?; 2) more idiomatic: Qu'est-ce qu'il y a comme épreuves (épreuve if one event) aujourd'hui ?; Do not use un évènement if it is actually a contest.; Une épreuve is a competitive event within which there may be multiple matches or heats etc. Though you can use it in the plural if there are multiple events. Do not use un évènement if it is actually a contest... like the olympic games.

question: an event
answer: un évènement (sometimes un évènement); Use this for gallery openings and award shows. For sporting events use: une épreuve.; NB: les oscars = the Oscars

question: to cheer on + to applaud
answer: encourager + applaudir

question: to boo (at a sporting event)
answer: huer; So people shout 'oo' instead of 'boo'.

question: I do not want to encourage my family to buy gifts.
answer: Je ne veux pas encourager ma famille à acheter des cadeaux.; When you negate VOULOIR it is unusual to use the conditionnel tense (even when you would use it in the un-negated form). Use: ne veux pas (instead of ne voudrais pas).

question: a play / a show (when you go to see live theater)

question: the setting / background

This is an idiomatic way to talk about the entire setting of an event (beyond the literal backdrop and props).

question: in the foreground + in the background (of an image or piece of art)

question: the manner of how something (like an event) is organized or layed out
answer: la mise en place; You could use this to talk about the setting of an event in a technical way. If instead you mean the backdrop of a theater show then use: la mise en scène.

question: a club

question: I recommend that you go to the store.
answer: There are three ways to make a recommendation. They all use DE + VERB (instead of QUE + PHRASE). 1) RECOMMANDER: Je te/vous recommande D'aller au magasin. 2) SUGGÉRER: Je te/vous suggère D'aller au magasin. 3) CONSEILLER: Je te/vous conseille D'aller au magasin.

question: I recommend it (to you).
answer: There are three ways to make a recommendation. 1) RECOMMANDER: Je te/vous le recommande. 2) SUGGÉRER: Je te/vous le suggère. 3) CONSEILLER: Je te/vous le conseille.

question: For a starter I would like...and for drink I would like...

question: I'll have coffee (when placing an order).

question: I would like some juice. + One glass of juice please.
answer: Je voudrais DES jus. + Une verre DE jus s'il vous plaît.; In the first phrase use partitive article (des) because the quantity is undefined. In the second phrase use generic DE because the quantity is defined.

question: list the verbs for eating five french meals

question: How do you ask for something at a store/market? e.g. Ask for flour.
answer: First you always greet (e.g. bonjour!) and then ask for a general amount: Bonjour je voudrais de la farine.; Then - after they know what you are talking about - you specify the amount... 500 grammes de farine.; Never ever say 'je veux...' which is very rude. If the other person is in a rush then it is possible to say 'un baguette s.v.p.' but this is an exception.

question: When ordering something in a market/store/etc. how do you construct the opening phrase?
answer: Use the partitive articles (du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d') initially to indicate an undefined quantity.; e.g. Bonjour je voudrais du café / de la farine / de l'huile / des pommes; NB: du = de + le and des = de + les because 'de le' and 'de les' are not used. D' occurs when du or des are followed by a noun that starts with a vowel.

question: When ordering something in a market/store/etc. how do you construct the second half of the phrase?
answer: After opening with a general statement of what you want in unspecified quanities... then specify the amount. Doing so will replaces partitive articles with DE or D' - only two options.; e.g. 500 grammes de café / un paquet de salade / une carafe d'eau / plus de pommes.; D' occurs when de is followed by a noun that starts with a vowel.

question: I would like salad.

question: I want 500 grams of meat.

answer: le contenu; un contenu = a piece of content; des contenus = content (in general); Use this as you do in English. It is the product - not the institutions or the media in general. It means only the content within a journal or post or book etc.

question: It was published in 1992.
answer: Il a été publié en 1992. Do not use indicatif imparfait (était) or passive voice (est publié) in this case. Passé composé is the idiomatic choice.

question: Simone de Beauvoir published The Second Sex in 1949.
answer: Simone de Beauvoir aurai publié La Deuxième Sexe en 1949.; Historical narratives are 1 of 3 cases (in French) where we are required to use futur antérior - even though it is likely not required in other languages.

question: the media
answer: la média OR les médias (often written as a plural); NB: la presse typically refers to traditional media only (newspapers and their websites). It typically excludes television and radio. Les médias is a more inclusive term but it is a fluid word (as in English). La média can refer to media in general (books + podcasts + journals + television + radio...). It can also be used to reference 'the press' or people who are in a position to publish the news.

question: a magazine
answer: le magazine; spelled and pronounced almost identical to english

question: the radio + television (as in the media)
answer: la radio + la télévision

question: the newspaper + the newspapers
answer: le journal ('jor-nah') + les journaux ('jor-noh'); NB: The base of the word is jour (day) because the newspaper is published daily.; The plural of this word is irregular: -al changes to -aux.

question: What are the three major newspapers in France and their place on the political spectrum?
answer: Libération (left) + Le Monde (center-left) + Le Figaro (right)

question: the front page of a newspaper
answer: la une

question: a written or spoken report
answer: un rapport; This can also mean the report that a financial institution makes to another entity.; But we must use another word to describe a news report/show: un reportage

question: a news report/show
answer: un reportage; Use a different word to describe a written or spoken report: un rapport.

question: to make a report on something
answer: faire de rapportage

question: an article + an essay (writing)
answer: un article + un essai; essai can also mean scientific assay.

question: an editorial (in the newspaper) + an editorial (on the radio)
answer: une tribute + une chronique

question: a comic strip
answer: une bande deessiné

question: a source (of a document)
answer: une source; This can also mean the origin of a body of water.; un retour aux sources = back to basics especially in terms of ecological living

question: an advertisement + a movie trailer
answer: une publicité OR un pub; une affiche = a printed poster for an event; une video publicité = a video on a website (not really an advertisement); Une annonce can be used to mean a television commercial.

question: a movie trailer
answer: une bande-annonce; une annonce can mean a small posting for a roomate etc

question: the notebook
answer: le cahier; de papier perforées = of perforated paper

question: the book + the ebook
answer: le livre + le ebook (le livre électronique)

question: a novel + a love story (book)
answer: un roman + un roman d'amour; une nouvelle = a short novel but longer than a short story (= novella)

question: a book that is historical fiction + a mystery (book)
answer: un roman historique + un roman suspens; un mystère = a mystery

question: a non-fiction book
answer: un livre reportage OR un livre sur X OR un livre d'histoire; 'un livre de non-fiction' is franglais.

question: based on a true story
answer: tiré(e) d'une histoire vraie OR inspiré(e) de faits réels

question: a sci-fi book
answer: Multiple options: un livre fantastique + un livre fantasy (spelled like english b/c franglais) + un livre de la science fiction (cannot use science fiction as adjective in french); NB: 'sci-fi' only exists in English (not used in French).

question: time travel
answer: un voyage dans le temps

question: a fairytale + a fairy
answer: un conte de fées + une fée; Une fée only exists in the feminine version and describes a feminine fairy.

question: a dwarf
answer: un(e) nain(e); Pronunciation: un nain ('nah') + une naine ('nay')

question: a wizard
answer: un sorcier / une sorcière; Alternative: un magicien / une magicienne = scorcerer or magician

question: to cast a spell
answer: jeter un mauvais sort

question: to keep the audience in suspense
answer: maintenir le public en haleine

question: a story
answer: une histoire OR un conte (= a tale)

question: an epic poem (Greek)
answer: un poème épique

question: a legend + a myth
answer: une légende + un mythe

question: a fable + a moral (to a story)
answer: une fable + une morale; alternative: la leçon appris = the lesson learned

question: a bookworm
answer: un rat de bibliothéque; NB: Use geek/nerd in french and in english. There are no french equivalents.

question: homework + a requirement
answer: devoirs + un prérequis; un devoir can also mean 'a duty' like a requirement of a job or a work assignement.

question: paperwork / administrative work
answer: le travail administratif OR les formalités (feminine) OR la paperasse (slang); Alternatives: une préparation du dossier + les documents administratifs

question: administrative procedures to be undertaken
answer: les démarches administratives à entreprendre

question: The document must have an apostille to prove its legality.
answer: Le document doit porter une apostille pour prouver son légalité.

question: a proof of residence + a proof of rent payment
answer: un justificatif de domicile + une quittance de loyer

question: a copy of your birth certificate
answer: une copie intégrale de l'acte de naissance

question: What are the four major forms of the word for 'all' in french (masc sing + fem sing + masc pl + fem pl)?; Specify the pronunciation of each.
answer: masc sing: tout ('too') + fem sing: toute ('toot') + masc pl: tous ('too') + fem pl: toutes ('toot'); The best way to remember the pronuncation is that it is generally 'too' when masculine and 'toot' when feminine.; TOUS (masculine plural) is pronounced 'too' when used as an adjective: tous les jours. But it is pronounced 'toos' when used as pronoun: Bonjour à tous!

question: all type of dance
answer: toutes les danses (feminine plural)

question: ballet (the dance form - not the location/performance)
answer: la danse classique

question: I like to go to the ballet.
answer: J'aime le ballet.; Do not use ALLER + À in this case.

question: I like to go to the opera.
answer: J'aime al opera.; Do not use ALLER + À in this case.

question: I like to ski.
answer: J'aime faire du ski.; When it is appropriate to use a verb directly following AIMER then you do not need any preposition between AIMER and the infinitive of the thing that you like doing.

question: gardening + to garden
answer: le jardinage +  jardiner / faire du jardinage

question: leisure activities / places to go out
answer: des sorties / des lieux pour faire des sorties

question: the park or the garden
answer: le jardin ('shar-don'); This is how you refer to both a garden in a home and a public park.

question: the community garden
answer: le jardin ouvriers/commun

question: the vegetable garden
answer: le potager; Watch the pronunciation so it does not get confused with: le potage = a type of soup

question: the map of Paris
answer: le plan de Paris OR la carte de Paris

question: I walked to the museum.
answer: J'ai marché jusqu'au musée.; Jusqu'au + masculine noun OR jusqu'à la + feminine noun; Use MARCHER when you are walking purposefully but you cannot use MARCHER + À. (J'ai marché au musée is impossible.); Use JUSQUE when you there is some distance and you are walking until the end.; Alternative: If you want to use À then you could say: Je suis allé(e) au musée. OR Je suis allé(e) à pied au musée.

question: I walked toward the school.
answer: J'ai marché vers l'école.; Use MARCHER when you are walking purposefully but you cannot use MARCHER + À.; Use VERS to mean 'towards'.

question: I walked around Paris.
answer: Je me suis baladée dans Paris.; Use DANS for 'around' in this case. If you use AUTOUR DE that literally means outside of.; Use SE BALADER for strolling leisurely instead of MARCHER.

question: I walk the dog.
answer: Je promène le chien. OR Je me promène avec mon chien. (The reflexive pronoun is not obligatory here because the object being walked is not a person.); When you are 'walking' a thing (not a person) then you can use PROMENER without reflexive pronoun. But if you were walking with a person then you would need to use SE PROMENER + AVEC; NB: You cannot say: Je marche mon chien. MARCHER does not work in this context. It is only used for purposeful walking between two points.

question: I walk with my grandmother.
answer: Je ME promène AVEC ma grand-mère.; PROMENER is the best verb choice. But you must use if reflexively if you are walking another person (instead of a dog etc.) AND you must use AVEC to indicate the person with whom you are walking (walking with someone instead of walking someone).

question: My friend and I went for a walk.
answer: Une amis et moi - nous nous sommes promené(e)s.; This is the idiomatic way to express this. Start with the two people. Then repeat the subject with a pronoun (the first nous). The second nous is the reflexive pronoun.

question: I escort the family.
answer: J'escorte la famille.; ESCORTER is a verb that you can use for walking around with someone that does not require prepositions or a reflexive pronoun. The person being escorted is the COD.

question: He accompanies her (e.g. with the guitar).
answer: Il l'accompagne.; ACCOMPAGNER is reserved for meaning 'on the side'. It is not used for escorting someone (to some place).

question: coffee for dessert with a cookie
answer: café gourmand

question: I was born in X (some city) in the United States.
answer: Je suis nè(e) à X aux‿États-‿Unis ('oh-Zay-ta-Zoo-nee'; 2 liaisons)

question: It is located in Utah of the United States.
answer: Il est situé DANS l'Utah aux États-Unis.; Use À for cities. Use DANS for states. Use en/au/aux for countries.

question: identity + place of origin + place where you live
answer: d'identité ('day-don-dee-tay') + lieu d'origine ('lyoo-dor-ee-jun') + lieu d'habitation ('lyoo-da-bee-ta-syoh'); Always ignore apostrophe when speaking - imagine the apostrophe is not there.; e.g. If you are French and one of your parents is Italian... Je suis français(e) d'origine italienne. The last word (italienne) is always feminine because it is an adjective that modifies origine (feminine).

question: That's it. / You got it.
answer: C'est bien ca.

question: Do you know of...?
answer: Qu'est-ce que tu connais ...?

question: first name / last name
answer: prénom / nom OR nom de famille

question: my darling
answer: mon chéri

question: a boyfriend / girlfriend
answer: un (petit) copain / une (petite) copine; An option that you might hear very young people use: mon (petit) ami / ma (petite) amie; Alternative: un amoureu / une amoureuse

question: an adult + a teenager
answer: un(e) adulte + un(e) adolescent(e); un ado = abbreviation for adolescent

question: a childhood
answer: une enfance; e.g. He spent his childhood in Uruguay. = Il est passé son (change from sa to son because noun starts with vowel) enfance en Uruguay.

question: pregnant + the pregnancy
answer: enceinte + la grossesse

question: to have a child (to become a parent) + to give birth to a child
answer: avoir un enfant + accoucher

question: They are married.
answer: Ils son marié. ...pronounced 'mar-ee-ay'

question: We got married.
answer: Nous nous sommes mariés.; This uses passé composé. You must use the reflexive form of the word to indicate that you did something to eachother - otherwise there is no object of the verb and it doesn't make sense in french.

question: Laurent is married to Lyna.
answer: Laurent est marié (because Laurent is masculine) avec Lyna.; Use AVEC for romantic relationships - including divorce/separation/couple status.

question: Lyna is married to Laurant.
answer: Lyna est mariée (because Lyna is feminine) avec Laurent.

question: Our friends will get married. (futur proche)
answer: Nos amis vont se marier.

question: Her girlfriend did not want to get married.
answer: Sa petite amie ne voulait pas se marier.; Use the imparfait tense because you are describing a scene / context / story.; VOULOIR (to want) is the infinitive. Voulons is the conjugation for nous au présent so the radical is VOUL. -AIT is the imparfait ending for il/elle.; Then you can use the infinitive (SE MARIER).

question: X is divorced from Y. Give both feminine and masculine versions.
answer: X est devorcé / devorcée avec Y.

question: X is separated from Y. Give both feminine and masculine versions.
answer: X est séparé / séparée avec Y.

question: X is engaged (for marriage) to Y. Give both feminine and masculine versions.
answer: X est engagé(e) avec Y.; engagé(e) can alo mean actively involved in current events. But this is different from the adjective that means 'engaging': engageant(e); Alternative: être promis(e) à qqn = to be promised to someone

question: X is in a relationship with Y. Give both feminine and masculine versions.
answer: X est en couple / couple avec Y. Same for masculine and feminine.

question: X is single.
answer: X est célibataire. Pronounced 'say-li-Ba-Ter'. The word liberty is in there. Same for either gender.

question: a love + lovers
answer: un amour + les amants

question: He is in love. / She is in love.
answer: Il est amoureux. / Elle est amoureuse.

question: I have lots of love for France.
answer: J'ai beaucoup de l'amour POUR la France.

question: to date someone + to reject someone
answer: sortir avec quelqu'un + rejeter quelqu'un

question: They are dating.
answer: Ils sort ensemble.; SORTIR + ensemble indicates dating - not platonic going out together.

question: They have a date.
answer: Ils ont un date. (more modern) OR Ils ont un rendez-vous.

question: to flirt with someone
answer: draguer quelqu'un; Alternatives: faire du charme + séduire (can mean to seduce or to flirt)

question: to hold someone's hand
answer: tendre la main à quelqu'un

question: to have a crush on someone
answer: avoir le béguin; e.g. Elle a le béguin. = She has a crush (on someone).

question: to marry + to enter a domestic partnership
answer: se marier avec quelqu'un + se pacser; PACS is the name of legislation passed in 1999 to establish domestic partnership agreements (similar to marriage): le mariage pour tous.

question: to cheat on someone
answer: tromper quelqu'un avec quelqu'un; alternatives: avoir une aventure + avoir une liaison avec quelqu'un

question: to break up with someone
answer: rompre avec quelqu'un; alternative: quitter quelqu'un = to leave someone (a romantic partner)

question: to get back together with a romantic interest (after a breakup)
answer: se remettre ensemble OR se réconcilier (avec quelqu'un); Using the reflexive form of a French verb is often is how we translate English verbs where we use 'to get'.

question: to divorce
answer: se divorcer de quelqu'un; This references the separation of both people. If instead you want to express that one person divorced (or left the other): divorcer quelqu'un OR quitter quelqu'un. Elle se divorce du homme. = She gets divorced from the man. Elle divorce/quitte l'homme. = She divorces/leaves the man.

question: to separate (as a romantic couple)
answer: se séparer quelqu'un; e.g. Il s'est separée la femme.

question: a life together (as a romantic couple
answer: une vie commune / une vie à deux / une vie de couple

question: to grow old together (like a couple)
answer: vieillir ensemble

question: to stay young
answer: rester jeune

question: to touch
answer: toucher

question: both bodies touch completely (when describing tango)
answer: les deux corps entier se touchent

question: intimate
answer: intime

question: a bond / a link (including hyperlink)
answer: un lien; The N is silent. Otherwise it sounds like the word for lion.

question: to relate / to link + to connect
answer: lier + relier

question: to relate to something (personally)
answer: s'identifier à quelque chose; e.g. Il est plus facile de s'identifier à quelqu'un qui fait le même travail. = It's easier to relate to someone that does the same job.

question: linked / related to..
answer: lié(e) à... OR en relation avec... (= in connection with...)

question: a related subject
answer: un domaine lié à ça; un champ is an idiomatic way to express subject/domain

question: They must be linked.
answer: Ils doivent être lier. OR Elles doivent avoir un lien.

question: to connect things (like to hook up a computer)
answer: brancher; Do not use joindre for this meaning.

question: to join
answer: Depends on context: 1) To attach something to a message: joindre qqch à un message   2) To contact someone by phone / virturally: joindre quelqu'un  3) to meet someone physically after a separation: rejoindre quelqu'un

question: I need to run an errand. I'll join you in an hour.
answer: J'ai une course à faire. Je vous rejoins dans une heure.; Use rejoindre (not joindre) for physically meeting up with someone.

question: The document is attached.; Give the formal and the informal versions.
answer: Formal: Je vous prie de trouver ci-joint le document. (Replace 'je vous prie' with 'nous vous prions' if writing on behalf of a company or couple.); Informal: Voici le documente en pièce jointe.

question: I attached my homework / a screenshot to this email.
answer: Je joins (JOINDRE) mon devoir / une capture d'écran à ce message.; Use joindre (not rejoindre) for attachments.

question: Formal email: Please see the information below.
answer: Je vous prie de trouver certaines informations ci-dessous.

question: an attachment (to an email)
answer: une pièce jointe

question: What is the preposition 'in' for any city (e.g. I live in Istanbul)?
answer: à Istanbul à Paris à Detroit...same for any city

question: What is the preposition 'from' for any city (e.g. I am from Istanbul)?
answer: de Istanbul de Paris de Detroit...same for any city

question: What is the preposition 'in' for a country (e.g. I live in France)?
answer: it depends on the gender...feminine: en France; masculine: au Canada; plural (au = à le which is never used): aux États-Unis; au and aux are pronounced 'oh'; Use this following verbs such as aller + rester + partir.

question: What is the preposition 'from' for a country (e.g. I am from Germany)?
answer: it depends on the gender...feminine: de France; masculine: du Brésil (du = de le which is never used);plural: des États-Unis

question: a city + a village; Specify pronunciation.
answer: une ville ('veel') + un village; The pronunciation of ville ('veeL') is an exception. Normally -ille is pronounced 'veey' (like fille).; Do not use cité - that is like a greek city-state and not idiomatic french.

question: in the city
answer: en ville (NOT á ville); EN can be a pronoun or a preposition (as in en ville). EN (as a preposition) indicates the interior of something or a state of mind. e.g. en métro + en ville + en colère

question: hometown + a capital city (of a country)
answer: la ville natale + la capitale

question: in a region + in a state (of the United States)
answer: dans une région + dans un état; Use À for cities. Use DANS for regions/states. Use EN/AU/AUX for countries.

question: in the Paris Basin + in the Loire Valley
answer: dans le Bassin Parisien + dans le Val de Loire; Use À for cities. Use DANS for regions/states. Use EN/AU/AUX for countries.; NB: in the Basque Region = au Pays Basque. This region is treated as a country so use à instead of dans.

question: at the bank + in the bank
answer: à la banque + dans la banque; À is used for a non-specific location. DANS is used for specific locations.; You could be even more specific: à l'intérieur de la banque = inside of the bank.

question: in Paris + in Berlin + in Montreal + in Buenos Aires; Specify pronunciation.
answer: á Paris ('pah-ree') + á Berlin ('bear-luhn'; i like ingénieur) + à Montréal ('mon-ray-ahl'; Do not pronounce the T.) + à Buenos Aires (pronounce it exactly the same as in spanish - including the S's; Do not try to pronounce this like a french word.)

question: in NYC + in Harlem
answer: á New York (pronounced same as in English) + à Harlem; Use à for cities and neighborhoods.

question: on the island of Manhattan
answer: dans l'île de Manhattan; Use dans instead of sur in this case.

question: in Cuba + in Taiwan + in Hong Kong + in Malta
answer: Island nations are often referred to without an article: à Cuba + à Taiwan + à Hong Kong + à Malta; There is no consistent rule and many exceptions. e.g. in Jamaica = à la Jamaïque (uses feminine article but preposition à instead of preposition en)  e.g. Some island nations adhere to the regular rules: au Japon + en Islande + en Haïti + en Nouvelle-Zélande

question: in Virginia + in California
answer: en Virginie + en Californie; Note that the spelling changes!; Use en instead of à when describing a region/territory. à is reserved for cities and very specific locations (e.g. a musuem)

question: in Provence + in Normandy
answer: en Provence + en Normandie; Note that the spelling changes!; Use en instead of à when describing a region/territory.

question: a country
answer: un pays ('pay-yee'); This is pronounced very clearly as two syllables - not 'pay'.

question: in France
answer: en France (feminine); Names of countries are capitalized in French. Names of nationalities and languages are not capitalized in French.

question: in Canada + in England
answer: au Canada (masculine) + en Angleterre (feminine); NB: United Kingdom = Le Royaume-Uni

question: in the United States
answer: aux États-Unis (plural); aux is pronounced 'oh'; NB: outre-Atlantique is a casual way to refer to the United States.

question: in Sweden + in Switzerland + in Belgium
answer: en Suède + en Suisse + en Belgique (all feminine); Generally if a country name ends in E then it is feminine. But there are exceptions.

question: in Mexico + in Morocco
answer: au Mexique + au Maroc (all masculine)

question: in Austria + in Hungary + in Scotland
answer: en Autriche + en Hongrie + en Écosse (all feminine); Generally if a country name ends in E then it is feminine. But there are exceptions.

question: in Israel + in Peru + in Nigeria
answer: au Israël + au Pérou + au Nigéria (all masculine)

question: in China + in Spain
answer: all feminine: en Chine + en Espagne ('uh-nay-spagn' pronounced all together ); Generally if a country name ends in E then it is feminine. But there are exceptions.

question: in Iraq +  in Iran
answer: en Iraq + en Iran; Both of these countries are masculine (not feminine). But we cannot write/say AU + VOWEL in french so we must use EN instead.

question: in Australia + in New Zealand
answer: en Australie + en Nouvelle-Zélande

question: in Bosnia-Herzogovinia; Specify pronunciation.
answer: en Bosnie('boS-nee')-Herzégovine; The first syllable has a clear S sound - not like a Z.

question: the former Yugoslavia
answer: les territoires de l'ex-Yougoslavie

question: from NYC + from France
answer: de ('duh') New York + France; Both are feminine.

question: from Brazil + from Japan
answer: du ('doo') Brésil + Japon; Both are masculine.

question: from the United States
answer: des États-Unis ('day' because plural)

question: What is the general rule for determinining if a country is feminine or masculine? And what are the 6 countries that do not follow this rule?
answer: Generally all countries that end in E are feminine... except for these six: le Mexique + le Mozambique + le Belize + le Cambodge + le Suriname + le Zimbabwe

question: I would like to live in Mexico.
answer: Je voudrais vivre au Mexique. (masculine)

question: Where are you from?
answer: D'où viens-tu? OR D'où venez-vous?; You must add DE + OÙ. The literal translation is From where are you?; If you omit the DE in this case: Où viens-tu? = Where are you coming?

question: I respect the country where I came from.
answer: Je respecte le pays d'où je viens.; You cannot end the phrase with a preposition in french.

question: Where did you go in Croatia?
answer: Où es-tu allé(e) en Croatie?

question: I am from New York City. + I am from the United States.
answer: Je viens de New York. ('vee-yun-duh') + Je viens des États-Unis (plural).

question: I am originally from Paris.
answer: Je suis originaire de Paris.

question: I am early / on time / late.
answer: Je suis en avance / à l'heure (OR à temps) / en retard.; En avance (= ahead of time/schedule) and en retard (= behind schedule) are the correct choice for describing arrival. But if you are describing departure then use tôt (early) and tard (late).; NB: en retard = late to an event BUT du retard = period is late (pregnant)

question: She is late (meaning her period is late and she may be pregnant).
answer: Elle est DU retard.; en retard = late for an event; du retard = period is late / possibly pregnant

question: The manager delayed the meeting.
answer: La directrice a retardé la réunion.; RETARDER = to delay

question: idiomatic expression that means to do something early
answer: faire quelque chose DE bonne heure

question: exactly on time
answer: pile à l'heure

question: at some time
answer: à une certaine heure

question: late (in the day) / early (in the day)
answer: tard / tôt

question: early in the morning
answer: tôt le matin OR tôt dans la matinée

question: by evening
answer: au soir OR à la fin de la journée; Both phrases use the preposition À because you are signaling some duration of time (something was happening and continued until the evening) instead of a precise moment (in the evening).

question: Sorry for being late.
answer: Je suis désolé(e) D'avoir été en retard.; Use DE after Je suis désolé(e) to explain for what you are sorry.

question: I'm sorry that I am not able to come.
answer: Je suis désolé(e) DE ne pas pouvoir venir.; Use DE after Je suis désolé(e) to explain for what you are sorry.

question: He arrived early. + He left the party early.
answer: Il est arrivé en avance. + Il est parti la fête tôt.; NB: En avance (= ahead of time/schedule) is used for arrival. Tôt (= early) is used for departure.

question: She arrived late.  + She left the party late.
answer: Elle est arrivée en retard. + Elle est partie la fête tard.; NB: En retard is used for arrival. Tard is used for departure (of people or things).

question: I left my apartment.
answer: Je suis parti DE mon appartement.; Use DE because you are leaving from a real location.

question: We talked late into the night.
answer: On a parlé jusqu'à tard la nuit. OR On a parlé très tard dans la nuit.; NB: If you talked until the morning = jusqu'à matin

question: They say it's never too late.
answer: On dit qu'il n'est jamais trop tard.

question: There were 10 people AT the party.
answer: Il y avait dix personnes À la soirée.; Not dans la soirée.

question: It was a long time ago. + It's been a while.
answer: Il y a longtemps. + Ça faisait longtemps.

question: It's been happening for a long time.
answer: Cela arrive depuis longtemps.

question: time (in general)
answer: le temps ('ton'); It has an S even when singular; Caution: Le temps can mean weather + time + tense of a verb.; Il est grands temps que... = Now is the time to...

question: I need more time. / We have lots of time.
answer: J'ai besoin de plus de temps. / On a beaucoup de temps.; NB: Both plus and beaucoup are defined quantities so we use generic DE before the noun.

question: It takes a lot of time. / It will take a lot of time.
answer: Ça prend beaucoup de temps. / Ça prendra (futur simple) beaucoup de temps.; Different verbs are used to mean 'it takes' in different circumstances including: PRENDRE + METTRE + DEMANDER

question: It took a lot of time to fix the leak.

question: What is an independent possessive pronoun?
answer: An independent possessive pronoun is a shortcut for showing ownership where the pronoun stands on its own instead of being an adjective to the noun that is possessed. For example: This is my cat. 'my' is a possessive pronoun. 'cat' is the noun being possessed (by me). BUT... This cat is mine. 'mine' is the independent possessive pronoun - you could eliminate the cat entirely: It is mine.

question: How do you construct the independent possessive pronouns in french? (e.g. mine)
answer: There are two ways to express these in french. In both cases you need a second word. 1) DEFINITE ARTICLE + non-generic posessive pronoun: e.g. C'est mien. = It's mine. ...if the noun (that is owned) is singular/masculine. Both the article and the possessive pronoun change to adapt to the gender and number of the noun being owned. 2) À + generic pronom tonique: e.g. La chat est à moi. = The cat is mine. These pronouns do not adapt to the number and gender of the possessed noun.

answer: Two options: 1) More modern: un(e) auteur(e)  2) More traditional: un auteur / une autrice; NB: écrivain(e) = a writer of novels (fiction). auteur(e) = writer of a paper or non-fiction book.

question: a reader (of a book or other writing)... when you refer to the audience
answer: un lecteur / une lectrice

question: an editor (masc + fem)
answer: un rédacteur / une rédactrice

question: a freelancer (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) pigiste

question: an archeologist (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) archéologiste; When the masculine version ends in E then the feminine version is the same form.

question: a mayor (masc + fem); Specify pronounciation.
answer: un(e) mair(e); Pronounced 'mer' which is the same as mère (mother).

question: a government worker (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) fonctionnaire; When the masculine version ends in E then the feminine version is the same form.

question: a customer + a consumer (masc +fem)
answer: un(e) client(e) + un consommateur / une consommateuse

question: consumer-facing (a job or business that interacts with individual customers)
answer: faire face au grand public; faire face à = facing; le grand public = the public

question: a salesperson (masc + fem)
answer: un vendeur ('von-dur') / une vendeuse ('von-dooz') OR un(e) marchand(e); NB: a buyer = un acheteur / une acheteuse; avoir la fière achetuese = to be a compulsive shopper

question: a person who works with customers in a very small business (e.g. a market stand or boutique) + a person who works with clients in a store or larger business (e.g. retail of B2B)
answer: un(e) commercial(e) + un(e) commerçant(e); When a french word ends in -CIAL pronounce it the same as the word for sky: ciel.

question: a wholesaler + a retailer
answer: un(e) grossiste + un(e) détaillant(e)

question: a real estate agent (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) agent(e) immobilier(e); 'ee-mobe-uh-lee-ay' but you can probably drop the middle syllable; a real estate agency = une agence immobilière

question: a real estate market
answer: un immobilier

question: a landlord/owner (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) propriétaire; When the masculine version ends in E then the feminine version is the same form.

question: caretaker + superintendent (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) gardien(ne) + un(e) surintendant(e); Gardien is a 'faux ami'. It does not mean guardian.

question: a tenant / renter (masc + fem)
answer: un locataire + une locatrice

question: a roomate (masc + fem)
answer: un colocataire + une colocatrice; en colocation = living with roomates; un(e) 'coloc' = short for roomate

question: to own
answer: posséder; The literal translation is 'to possess' and so this verb can be used more broadly in french compared to english. e.g. Je possède (accent changes) un chat. = I own a cat. La maison ne possède pas de cave. = The house does not have a basement.

question: to rent an apartment + the rent (that you pay)
answer: louer ('loo-ay'; There is only one Y sound.) un appartement + le loyer ('lwa-yay'; There are two Y sounds.)

question: to sublet an apartment
answer: sous-louer

question: for rent + for sale
answer: à louer ('loo-ay') + à vendre

question: to allocate (money to something)
answer: allouer; The base is louer (= to rent a property).

question: What is the difference between une location and une localisation?
answer: une location = a rental property; une localisation = a location; un localisateur de GPS = an airtag or similar tracking device

question: a rental contract + a subcription contract (like for a service)
answer: un contrat de location + un contrat d'abonnement / un abonnement; un abonnement annuel = a yearly subscription

question: the deposit (the money you give up front when renting an apartment)
answer: la caution OR la somme d'argent

question: We rent our apartment to our friends.
answer: On loue notre appartement À nos amis.

question: We rent our apartment from our friends.
answer: On loue notre appartment DE nos amis.

question: to make a deposit (to a bank account) + to make a withdrawal (from a bank account)
answer: faire un dépôt + faire un retrait

question: to be overdrawn (in a bank account)
answer: être à découvert

question: the limit on a bank account
answer: un plafond

question: an ATM
answer: un distributeur de billets

question: a building
answer: There are two words: 1) le bâtiment is any structure including a house + an apartment building + a store... it is the larger category; 2) un immeuble ('ee-mobl'): a residential building where multiple families live or where there are multiple offices. ...it is the smaller category; immeuble is pronounced 'ee-mobl' (instead of 'uh-mobl') because there is a double consonant following the I.

question: the housing
answer: le logement; This is a good alternative to un appartement and une maison.

question: a storage unit
answer: un entrepôt de stockage ('stoh-kahj')

question: a property (real estate or otherwise)
answer: une propriété OR un bien; NB: la foncier = an administrative term meaning the property / the land. You might see used to designate a type of tax.

question: a business + business (in general)
answer: une commerce + des affaires; NB: des affaires can also refer to personal effects.

question: an event/case
answer: une affaire; Be careful because 'des affaires' means business (in general) or personal effects.

question: a studio apartment
answer: un studio ('stoo-deeoo'; two deep U sounds); une studette is a studio apartment that is very small (typically for students); Suffixes -ET (masculine) and -ETTE (feminine) indicate a very small version of the noun.

question: the tiny studios on the top floor of Haussman buildings in Paris
answer: la chambre de bonne; These appeared starting around 1830s. The domestiques (house servants - also called 'un bon') lived here and served the wealthy families in the floors below.

question: a house
answer: une maison ('may-Zon') OR une baraque (a very familiar term for a family house); The S sounds like a Z here because the S is between two vowels.

question: a villa; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: une villa; Pronunciation is an exception. LL is pronounced like an english L (instead of Y). Same exception as une ville (a city).

question: a large home in the country
answer: chalet or maison de campagne

question: a skyscraper
answer: une tour (tower) / un gratte-ciel (sky-scratcher); gratter = to scratch

question: to scrape / to scratch
answer: gratter; Alternative: griffer = to scratch specifically when an animal scratches another animal or a person with their claws

question: a tower + a tour (like a walking tour)
answer: une tour (feminine = tower) + un tour (masculine = tour); faire un tour = to go on a tour (of a site)

question: I went a tour of the yacht.
answer: J'ai fait un tour le yacht ('yo').

question: a factory
answer: une usine

question: a cabana / hut
answer: une cabane / une hutte

question: a boathouse
answer: une peniche

question: a tent
answer: une tente ('tont')

question: What do these apartment codes mean in France? F1 + F2 + F3
answer: F1 = studio; F2 = 1 bedroom; F3 = 2 bedroom

question: a corner (of a room)
answer: un coin; e.g. aux quatre coins du monde = in the 4 'corners' of the world; This can be used to describe a part of the neighborhood. But it cannot be used to describe the corner that two steets make: un angle.

question: a corner (in a road)
answer: un angle; un angle mort = a blind corner; Do not use 'un coin' to describe the corner of streets. It means something closer to 'area' (like the corner of a room or a part of a neighborhood).

question: a room
answer: une pièce ('PEE-ays') very quickly almost on syllable...apartments are advertised by count of total rooms sans kitchen; so 3 pièce is likely 1 or 2 bedrooms plus a main room and maybe a dining room; la chambre is only used to indicate a bedroom

question: a room with its own bathroom
answer: une pièce avec SA PROPRE salle de bain.; SA PROPRE + NOUN = his/her own something

question: the bedroom + the guestroom
answer: la chambre (shombr) + la chambre d'amis; Technically a chambre is any room with walls and a door. So it could be a room in an apartment that is being used as an office but could be used as a bedroom in the future.

question: the kitchen
answer: la cuisine (same pronunciation as in english) ...une cuisine américaine means kitchen open to another room (not galley or separate room)

question: the bathroom (with shower)
answer: la salle de bains (sal-duh-bah) ...when it's more than just a toilet

question: the bathroom (small; toilet only)
answer: WC; when asking for the bathroom in a restaurant: les toilettes; les cabinets is another word used for toilets but it has many meanings.

question: the dining room
answer: la salle à manger

question: the living room
answer: le salon / la salle de séjour

question: the ballroom
answer: la salle de bal

question: the office
answer: le bureau; This can mean 1) the office of a business (not the retail location - but the place where all employees go to work) 2) a home office 3) a desk; The word cabinet is close to office but it really means an association instead of a physical place e.g. cabinets d'avocats = assocciation of lawyers; headquarters = le siège social

question: a service + customer service
answer: un service + le service clientéle

question: the cellar / the basement
answer: la cave / le sous-sol

question: the insulation (in a building)
answer: la isolation; bien/mal insolé(e) = well/poorly insulated; Watch out because there are faux amis. isolé(e) = isolated. le isolement = the isolation. la insolation = exposure to heat.

question: the pipes (in a building) + the pipe
answer: les canalisations + le tuyau; Un pipe exists in french but it means a smoking pipe.

question: the cold storage (outer compartment for keeping food and supplies)
answer: l'entrepôt frigorifique

question: the storage room
answer: le débarras ('day-bar-rah'; each syllable gets almost the same emphasis); This is a small room in a house where one stores bulky items.; se débarrasser = to get rid of something

question: the laundry room
answer: la buanderie ('boo-ahn-dree')

question: the garage
answer: le garage

question: the attic
answer: le grenier

question: a room that was made out of an attic with sloping walls
answer: la mansarde

question: a leak (of water)
answer: une fuite (d'eau)

question: water dammage
answer: le dégâts des eaux

question: burglary
answer: le cambriolage

question: on the ground floor
answer: AU rez de chaussée; Use AU for any floor.; la chaussée = the part of the road where the cars actually drive

question: on the first floor
answer: AU premier étage; typically written as: au 1ème étage; This means an American second floor.

question: I live on the 4th floor.
answer: J'habite AU 4ème étage.; NB: étage is very close to the word for a shelf (une étagère)

question: on the top floor
answer: AU dernier étage; NB: dernier/dernière (m/f): When placed before the noun it means the last in a series but when placed after the noun it means the previous one.

question: On which floor do you live?
answer: AU quel étage habitez-vous?

question: the floors of the building
answer: les niveaux du bâtiment

question: This room opens into a bedroom.
answer: Cette salle DONNE DANS une chambre.; DONNER + DANS is a common way talk about adjoining spaces in a building.

question: The hallways leads to the bedrooms.
answer: Le couloir DONNE SUR les chambres.

question: The balcony overlooks a large boulevard.
answer: Le balcon DONNE DANS SUR un grand boulevard.; In this case we cannot use only DONNER + DANS. We also add SUR because we are looking down onto a street instead of simply opening up to another room on the same level.

question: The veranda opens to the garden.
answer: La véranda donne accès à le jardin.; DONNER + ACCÈS + À is a common way to talk about a space that overlooks or opens into another space.

question: to have access (to a home or computer)
answer: avoir accèss À quelque chose

question: It's easy to access entertainment (in a city).
answer: Il est facile d’accéder au divertissement (en ville).

question: an elevator + an escalator
answer: un ascenseur ('ah-san-sir') + un escalier mécanique/roulant; NB: un escalier = a stair

question: the stairs + a stairwell
answer: un escalier + des escaliers; Generally the plural form is not used. Default to the singular (un escalier) which means a grouping of stairs. The only time you use the plural is when you are talking about the area as a room e.g. stairwell

question: the railing (for stairs)
answer: la rambarde / la balustrade; I think la balustrade specifically refers to a railing when it is supported by balusters like on a curving or independent stairs.

question: the balcony
answer: le balcon

question: the terrace
answer: la terrasse; NB: salon de jardin is different - it is a patio with furniture.

question: the roof
answer: le toit ('twa')

question: the gutter
answer: le gouttière

question: the chimney
answer: le cheminée; This is the same word for fireplace.

question: an antenna (on the roof of a building)
answer: une antenne

question: the shutter
answer: le volet; les volets bleus = the blue shutters; NB: des rideaux is another word for shutters

question: the window
answer: la fenêtre (foo-net)

question: the curtain / the curtains
answer: le rideau / les rideaux; This is the same word used for shower curtain.

question: the gate (of a fence around a yard or building)
answer: le portail

question: a fence (typically in public spaces)
answer: une clôture (literally: an enclosure) OR une barrière (literally: a barrier)

question: the yard
answer: la cour OR la pelouse (the grassy part of a garden)

question: the mailbox
answer: la boîte aux lettres

question: the address of the building/house
answer: le numéro de la maison

question: the harbor + the door
answer: le port + la porte; la porte-fenêtre = the french door (with glass panes)

question: the doorbell
answer: la sonnette (de porte)

question: the door handle
answer: la poignée

question: the entrance
answer: l'entrée

question: the hallway / corridor
answer: le couloir ('cool-war')

question: the furniture + the furnishings (broader category)
answer: les muebles + les furniture/les rangement; les meubles is the more common word.

question: the ceiling
answer: le plafond

question: the floor
answer: le sol / le plancher

question: the ground + on the ground
answer: la terre + par terre

question: on the ground / on the floor (like a mat)
answer: par terre OR au sol

question: on the wall
answer: SUR le mur OR au mur

question: The walls are painted.
answer: Les murs sont peints.

question: the bed
answer: le lit; un lit simple = single bed; un lit double = double bed; un gran lit = a large bed for two people

question: the bunk bed
answer: un lit superposé

question: the headboard
answer: la tête de lit

question: the box spring / base of the bed
answer: le sommier

question: the matress
answer: le matelas ('mah-tla')

question: the sheet
answer: le drap / drap plat (flat) drap house (fitted); NB: Remember that the P at the end is silent ('drah')

question: the comforter / duvée
answer: la couette ('qweht') - the pronunciation is one syllable and very quick

question: the bedspread
answer: la couverture; Think of the verb COUVRIR (to cover).; la première/quatrième couverture = the front/back cover (They call it the 4th cover because that is the fourth side of a book if it did not have any pages.

question: the pillow
answer: l'oreiller (lor-ee-yay)

question: the pillowcase
answer: le taie d'oreiller

question: an alarm + an alarm clock
answer: une alarme + un réveil

question: the nightstand
answer: la table de nuit / de chevet

question: the dresser (of drawers)
answer: la commode

question: the drawer / drawers
answer: le tiroir / les tiroirs

question: the chest (a piece of furniture)
answer: the coffre

question: the closet
answer: le dressing / la placard; Use this for a small room with a door that holds clothing.; This is not a separate piece of furniture.

question: a locker (at a museum) + a coat check (at a club)
answer: un casier + un vestiaire

question: the cupboard/cabinet (like in a kitchen)
answer: le placard; Perhaps the same word for closet because it is a built-in feature instead of a free-standing piece of furniture (like an armoire)

question: idiomatic way to say that something is hidden away or put away (serupticiously)
answer: au placard (literally: in the closet); This phrase is not used as commonly in french as it is in english. It is possible to say 'sortir la placard' when someone is homosexual and reveals this fact. But it is not used commonly.

question: gender-neutral
answer: Two options with different meanings: 1) unisex is an established term that means both sexes can use it (e.g. bathrooms) 2) dé-genrés is a very new term which describes an effort to remove gender norms (e.g. from commercials and toys). Some consider this term to be controversial.

question: neutral
answer: neutre

question: the built-in storage (in a room of a house)
answer: le mur de rangement; un bureau intégré le mur = a desk built into the wall

question: an armoire / the armoire
answer: une armoire / l'armoire = a separate piece of tall furniture that holds clothing (like a wardrobe).; This is not used for a closet or space.; un garde-robe is another word for wardrobe.

question: buffet (in dining room) + tall cabinet to keep dishes and silverware in dining room
answer: un buffet + un buffet vaisselier

question: the hanger
answer: le cintre ('sont') / le porte-manteau (coat hanger)

question: a mirror
answer: le miroir / la glace

question: a floor mirror
answer: le mirour á pied / grand miroir sur pied

question: the desk
answer: le pupitre (poo-peet) OR le bureau; le bureau primarily means office but can be used for desk

question: the light + the lamp + the chandelier
answer: la lumière + la lampe ('lom') + le lustre ('loostr'); un luminaire = a thing that produces light

question: the natural light
answer: la lumière naturelle; We do not see daylight. =  On ne voit pas le jour. (In this case we do not use the word for light.)

question: a lightbulb + an LED
answer: une ampoule + LED (pronounced 'led' - NOT as an acronym)

question: the flashlight
answer: la lampe-torche ('lom-ptosh'; very quick two syllables)

question: a traffic light
answer: un feu de circulation; Conversationally: le feu rouge/orange/vert

question: a round-about + a transportation hub
answer: un rond-point (dash is optional) + une plaque tournante

question: the fan
answer: le ventilateur

question: the rug
answer: le tapis; le tapis de bain = bathmat; le tapis rouge = the red carpet (same meaning as in english); NB: Use the verbs ployer and déployer to describe rolling up and unrolling a carpet.

question: the tapestry
answer: la tapisserie; NB: faire tapisserie is slang for 'to be a wallflower' (like at a party)

question: the carpeting
answer: de la moquette = carpeting/rug that covers the entire floor or a very large rug

question: the table
answer: la table

question: the coffee table
answer: la table basse ou la table de salon

question: the side table + the end table
answer: la table d'appoint ('duh-pwa') + la table de chevet

question: the chair + the deck chair (like on a beach)
answer: la chaise ('shez') + la chaise longue

question: a hammock
answer: un hamac

question: the armchair
answer: le fauteuil (foot-oy)

question: a seat + a stool
answer: un assis + un tabouret; Alternative: le siège = the seat (like at a theatre) or the location of a domicile or institution

question: the sofa / couch
answer: le canapé / le divan / le sofa; These words generally mean the same thing.

question: the sofabed (fold up)
answer: le canapé lit / le canapé clic-clac

question: the cushions
answer: les coussins (ku-son)

question: the ottoman
answer: le pouf

question: on wheels
answer: à roulettes; like the game at a casino

question: a shelf
answer: a shelf = une étagère; NB: This is very close to the word for the floor of a building: un étage. But the word for the stairs is totally different: un escalier (always singular)

question: on the shelves
answer: DANS les étagères (le-ze-ta-ger); Use DANS instead of SUR.

question: I put more shelves in the armoire.
answer: J'ai mis plus d'étagères dans l'armoire.

question: a vase
answer: un vase

question: a fountain
answer: une fontaine ('fon-tane'); Make sure you pronounce it with the hard A at the end. Otherwise it sounds like the word for phantom: le fantôme ('fan-tome')

question: a bench
answer: un banc

question: a basket
answer: un panier

question: a seed + an acorn
answer: une graine + un gland

question: corn
answer: le maïs

question: the grass
answer: l'herbe

question: a plant + a flower
answer: une plante + une fluer

question: a root
answer: la racine; This can also be used to express your family / 'your roots' = des racines

question: a tree + a palm tree
answer: un arbre + un palmier; to cut down trees = abattre des arbes / la déforestation

question: a christmas tree + a lemon tree
answer: un sapin / un arbre de Noël + un citronnier ('see-trohn-yay'; the -ier ending makes a Y sound)

question: I am looking at the trees.
answer: Je vois l'arbre. Use the singular form of the noun.; The plural form of trees is generally not used unless you literally mean a small group of specific trees.

question: to tear something off or out (like weeds from a garden)
answer: arracher

question: to decontruct / to take apart
answer: décortiquer; The original use of this verb means to tear apart prawns before eating.

question: a statue
answer: une statue ('stah-choo')

question: a candle
answer: une bougie; un cierge (bèni) = a religious (blessed) candle used in the church; bénir = to bless

question: a cotton swap + a safety pin
answer: un coton-tige + une épingle à nourrice

question: a physical sign (like street sign)
answer: une pancarte OR un panneau; BUT un panneau is not used by itself. e.g. un panneau de circulation = a traffic sign; e.g. des panneaux de signalisation = means signage in a shop

question: a metaphorical sign (like a signal of something to come)
answer: un signe; Use une pancarte or un panneau for physical signs.

question: a symbol
answer: un symbole

question: a poster
answer: une affiche (or un poster) is used for a cheap poster or an advertisement for an event; un cadre is better and used for something more formal but not necessarily a piece of art

question: to draw + to paint
answer: dessiner + peinturer

question: to manufacture + to make it by hand + custom-made
answer: fabriquer + faire à la main + sur-mesure; e.g. un usine fabrique quelque chose = a factory makes/manufactures something

question: a work (of art) / an artistic product + a home-made product
answer: un oeuvre (d'art) + un produit fait maison; fiat maison = home made

question: a frame
answer: un cadre; un cadre is also used for a nice print - something more formal than a concert poster but not necessarily a piece of art

question: a photograph + a selfie
answer: une photo (feminine!) + un selfie; Do not use 'photographe' - that means photographer.

question: a picture (in a book)
answer: une image

question: a drawing
answer: une illustration OR un dessin; un tableau could also be used if the drawing is mounted - like a work of art

question: a painting
answer: une peinture (a formal piece of art) OR un tableau (masculine) - these really are two words that you can use for something like Mona Lisa; Often used alternative: la toile = the canvas / the cloth

question: a collage + graffiti
answer: un collage + un graffiti

question: an artifact
answer: un artefact

question: a detail
answer: un détail; NB: en détail = in detail (e.g. to recall something in detail); la précision = the precision (an exactness); des précisions = something like specifications

question: the supply (as in supplies for making something)
answer: des fournitures OR l'approvisionnement

question: a watch + a clock
answer: une montre + une horlage

question: a device
answer: un appareil; Alternatives: un objet + un dispostif (can also mean a system/collection of demands); NB: Un appareil must be something that uses electricity. Often it is hand-held.; un object muni de quelque chose = an object equipped with something

question: a machine
answer: un machine

question: a machine for running (e.g. a treadmill)
answer: un machine À courir; When you need to describe a machine (and you don't know the actual name) you can always use un machine + À + verb or noun.; e.g. un machine à raclette = a device that melts the cheese for raclette

question: a time machine
answer: une machine à remonter le temps

question: a connected device
answer: un appareil connecté; You can use the adjective for any noun. e.g. une balance connectée = an computerized/connected scale

question: an appliance (household)
answer: un électroménager

question: the fuse box
answer: le tableau électrique

question: a light switch
answer: un interrupteur; interrompre = to interupt (when a person is talking)

question: the electric socket
answer: la prise (électrique) / la prise de courant; literally 'the catch'

question: the power strip
answer: la multiprise

question: the electricity
answer: l'électricité; NB: Nouns that end in Y in english often are the same word ending in É in french. And they are feminine in french.

question: a transformer (for changing the voltage of an appliance)
answer: un trasformateur OR un transfo (for short)

question: the voltage
answer: le voltage; Le voltage au USA est la moitié de le voltage en Europe. = The voltage in the US is half the voltage in Europe.; moitié moins is a more familiar way to express 'half of'

question: the heating
answer: le chauffage (could mean a boiler but could be any heating system); le style de chauffage = the type of heating

question: a radiator + a boiler
answer: un radiateur + une chaudière

question: a washing machine (for clothes) + a dryer (for clothes)
answer: un lave-linge ('lav-lahn' spoken very quickly) OR une machine à laver + un sèche-linge

question: a clothes rack (for drying clothes)
answer: un étendoir; OR un portant á vêtements

question: a clothes pin
answer: la pince à linge

question: the clothes hamper (for dirty clothes)
answer: le panier à linge

question: the laundry (the clothes to being washed or dried)
answer: le linge

question: the laundry detergent (dry)
answer: la lessive ('lee-seev') en poudre

question: the fabric softener
answer: l'adoucissant or l'assouplissant; both are masculine

question: the iron (for ironing clothes)
answer: le fer à repasser ('fe-ra-ra-pa-say')

question: the ironing board
answer: la planche à repasser

question: a vacuum cleaner
answer: un aspirateur

question: the mop
answer: le balai

question: the broom
answer: le balai-brosse

question: the dustpan
answer: la pelle; same word as for shovel so you may have to specify

question: the bucket or pail
answer: le seau ('soo')

question: the bleach
answer: l'eau de javel

question: a trash can in a private home + a public trash or recycling bin

(Though in French matière also means a subject in school.); NB: There are two similar words with different meanings: un matériel (something physical required to complete an activity) and un matériau (materials required for construction)

answer: une matière; This can also mean a substance in the universe (matter).

It is only used to describe materials used for construction.; NB: un matière (= matter or a matter) is completely different. It means a substance in the universe or a subject of study/conversation.

question: Do adjectives come before or after the noun they describe?
answer: Generally adjectives follow the noun that they describe. But there are many exceptions. Some categories of adjectives are always placed before the noun. For example: Salutations like Bonne week-end! Bonne nuit. For example: Adjectives that indicate order/class (premier/première + dernier/dernière + etc) are placed before the noun they describe.; It is also true that some adjectives can be used on either side of the noun and the placement changes the meaning.

question: Which adjectives almost always come before the noun they are describing (instead of after it as expected)?
answer: autre + long + court + jeune + nouveau + vieux/vieille + petit(e) + grand(e) + gros(se) + joli(e) + mal/mauvais + beau/belle/beaux (beautiful; m/f/pl) + bon/bonne/bons/bonnes (good) + meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meilleures (better) + le meilleur/ la meilleure/ les meilleurs/ les meilleures (best); NB: When adjectives are used to indicate order/class (premier/première + dernier/dernière + etc) then they are also placed before the noun they describe.; NB: The masculine singular versions of these adjectives may change spelling if the noun begins with a vowel or silent H.

question: What changes when an adjective is placed before a noun instead of after it (as is the general case)?
answer: When an adjective is placed before a noun then the spelling of that noun becomes important. If the noun starts with a vowel then it may change the spelling of the adjective. This is most common for adjectives that end in -eau and -eux. For example: The masculine singular version of 'old' is vieux. But an old man = un vieil (not vieux) homme because H is treated as a vowel.

question: When an adjective can be placed either before a noun or after a noun - what does the placement indicate?
answer: There are many adjectives that change meaning completely depending on whether they are placed before or after the noun. But for the other adjectives that are generally always placed after a noun (e.g. magnifique) then the placement before the noun indicates a more emphathetic or subjective value. e.g. un paysage magnifique vs un magnifique paysage. The second example is more empathetic/subjective.

question: List 3 categories of adjectives that are placed before the noun.
answer: l'esthétique (une belle femme) + la taille (un grand écran) + un chiffre/l'âge (J'ai deux ans.)

question: List 3 categories of adjectives that are placed after the noun.
answer: la nationalité (la femme française) + la couleur (les yeux blue) + functionality (un écran étanche = a waterproof screen)

question: What is the general rule for adapting adjectives to gender and number?
answer: Add E to form feminine singular - this will force the pronunciation of the final consonant (that was silent in the masculine singular form) but it's a light touch on the consonant...it's not hard or heavy; Add S to form masculine plural; Add ES to form feminine plural; No change in pronunciation from the singular to plural forms of the same gender because the S and ES are generally silent.; There are many different variations of adjectives but this is the most basic transformation.

question: When do adjectives have the same spelling and pronunciation for masculine and feminine and plural?
answer: Generally any adjective that ends in an E or S or X in the masculine form is spelled the same in the feminine form.

question: good or nice

question: What is the difference in pronunciation between bon (good/masc) + bonne (good/fem) + beau (beautiful/masc) + beaucoup (many)?
answer: The first two have an extreme nasal quality: 'boh' and 'bohn'. Shoot the sound up at the roof of the mouth and out the nose. The third and fourth sound the same ('bow') without any nasal quality.

question: dead

question: old

question: Which adjectives (that are placed before a noun) change their form when the noun starts with a vowel?

question: new
